@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"TORONTO
Canadians sure love their fish.
Ripley’s Aquarium of Canada finally opened Wednesday at the base of the CN Tower
column2: with dozens of visitors exploring almost 40
column3: 000 square metres of marine habitat.

column1: The largest indoor aquarium in Canada is home to over 16
column2: 000 animals
column3: including sharks
column4: seahorses
column5: electric eels
column6: and poisonous fish.

column1: Even Mayor Rob Ford made a brief appearance at the launch. Reporters learned his favourite marine animal is the great white shark.
“It has a big mouth and it has sharp teeth
column2: ” Ford said. “If anything gets in its way
column3: he takes care of it pretty quick.”

column1: But Ford admitted he found ticket prices a little on the high side
column2: at $29.98 for adults
column3: $19.98 for youth aged 6-13 and seniors 65 and over
column4: and $9.98 for kids aged 3-5.

column1: “It’s a bit pricey
column2: but we’ll see what happens
column3: ” he said.

column1: Visitors can pet a sting ray
column2: stroke a horseshoe crab
column3: or engage in a stare-off with a cheeky green sawfish on a stroll through the aquarium’s underwater tunnel that is almost 100 metres long.

column1: Andy Dehart
column2: director of husbandry
column3: said he hopes people will learn more about life in the ocean through Ripley’s new venture.

column1: “There’s a lot of amazing things in nature
column2: whether it be male seahorses carrying babies
column3: whether it be fish that are venomous for protection
column4: or even sand tiger sharks
column5: how they can lose 30
column6: 000 teeth in a lifetime
column7: ” he said.

column1: The $130 million aquarium also features animals displaced during Superstorm Sandy last year.
Justin Culbert
column3: said his father first sparked his interest in marine life years ago. He now keeps a 250-litre reef tank at home.

column1: “My dad (and I) have been going (to aquariums) since I was little and just got into it and loved it
column2: ” Culbert said.

column1: The opening also attracted a protester from Marineland Animal Defence
column2: a group advocating for animals in captivity.

column1: Zach Ruiter
column3: said animals belong in the wild.

column1: “A pool is not a home
column2:

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Sign up to FREE email alerts from HullLive - Daily Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Invalid Email
It is already the most watched programme of 2017 as audiences have been left amazed by what is under our oceans.
BBC One’s Blue Planet II has been pulling in audiences of 14m
column2: outdoing the likes of Britain’s Got Talent
column3: I’m a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here and Strictly Come Dancing.

column1: But here in Hull you can watch the drama of the ocean depths and the colourful coral reefs up close with a trip to The Deep.
In the first episode of the Blue Planet II
column2: one of the stars of the show was Percy the tusk fish which was captured trying to break a clam on a bowl of coral.

column1: The Deep also has tusk fish and
column2: who knows
column3: other residents may become stars of the show in one of the five remaining episodes.

column1: “Everyone is loving the recent launch of Blue Planet II
column2: ” The Deep’s conservation officer Suzanne Rowe said. “From episode one
column3: everyone marvelled at the tool use behaviour of the tusk fish.

column1: “Its ingenious method of banging the clam against an exposed coral skeleton to get at the soft flesh inside was amazing to watch and demonstrated that tool use does indeed go beyond the intelligence of primates and birds.
“The Deep is home to another
column2: more colourful
column3: species of tusk fish – the Harlequin tusk fish. Its vivid orange and blue stripes really make it stand out from the crowd.

column1: “Like other tusk fish
column2: its large crushing fangs enable it to break open the tough shells of cockles
column3: mussels and clams. When they reach maturity the teeth of these fish turn bright blue
column4: adding to the intrigue.”

column1: As well as gaining an insight into the weird and wonderful world of our seas
column2: conservation is also a big part of the television series.

column1: “The Deep demonstrates the diversity of our world’s oceans
column2: ” Suzanne said. “Sadly many of these are now under threat.”

column1: Here Suzanne discusses some of the marine life which features at The Deep and its importance to the global environment.
Coral
The next episode of Blue Planet focuses on coral reefs and The Deep actually cultivates its own coral.
“There are over 2
column2: 500 species of coral inhabiting our world’s reefs
column3: with over 1
column4: 000 of these essential to building the structure of the coral reef itself
column5: ” Suzanne said.

column1: “Apart from being beautiful in structure and colouration
column2: coral reefs are an essential nursery ground for a number of fish and shark species. Many of these juveniles wouldn’t survive if they were suddenly forced into the open ocean.

column1: “Unfortunately
column2: corals are dying off at an alarming rate due to global warming and ocean acidification. They act as a buffer from storm surges and rising tides and are home to 25 per cent of all marine life on the planet.”

column1: Sharks
Sharks have already featured on Blue Planet II with six gills seen greedily devouring a whale carcass.
Hull is home to a variety of sharks
column2: including nurse
column3: epaulette
column4: zebra and reef sharks who could all yet feature in the series.

column1: “There are over 500 species of shark in the world
column2: ” Suzanne said. “They can be found in just about every ocean habitat
column3: from the shallow tropical reefs and the deepest of seas to the coldest Arctic Ocean.

column1: “Occurring in all shapes and sizes
column2: they range from the smallest dwarf lantern shark (the length of an adults hand) to the enormous whale shark which
column3: at 12 metres
column4: is the largest fish in the world.

column1: “Spotting sharks in the water is an indicator that a habitat is healthy
column2: most definitely a species that should be welcomed not feared.”

column1: Jellyfish
A field of tiny glowing jellyfish feature in the trailer for Blue Planet II so expect them to make an appearance at some point. The Deep has its fair share of the ghostly marine creatures.
“Despite their name
column2: jellyfish are not actually fish but a type of large gelatinous plankton
column3: ” Suzanne said. “With a fast reproductive rate and short lifespan
column4: they are an important food source for animals such as large fish
column5: turtles and even other jellyfish.

column1: “Increasing ocean temperatures are contributing to regular jellyfish blooms – an unwelcome sight to the regular beach-goer.
“They act as drifting nurseries for juvenile fish and crabs
column2: protected from predators by a wall of stinging trailing tentacles.”

column1: Penguins
(Image: The Deep)
Blue Planet II will cover all aspects of ocean life so it will be a surprise if the charismatic penguin doesn’t make an appearance.
The 13 gentoo penguins at The Deep have become stars of the aquarium since arriving three years ago.
“There are 18 species of penguin in the world
column2: ” Suzanne said
column3: “with the largest being the emperor penguin and the smallest the little penguin. In all
column4: of these are classed as threatened or endangered due to a reduced number of fish and loss of habitat.

column1: “But penguins do more than make us smile – they are an important link between the land and sea. Carrying nutrients between both habitats
column2: their faeces are an essential fertiliser
column3: enriching both the soil and the seabed.""

column1: Turtles
This iconic species will feature heavily in Sunday’s episode on corals which will show green turtles being pampered by fish who will clean the animals of parasites and algae.
The Deep has recently taken in two previously injured loggerhead turtles who have settled well in the Endless Ocean tank.
“All seven turtle species are considered threatened or endangered
column2: ” Suzanne said. “Man-made threats such as pollution
column3: habitat destruction and the loss of nesting beaches are all contributing to population decline.

column1: “Having been around for millions of years
column2: they truly are ancient beings. Only able to breed from 35-40 years old
column3: they live most of their lives at sea
column4: only returning to the beach where they were born to lay their eggs.”

column1: Starfish
Such is their numbers and variety
column2: you will see starfish appear throughout the Blue Planet II series and there are plenty at The Deep which you can even handle in the touch tank sessions.

column1: “Also known as sea stars
column2: anyone who has seen a starfish will know that it bears no resemblance to a fish
column3: ” Suzanne said.

column1: “There are around 2
column2: 000 species of starfish living in our world’s oceans
column3: from the tropical waters to the freezing Arctic and from shallow reefs to the deep sea. So named for their typical five-armed appearance
column4: there are some with ten
column5: 20 and even 40 arms!""

column1: Medical importance
Suzanne and other marine experts and conservationists hope the popularity of programmes like Blue Planet II will raise awareness of the oceans’ importance.
“It’s clear the animals in the ocean depend on each other for survival
column2: ” she said
column3: “and we depend on the oceans for the survival of the land.

column1: “But our dependence on them runs even deeper than a means for food
column2: industry and tourism. Many marine species have contribute to ground-breaking medical diagnosis and treatments.

column1: “Did you know that barnacles have helped create ‘Medhesive’
column2: a bacteria resistant surgical glue that can be used both inside and outside of the body to repair life threatening wounds and injuries.

column1: “Pain relief for those resistant to morphine has been derived from the venomous cone snails and glowing cells found in jellyfish are being used to find tumours hidden deep within the body.
“Marine sponges are already being used to stop advanced breast cancer cells in their tracks. It’s strikingly obvious that if we want to save ourselves
column2: we need to save the ocean – the life source of this planet.”

column1: The Deep's stars that should feature on Blue Planet II
There have been two episodes of the show so far with the humble tusk fish the only animal to feature on the show which can also be seen at The Deep.
A grouper will feature in this Sunday’s episode which can use sign language. The Deep has its own potato grouper called Eddie but it has no other groupers to chat to!
We pick some of the creatures at The Deep which could and should feature on Blue Planet II.
Green sawfish - found in The Deep’s Endless Oceans tank
column2: sawfish are a type of ray.

column1: These strange looking fish are specialised feeders who use their impressive toothed rostrum to sift through the sand in search of prey and can immobilise them with one hard swipe.
Atlantic mudskipper - found next to The Deep’s Lagoon of Light
column2: this amphibious fish can walk on land using its specialised pectoral fins during low tide.

column1: Their party trick is the ability to roll their eyeballs in their specialised water-filled sockets to refresh their faces and gills with oxygenated water
column2: which allows them to breathe on land.

column1: Living in the world’s mangrove forests
column2: these are highly sensitive creatures with great ecological importance.

column1: Bicolor parrotfish - found in The Deep’s lagoon tank
column2: parrotfish come in an exciting array of colours and has an unusually shaped mouth.

column1: Scraping algae and food from coral reefs
column2: they ingest a lot of rock
column3: which is excreted as fine white sand – the stuff we like to sunbathe on.

column1: They also have another trick up their sleeve by tucking themselves into bed at night in a cosy mucus sleeping bag
column2: protecting them from parasites and predators.

column1: (Image: The Deep)
Porcupine pufferfish - the Deep’s pufferfish can be found in the lagoon tank. This fish is pretty cute
column2: but there is no denying it’s an oddball.

column1: Pufferfish have the ability to inflate their body to twice its size when threatened
column2: making its sharp spines stick up. Despite its spiky exterior
column3: this fish has a fun and quirky personality – but it is highly venomous.

column1: Wolf eel - found in The Deep’s Cool Seas exhibit this creature is not a wolf
column2: nor is it an eel.

column1: These animals are relatively shy but they have one of the strongest jaws in the animal kingdom.
Their fang-like teeth are designed to deliver a nasty bite which is perfect for eating sea urchins and crabs.
Are you looking for a job? Click here to see our Hull listings
Wolf eels also have another quirky adaptation. Their blood contains a special antifreeze factor
column2: keeping their blood fluid at temperatures as low as -30C.";Loving Blue Planet II? column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Rays and Skates – Skate Video
by Dick Marquand
Rays and skates often cause anglers confusion. Let’s take a look at some of the members of the Order Rajiformes and their various differences. This order includes stingrays
column2: eagle rays
column3: skates
column4: electric rays
column5: as well as tropical species such as manta rays and sawfish. Although rays and skates at first glance appear to look very similar
column6: they are quite different when you know what to look for. Stingrays
column7: for example
column8: are nearly always nearly black on top and light grey underneath. The head of the stingray blends into the body.

column1: The head of the eagle ray
column2: by contrast
column3: is at the front of the body jutting forward and rises above the back appearing almost frog-like. The back of the eagle ray is also much lighter in colour and tends to be greenish with dabs of blue.

column1: Skates are more diamond-shaped and have an upper body colour that is usually pinkish-brown and speckled with darker markings. Like the stingray the head of the skate blends into the body barely rising above the back at all. Skates also tend to have wider fleshier tails.
Caught at Nape Nape Beach
column2: North Canterbury
column3: during a surfcasting competition.

column1: Stingray Facts:
There are two species of stingray commonly found in New Zealand waters
column2: these being the long-tailed stingray Dasyatis thetidis and the short-tailed stingray Dasyatis brevicaudata. The easiest way to differentiate between these species is by the length of the tail.

column1: The long-tailed stingray has a whip-like tail which is longer than its body. About a quarter of the way down the tail one or two long serrated barbed spines project from the upper side. On the other hand
column2: the short-tailed stingray has a thicker tail which is shorter than the length of its body. It too has one or two barbed spines which may measure up to 30 centimetres in length.

column1: A Stingray Barb can cause a fatal injury
Stingrays are not generally regarded as dangerous to humans although over the years there have been incidents where swimmers have been killed or seriously injured by their flailing tail barbs.

Stingrays have a habit of resting on the bottom sometimes in quite shallow water. It is thought that swimmers may have accidentally stood on or surprised a stingray in such situations causing it to lash-out in an attempt to escape. Fatalities from stingrays are extremely rare.
Although the spines contain venom and a strike can be very painful
column2: they are usually deadly. When deaths to people have occurred it is when the barb has hit a vital organ. Most notably when Steve Irwin
column3: the Australian wildlife expert
column4: was tragically killed by a stingray barb in 2006 when it pierced his heart

column1: How big can a stingray get
Stingrays can grow to a weight of at least 240kg (500lb) and a width across the flaps of between two and three metres. They frequent shallow inshore waters
column2: particularly harbours
column3: inlets and just offshore of the breaker line on sheltered surf beaches
column4: where they feed on crabs and shellfish. Both species are found in the waters of the North Island and generally
column5: it is the short-tailed stingray that is found in our southern waters. The colouration of the upper surface is usually dark grey
column6: brown or black.

column1: Generally
column2: stingrays are not targeted by anglers
column3: but when they are accidentally taken on a surfcasting outfit
column4: they put up a long and powerful fight. One warm autumn day
column5: while fishing on the bottom inside the mouth of Thompson Sound
column6: one of my crew
column7: Bill Routhan of Hokitika
column8: had a solid hook-up in about 10 fathoms. The fish moved off on a long powerful run
column9: testing the line and my old Penn Sea Boy reel.

column1: We had no idea what Bill was hooked onto until an hour later when the shape of a ray appeared beneath “Samara.” As Bill eased the fish alongside
column2: Pete missed with the gaff and another 20 minutes passed before the ray could be coaxed close enough to be secured. The short-tailed stingray had two spines on the back of its tail
column3: the largest of which was 12 centimetres long. It was an amazing capture on a thin wire hook which had foul-hooked the ray under one wing. The ray later weighed in at 34kg (75lb).

column1: Surfcasting success after a long drawn out battle with light gear. Barry Toomey with his 40kg Eagle Ray caught at Tukurua Beach
column2: Nelson. Read about this eagle ray being caught here.

column1: Eagle Rays:

The eagle ray Myliobatus tenuicaudatus is a common species in estuaries and harbours of the North Island where it can be seen basking in the warm shallows or slowly moving along the bottom in search of crabs and shellfish. They are relatively uncommon in the South Island but have been recorded as far south as Poison Bay near Milford Sound. However
column2: eagle rays can be seen in large numbers
column3: particularly at low tide in Westhaven Inlet near Collingwood.

column1: The species can have a wingspan of up to 1.5 metres and is easily recognised by its head which protrudes in front of the swept-back delta-shaped wings. It has a long whip-like tail with a sharply pointed barbed spine protruding from the upper side
column2: not far behind the body. The colouring on the upper surface is greyish brown to greenish-brown with brilliant blue markings.

column1: The eagle ray provides great sport on a light surf outfit or boat rod and generally gives a hard fight with long powerful runs. The largest I have seen would weigh around 50kg (110lb).
Skates:
There are two species of skates that are likely to be seen by anglers around the coastline of the South Island; they are the rough skate Raja nasuta and the smooth skate Raja innominata.

The rough skate is found in shallow waters on a muddy or sandy seafloor and is commonly caught by surf anglers on the west coast of the South Island. The species can grow to around one metre across the wings
column2: but most of the specimens that I have seen have been half that size.

column1: This enormous skate was caught by Liz Melrose while surfcasting at Coopers Lagoon near the Rakaia River mouth. It weighed a hefty 40kg and measured seven feet in length. We think this particularly large specimen is a rough skate but cannot be 100 percent certain. Note the tail with its sharp thorns has been removed.

Three rows of small spines or prickles run down the top side of the tail which does not have the spine or barb that is found on the stingrays and the eagle ray. The colouration on the upper surface is brown with dark marbled patches.
More about Rough Skate – Raja nasuta which are often caught by surfcasters
One night while fishing the shallow waters of Poison Bay
column2: I had some great sport fishing for skates with a light threadline outfit. Although only 50 centimetres across the wings
column3: the skates put up a terrific fight on 3kg line with plenty of long hard runs. I landed and released five and lost at least as many.

column1: The smooth skate is not encountered as often by anglers as the rough skate
column2: as it prefers deeper waters. This species grows to over 1.5 metres across the wings and as the name suggests
column3: the upper surface is usually smooth. Colouration is usually grey with dark brown spots.

column1: I have only ever caught two smooth skates
column2: both in Milford Sound. One was a large specimen perhaps two metres across and was taken at the head of the sound near the Sinbad River mouth. It came up from the depths like a grey blanket and after a quick photograph
column3: it was released.

column1: In his book “A Treasury of New Zealand Fishes
column2: ” David H. Graham makes mention of one in Milford Sound that was over seven feet in length. He also reports that in 1862
column3: a large skate was caught that was ten feet in length and weighed 4221b. I would imagine that both these fish were smooth skates.

column1: Skate eat molluscs
column2: crustaceans
column3: and various species of small fish likely found on the bottom. Skate will also take fish that have been hooked by anglers lines. Skate is often caught by surfcasters. Here is a skate caught surfcasting by Allan Burgess at Amberley Beach. Few surfcasters would deliberately try to catch skate. If you are attempting to catch one
column4: as you might during a surfcasting competition
column5: then a really long distance cast as far beyond the surf-zone as possible seems to be the way to go.

column1: Eating Rays and Skates

The wings of both rays and skates are good eating. Skate has a delicate flavour and is very good cooked in a variety of ways but they are not a popular fish in New Zealand. Skate wings are sold in shops which have been skinned with the cartilage still in the centre. Stingrays are not usually eaten in New Zealand although they are popular in other parts of the world.
Other Rajiformes
Electric rays are widespread throughout New Zealand’s coastal waters and although usually seen amongst trawl catches
column2: a few are also taken by line anglers. They grow to over one metre in length and are capable of delivering a severe electric shock. Two species of the blind electric ray are also found in our waters but these are deep water inhabitants and are not likely to be encountered by anglers.

column1: Manta rays are occasionally seen by offshore anglers fishing the northern coastal waters of New Zealand. They can easily be recognised as they swim just beneath the surface by the two projecting horns each side of the head. Mantas are known to grow to at least 6 metres between the wings and attain a weight of at least 2000kg. They feed on small fish and zooplankton and are occasionally seen leaping clear of the sea’s surface. It is very unlikely that this species would venture into the cooler waters of the South Island.
Sawfish are not found in New Zealand waters but are nevertheless a close relative of the rays. The Longcomb sawfish
column2: Narrowsnout sawfish or Green sawfish Pristis zijsron can reach a length of 10 metres of which at least 2 metres is its saw-like rostrum.

column1: Rays and Skates – Release Unwanted Fish
So
column2: when you next land a ray or a skate
column3: take a couple of seconds to decide if you are going to use it. Although the flesh on the wings is edible if prepared correctly
column4: it is my opinion that there are better food species in our waters. If you aren’t going to use the fish
column5: don’t kill it for the sake of killing. Instead
column6: show a little mercy and release your catch. The text of this article has been extended by Allan Burgess.

column1: Smooth skates Raja-innominata occasionally come into shallow waters. Ian Cole caught this one while surfcasting at Carters Beach
column2: South Westland.";Rays and Skates – Stingray
column3: Eagle Ray

column5:

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Her passion for marine science started with a pair of goldfish
column2: Salt and Pepper

column1: Shedd Aquarium's Cheryl Mell
column2: senior VP of global field expeditions and conservation ambassador
column3: swims inside the shark tank on June 18
column4: 2015 in Chicago. (Abel Uribe/Chicago Tribune/TNS) Shedd Aquarium's Cheryl Mell
column5: senior VP of global field expeditions and conservation ambassador
column6: swims inside the shark tank on June 18
column7: 2015 in Chicago. (Abel Uribe/Chicago Tribune/TNS) Image 1 of / 3 Caption Close Her passion for marine science started with a pair of goldfish
column8: Salt and Pepper 1 / 3 Back to Gallery

column1: Cheryl Mell’s road to Chicago’s Shedd Aquarium seems almost preordained.
As a kid growing up in Morton Grove
column2: Ill.
column3: she was never able to have the most common pets.

column1: “Both my sisters and my mother have allergies to dogs and cats
column2: ” she says
column3: sitting in her office at the Shedd
column4: where she is senior vice president for global field expeditions and conservation ambassador. “(My interest) truly started with a pair of carnival goldfish. Salt and Pepper
column5: one white
column6: one black. So at a young age I got into fish.”

column1: She had an aquarium by the time she was in the fourth grade
column2: and by seventh grade she knew she wanted to study marine biology. By her junior year of high school
column3: she was scuba diving.

column1: Mell went off to the University of Miami
column2: where she received her bachelor of science degree in biology and marine science in 1989 and a master of science in education
column3: biology and secondary education in 1991.

column1: In an interesting twist
column2: while doing undergrad work she spent a lot of time on the Shedd’s research ship
column3: the Coral Reef II
column4: which the University of Miami leased.

column1: “I came back after grad school and stopped in Chicago to see family
column2: ” Mell says. “On my bed was an ad
column3: cut out of the paper
column4: for an educator at the Shedd. … I applied as soon as I saw the position.”

column1: She got the job and has been at the Shedd for 24 years. It has been a wonderful relationship.
“I’m so lucky
column2: ” she says. “My passions are education and marine life. To bring the two together
column3: it doesn’t get any better.”

column1: During a recent visit in her office
column2: Mell
column4: talked about her time at the Shedd and three of her favorite topics: conservation
column5: education and travel. This is an edited transcript of the conversation.

column1: Q: Is aquatic conservation what you consider your area of expertise?
A: Yes
column2: it’s one of my focuses. This is my seventh job here. I always say the Shedd was a good fit for me
column3: and I was a good fit for the Shedd. I’m a marine educator at heart.

column1: Q: Your bio mentions that part of your job is providing travel opportunities. What kind of travel do you have a hand in?
A: I work a lot with tourism businesses. Right now
column2: we’re working with New Brunswick in Canada. We love to take Shedd Aquarium members to these beautiful sites. For the most part
column3: our audience has been members or friends of members. We recently had a woman who brought a friend
column4: a musician (she met at a CSO concert)
column5: and she went on the Amazon trip. What I loved
column6: she saw things with the eye of an artist.

column1: Q: And you’re also reaching out to younger people.
A: This year
column2: for the first time
column3: we’re doing a trip aimed at millennials
column4: open just to people 21 to 35 years old. It’s to Cancun
column5: and they will swim with whale sharks. Here’s this group of young professionals who are so excited to get in the water with the largest shark in the world. What’s killing me: I planned it
column6: but I don’t qualify in the age group.

column1: Q: Whale sharks?
A: They go to Cancun in the summer to feed on plankton. The divers will go in the water
column2: a pair at a time.

column1: Q: Do people in that age group present any special challenges?
A: Millennials want short trips
column2: with a price point not to go over $1
column3: 800. But they want Wi-Fi in their hotel
column4: so they can brag to their friends.

column1: Q: You have been to seven continents and have seen some amazing things. How do you maintain a sense of wonderment
column2: curiosity?

column1: A: It comes much easier than you expect. You meet fellow travelers: “Where do you go next?” “Did you go down that street?” The travel community just inspires. I have visited almost 100 countries. But it’s not about a checklist. I love traveling because it broadens my horizons. I do a lot of conservation travel. It settles me
column2: gives me an appreciation.

column1: Q: Do you have a favorite spot?
A: For aquatic life
column2: animals
column3: the Galapagos Islands. The animals have no fear. It’s phenomenal. You can get right up to them. The other place is the Peninsula Valdes
column4: off the coast of Argentina. There are whales
column5: rookeries of penguins. We climbed a lighthouse and saw orcas going by. At almost the end of the day
column6: we saw a herd of elephant seals on the beach. It was there I had an aha moment. I slipped and fell on the beach — all these small pebbles. And the pebbles were warm. No wonder the seals lie on that beach.

column1: Q: Where are you going next?

A: In August we’re going to Borneo. We’re going there to scout it out. We’re partnering with Brookfield Zoo on this. They have experts on orangutans; Shedd has experts on coral. We’re looking at a 10- or 12-day trip in 2017. I think there are a lot of Shedd members who would like to make that trip.
Q: People taking one of your trips will see things that fascinate them. How do they make the leap to “I want to do something to help?”
A: A lot of the magic comes from the trip leaders. There’s always a Shedd staffer on each trip. They hear a leader talk so passionately about an endangered fish
column2: and maybe they can’t save that fish
column3: but they can do something when they get home.

column1: Q: Educate themselves? Teach their children? Any books or videos you recommend?

A: I joke because I’m a 47-year-old woman who watches Channel 7 (WLS-TV) Saturday mornings to see all the animal programming. A great way (to do something is) the Great Lakes Action Days (a Shedd initiative to restore habitat; several events are scheduled from July to October). There are beach cleanups
column2: or you go out and capture amphibians
column3: you test waters. (But) there are a lot of good organizations
column4: a lot of ways to get involved.

column1: Q: After we’re done here
column2: you’re going diving in the “Wild Reef” exhibit. Is that for fun?

column1: A: It’s a working dive. We dive several days a week. It’s a cleaning and feeding dive.
Q: What’s it like?
A: There are leopard sharks
column2: Napoleon wrasse (also called humphead wrasse) and a green sawfish named Ginsu. She makes her beds — she has two — on the bottom. We go to the bottom and smooth the gravel. We literally make her bed. Feeding them is fun
column3: but making Ginsu’s bed is my favorite part of it.

column1: Q: What is your favorite exhibit at the Shedd?
A: I actually have two
column2: both in “Wild Reef.” I love the garden eels because
column3: as a diver
column4: I can tell you that seeing them in the wild can be tricky since they duck down into the sand very fast. At Shedd
column5: you have the opportunity to see them fully and at eye level. The second are live algae and coral habitats
column6: just past the main shark exhibit. They are so beautiful. It’s so magical to see live coral and algae with bright fish swimming by.

column1: Q: Do you have any other favorite animals?
A: The manta ray. They can grow up to 20 feet long
column2: but they are actually beautiful gentle giants. I’ve been lucky enough to see them in the wild
column3: and I was so moved by their grace and beauty that I actually got a tattoo of one while I was in Tahiti.

column1: Q: What do you do when you’re not working?
A: I’m not married
column2: no kids
column3: but I have six nieces and nephews. I’m referred to as cool Auntie Cheryl. They’ve come here all their lives. Sleepovers
column4: everything. Summertime is a good time for me. I’m an avid kayaker. I’m on the river all the time. I live next to Wrigley Field
column5: so my dog
column6: Fozzie Bear
column7: and I spend a lot of time at the Wilson Avenue beach. I spend a lot of time with family and friends. I live by that Southport Corridor
column8: with a lot of great restaurants.

column1: Q: What kind of music do you listen to?
A: I kick it old school. Van Morrison
column2: Steely Dan
column3: James Taylor.

column1: Q: Are there any must-see places you haven’t seen yet?
A: I’m dying to go to India. And Papua New Guinea and Madagascar. But for all of them
column2: I’d need a minimum of three weeks.";Her passion for marine science started with a pair of goldfish

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Two Hawaiian monk seal pups — a male and female — rescued from Laysan Island are now receiving care at Ke Kai Ola
column2: the hospital run by The Marine Mammal Center in Kailua-Kona.

column1: The newly weaned pups
column2: ‘Akulikuli and Maiapilo
column3: were suffering from malnutrition in the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands
column4: according to Ke Kai Ola
column5: but their Sept. 13 arrival was delayed due to Hurricane Olivia.

column1: The Oscar Elton Sette
column2: the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s research vessel that rescued the seals
column3: had to seek shelter at Pearl Harbor as the hurricane approached the islands and wait for the storm to pass before transporting the two monk seal pups to Hawaii island.

column1: “Both of these pups have had quite a harrowing journey due to Hurricane Olivia before they arrived at the hospital
column2: ” said Ke Kai Ola hospital manager Claire Simeone in a news release. “We are grateful to have many partners who reacted quickly to handle this unique situation and give these pups a second chance at life.”

column1: Both pups are now active and doing well
column2: officials said.

column1: They joined Sole and RK58
column2: two male pups already undergoing rehabilitation at Ke Kai Ola since this summer.

column1: ‘Akulikuli
column2: a male
column3: had a few lacerations on his face and a small ulcer on the roof of his mouth. He weighs about 24 pounds lighter than his companion
column4: Maiapilo
column5: a female. Both are being fed a “fish-mash smoothie” three times a day to help them get vital nutrients.

column1: Megan McGinnis
column2: animal care manager at the Big Island facility
column3: described ‘Akulikuli as small
column4: but vocal
column5: and Maiapilo as “feisty from the start.”

column1: ‘Akulikuli is named after an indigenous coastline plant
column2: while Maiapilo is named after a plant native to Laysan Island.

column1: Hawaiian monk seals are an endangered species
column2: with an estimated population of about 1
column3: 400 remaining in the wild
column4: officials say.

column1: Wildlife officials remind the public to remain a safe distance from Hawaiian monk seals
column2: especially moms and pups. Sick and injured seals on Hawaii island can be reported to Ke Kai Ola’s 24-hour hotline at 987-0765. column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Federal officials are reminding the public to keep a good distance from a female monk seal that has hauled out at a Waikiki Beach for the fourth day on Wednesday.
The seal
column2: identified as 8-year-old Kaiwi
column3: has given birth to two pups previously in South or East Oahu
column4: which are areas that she frequents.

column1: While National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration officials do not believe Kaiwi
column2: based on appearances
column3: is pregnant this time
column4: there is still a possibility that she is.

column1: “This would be the time of year that she would give birth based on her previous puppings
column2: ” said NOAA marine mammal response coordinator Dave Schofield. “However
column3: she’s not as large as we would expect to see her if she was giving birth at the beginning of May. Based on appearances
column4: we’re feeling that she’s not pregnant.”

column1: PHOTO GALLERY >> Hawaiian Monk Seal visits Fort DeRussy Beach Park
Still
column2: since Hawaiian monk seals
column3: an endangered species protected by both state and federal laws
column4: typically forage at night and haul up to rest during the day
column5: NOAA is reminding the public in a high traffic area such as Waikiki to give Kaiwi some space.

column1: “There’s a lot going on in Waikiki
column2: so any time a seal hauls up in a high human use area
column3: we ask people to use precaution to keep the noise level to a minimum and to give a seal some space
column4: ” said Schofield.

column1: NOAA asks that people not try to get a close-up selfie with the monk seal
column2: and to stay behind protective borders that have been set up at a safe distance.

column1: Volunteers from Hawaii Marine Animal Response
column2: a non-profit that works with NOAA
column3: have already set up a border around Kaiwi and are keeping an eye on her safety from sunup to sundown.

column1: The year 2018 was a banner year for monk seal pups
column2: with 30 pups born in the main Hawaiian isles.

column1: While NOAA officials are not 100% sure if Kaiwi is expecting or not
column2: they hope that if she is
column3: she will give birth in a more remote location.

column2: Rocky the monk seal created a stir
column3: giving birth to a pup at crowded Kaimana Beach in Waikiki. The pup kept swimming into the Natatorium nearby
column4: and was eventually translocated after weaning to a more remote location away from crowds. Last year
column5: NOAA officials breathed a sigh of relief when Rocky returned to her usual pupping location on Kauai to give birth to her pup.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Federal officials had good news regarding critically endangered Hawaiian monk seals — the population in Hawaii appears to be holding steady due to recovery efforts.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported this month that the monk seal population in 2019 was about the same as in 2018
column2: with slightly more than 1
column3: 400 seals
column4: with approximately 1
column5: 100 in the Northwestern Hawaiian isles and 300 in the main Hawaiian isles.

column1: “The 2019 results provide strong evidence that the number of seals in this region has been growing since at least 2013
column2: ” said NOAA Fishers. “Despite these positive signs
column3: we must work to mitigate many human-associated threats to the main Hawaiian Islands monk seal population. These include Toxoplasma
column4: fisheries interactions
column5: and intentional killings.”

column1: According to NOAA
column2: a record high of 48 pups was born in the main Hawaiian isles last year
column3: marking a particularly good reproductive year.

column1: Interventions are also paying off.
Just last week
column2: NOAA and The Marine Mammal Center successfully released RA20
column3: one of a handful of seals that spends the majority of their time on Hawaii island
column4: at Ooma Beach Park.

column1: RA20 is an adult female monk seal
column2: and mother to the last two pups born on Hawaii island. She is regularly seen near the Fairmont Orchid
column3: but on Feb. 29 was displaying abnormal behavior that continued for several days.

column1: A team rescued RA20 and brought her to TMMC’s Ke Kai Ola
column2: a monk seal hospital in Kona
column3: where veterinarians determined she had a bacterial infection. Upon further exam
column4: veterinarians also suspected she may have recently lost a pregnancy.

column1: Despite the good news in seal count
column2: the report also found that fewer juvenile monk seals have survived at several of the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands sites than in past years. On Oahu’s North Shore
column3: drowning in fishing nets was the most likely cause of death for three juvenile seals in 2019.

column1: Last year
column2: two important seal pupping islets at French Frigate Shoals reappeared after being inundated or washed away by Hurricane Walaka in 2018
column3: but still offer a limited area for seal pupping. Researchers translocated pups from the area to safer havens on higher ground.

column2: NOAA worked with partners to mitigate threats to monk seals with the following actions:

column1: >> Disentangled marine debris from 12 seals in the NWHI
column2: and two seals in the main Hawaiian isles.

column1: >> Rescued five seals from entrapment or drowning in the human-made sea wall at Tern Island and French Frigate Shoals.
>> Removed fish hooks from 21 seals in the main Hawaiian Islands.
>> Sent six undersized seals — four from the NWHI
column2: and two from the main isles – to Ke Kai Ola.

column1: >> Translocated 14 pups from areas of high shark predation and nine seals from male seal aggression within atolls in the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands.
>> Vaccinated seals against morbillivirus and treated infections with antibiotics.
>> Reunited moms and pups that had become separated.
Ke Kai Ola in Kona continues to care of Pohaku
column2: or RO28
column3: a female seal recovering from toxoplasmosis
column4: a parasitic disease spread through cat feces
column5: as well as four seal pups rescued from Pearl and Hermes Atoll and Lisisanski Island last year.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"A critically ill Hawaiian monk seal has been rescued from Kauai for the second time and is now under the care of a monk seal hospital in Kailua-Kona.
RH38
column2: a juvenile female monk seal
column3: is in stable
column4: but critical condition
column5: according to Ke Kai Ola
column6: a monk seal hospital run by The Marine Mammal Center. The center’s veterinary team conducted initial tests and found that RH38 is suffering from weakness
column7: infection
column9: the team is still trying to pinpoint the cause of these symptoms.

column1: She has been provided with life-saving and supportive care
column2: and the team continues to conduct extensive testing to find the cause of illness in the endangered monk seal. Most recently
column3: she was transported to North Hawaii Community Hospital for a CT scan — the first ever performed on a wild Hawaiian monk seal.

column1: “We’re incredibly concerned by RH38’s case as every individual is critical to this endangered population
column2: ” said Dr. Claire Simeone
column3: the center’s hospital director
column4: in a news release. “We are committed to finding the cause of her illness and are using world-class expertise and medical techniques to keep RH38 alive and get her back to the wild.”

column1: Over the past year
column2: the Kauai Hawaiian Monk Seal Conservation Hui has been monitoring RH38
column3: and volunteers routinely observed her in good body condition. In March
column4: however
column5: her body condition rapidly grew worse.

column1: She was rescued from Kauai on March 12 and transported by the U.S. Coast Guard to Ke Kai Ola.
The center said RH38 has been tested for dozens of diseases
column2: toxins and parasites. Veterinarians have not found any evidence of toxoplasmosis
column3: leptospirosis
column4: morbillivirus
column5: or influenza
column6: trauma or poison
column7: but are not ruling anything out at this point.

column1: In August 2017
column2: RH38 was also admitted to Ke Kai Ola for malnutrition and parasites. During three months of rehabilitation
column3: she more than doubled her body weight and was successfully released back to the wild in Kauai.

column1: Federal researchers from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will continue to monitor the population of monk seals on Kauai
column2: but so far
column3: have found no indication that there is a threat to the larger population.

column1: “No additional sick or malnourished monk seals have been detected across the main Hawaiian islands
column2: ” said Michelle Barbieri
column3: a veterinarian with NOAA’s Hawaiian Monk Seal Research Program
column4: in a statement. “We do not currently have any reason to believe that what is affecting RH38 is contagious to the rest of the population.”

column1: Since opening in 2014
column2: Ke Kai Ola has rehabilitated 27 monk seals
column3: most of which were rescued from and returned to the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands. Hawaiian monk seals are a critically endangered species protected by state and federal laws. Only an estimated 1
column4: 400 remain in the wild.

column1: NOAA reminds the public to keep a safe distance from monk seals. Sightings on Hawaii island can be reported to the center’s response team at 987-0765. Statewide
column2: monk seal sightings can be reported to NOAA’s hotline at 888-256-9840.";Critically ill monk seal gets CT scan at North Hawaii Community Hospital;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMif2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnN0YXJhZHZlcnRpc2VyLmNvbS8yMDE5LzA0LzIzL2hhd2FpaS1uZXdzL2NyaXRpY2FsbHktaWxsLW1vbmstc2VhbC1nZXRzLWN0LXNjYW4tYXQtbm9ydGgtaGF3YWlpLWNvbW11bml0eS1ob3NwaXRhbC_SAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://www.staradvertiser.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/web1_20190423_brk_rh3801.jpg;04/23/2019;[{'sent': 'A critically ill Hawaiian monk seal has been rescued from Kauai for the second time and is now under the care of a monk seal hospital in Kailua-Kona.\n\n'

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The attorney for a man who slapped a Hawaiian monk seal while visiting Oahu several months ago has issued an apology on behalf of his client.
Attorney Blake Long of Barnwell & Long PLLC in North Carolina said the young man
column2: who he advised to remain anonymous to avoid severe backlash
column3: has paid fines from federal and state agencies in full for his violation of the Endangered Species Act. He did not disclose the amount paid.

column1: Long said his client requested that he issue the apology “to express his sincere remorse for his immature
column2: inexcusable actions.”

column1: In February
column2: officials from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Office of Law Enforcement
column3: as well as the state Division of Conservation and Resources Enforcement
column4: began investigating an incident posted to TikTok
column5: which showed a man approaching a monk seal from behind
column6: leaning over
column7: and then slapping it in the hindquarters.

column1: The incident was also shared on other social media platforms
column2: including Instagram.

column1: “While this is an incident that my client wishes to leave behind
column2: he is also hopeful that his mistake will be used as an example of the types of conduct tourists must avoid when encountering wildlife
column3: ” said the statement. “It is imperative that one maintains a respectful distance when observing all animals so as not to cause a disruption
column4: potential harm or agitation to the animal or its environment.”

column1: The statement continues: “The hope of my client and of the law enforcement officers involved in this matter is that my client’s brief lapse of judgment serves as a lesson that ultimately aids in the protection of both the indigenous species of Hawaii and those who are fortunate enough to observe them personally. To all who were dismayed at my client’s actions
column2: please accept this apology expressing my client’s utmost regret and learn from his example as to the respect and care that must be afforded to wildlife not only in Hawaii
column3: but across the world.”

column1: NOAA’s Office of Law Enforcement responded with its own statement
column2: warning that more seals may actually be resting on Hawaii shorelines due to the “stay-at-home” orders during the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: “Hawaiian Monk seals are endangered species and are protected by state and federal law
column2: ” said NOAA. “Harassing a protected species has serious consequences. This is a friendly reminder for our ocean users that the animals do frequent beaches to rest and with less beach traffic
column3: you are seeing more animals come ashore to rest and sun themselves.”

column1: In its viewing guidelines for marine wildlife in Hawaii
column2: NOAA recommends staying at least 50 feet away from Hawaiian monk seals.

column1: “There is no need to get close — your sudden movements may cause them to either flush into the water
column2: or charge you
column3: ” said NOAA. “It is best to view them from afar. Use binoculars or your camera’s zoom lens for a close up photo.”

column1: The Hawaiian monk seals — with a population of about 1
column2: 400 — are protected under the Marine Mammal Protection Act and Endangered Species Act. Under Hawaii law
column3: the harassment of a monk seal is considered a class C felony
column4: punishable by imprisonment and fines.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Wildlife officials have determined that R028
column2: a sick female Hawaiian monk seal under its care
column3: is suffering from toxoplasmosis.

column1: Following test results
column2: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration officials determined that R028
column3: also known as Pohaku
column4: is suffering from the parasitic infection often spread into the environment via feral cat feces.

column1: “Despite aggressive treatment
column2: she is very lethargic
column3: a sign that the infection is causing pain and severe inflammation throughout her internal organs
column4: ” said NOAA in the latest update on its website.

column1: Officials picked up Pohaku from Ko Olina
column2: and brought her to NOAA’s headquarters on Jan. 22 for monitoring after reports that she was “logging
column3: ” or lethargically floating on the water
column4: a sign of possible illness.

column1: “Toxoplasmosis is a disease caused by infection with Toxoplasma gondii
column2: a parasite that reproduces in the digestive system of cats and spreads oocysts (eggs) into the environment via cat feces
column3: ” said NOAA officials in the post. “Feral cats
column4: of which there are an estimated 50
column6: 000 on the island of Oahu alone
column7: are the primary source of T. gondii oocysts in Hawaii.”

column1: Hawaiian monk seals are exposed to these oocysts when they consume contaminated prey or water.
The parasite destroys vital tissues
column2: such as muscle
column3: liver
column4: heart and brain tissues
column5: officials said
column6: which can lead to organ failure. Unfortunately
column7: there is currently no vaccine for toxoplasmosis
column8: and treatment options for infected seals are extremely limited.

column1: So far
column2: Pohaku has done better than most monk seals with toxoplasmosis
column3: who are often found dead without warning. Two seals that were rescued prior to death succumbed to the disease within 48 hours.

column1: “However
column2: we are very guarded in our optimism
column3: ” NOAA officials said. “RO28’s prognosis is still poor given the aggressive nature of this disease and RO28’s lethargic condition in intensive care.”

column1: To date
column2: 11 Hawaiian monk seals are known to have died as a direct result of toxoplasmosis
column3: but the number is likely higher due to unreported cases. Toxoplasmosis also affects other marine animals
column4: including spinner dolphins and native birds
column5: including alala
column6: or Hawaiian crows.

column1: NOAA officials say the public can help reduce the transmission of toxoplasmosis by keeping pet cats indoors
column2: and making them indoor cats.

column1: NOAA was also sad to report that RKC1
column2: a juvenile
column3: male monk seal also known as Sole
column4: was found dead in Laie on Oahu the afternoon of Jan. 26. In 2018
column5: Sole was rescued as a prematurely weaned pup on Molokai
column6: and successfully rehabilitated at The Marine Mammal Center’s Ke Kai Ola in Kona.

column1: He was released back into the wild near his birth site on Molokai
column2: and sighted on Oahu shortly afterwards
column3: but had only been seen a handful of times since them. The cause of his death is still being determined through a postmorten examination.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Could a Hawaiian monk seal mom have given birth to twin pups at Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument this year?
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration researchers believe this is a possibility after observing Hawaiian monk seal mom
column2: GV18
column3: nursing two similarly sized pups at Lisianski Island.

column1: The researchers have been at Papahanaumokuakea since May
column2: where they spend five months at field camps
column3: measuring and tagging seal pups
column4: monitoring sea turtles and cleaning up marine debris
column5: along with other tasks.

column1: While monk seal moms occasionally adopt a second pup
column2: says NOAA
column3: this usually lasts for a short period of time. Either the mom or larger pup will drive the adopted pup away. In this case
column4: researchers have not found other seal mothers missing a pup.

column1: GV18
column2: a 14-year-old Hawaiian monk seal mom
column3: nursed both pups together and weaned them at a slightly smaller than normal size.

column1: The birth of twin monk seal pups is extremely rare
column2: according to NOAA.

column1: A previous review of nearly 5
column2: 000 monk seal births over a 26-year period between 1983 and 2008 revealed only seven sets of twin pups. Thus

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The “stay-at-home” orders in place due to the coronavirus pandemic have benefited some non-human species – specifically

column1: Monk seal researchers from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said this year is off to a good start for Hawaiian monk seal pups in the main Hawaiian islands.

column4: ” said David Schofield

column6: moving through and swimming and surfing then we perceive there will be less interaction between the public and marine wildlife.”

column3: three on Molokai

column1: Generally
column2: moms rear their pups for five to seven weeks
column3: nursing them until they grow from about 30 pounds to nearly 200 pounds from fatty milk. During this time

column5: and abruptly weans the pup in order to return to sea and forage.

column1: Although there are fewer people on the beach

column4: then the viewer is far enough – approximately 50 feet — away.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Within 24 hours of Gov. David Ige announcing the state’s shelter-in-place order
column2: the Hawaii Humane Society had a 250-person waiting list for cat fosters hoping to cope with loneliness
column3: anxiety and boredom from the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Cat fosters are up 65% compared to this time last year
column2: said Daniel Roselle
column3: director of community relations for the Hawaii Humane Society.

column1: While a pet cat can ease stress in humans
column2: the animal can take a huge toll on Hawaii’s environment. The latest episode of our podcast “Are We Doomed? And Other Burning Environmental Questions
column3: ” has tips on how to protect Hawaii’s environment from cats
column4: even if you don’t own one.

column1: Claire Caulfield/Civil Beat
The Hawaii Humane Society is expecting a boom in the feral cat population post-pandemic. During the 2008 financial crisis
column2: pet abandonment was common and Roselle said shelters in the state have already seen people surrendering their pets.

column1: “We’re preparing for a lot of people coming to our pet food banks because on a reduced or cut income they won’t be able to feed their pets
column2: ” said Roselle
column3: who noted that the Humane Society gave away over 6
column4: 000 pounds of pet food in April.

column1: Roselle said donating food or money to a local shelter or pet food bank can help someone keep their cat
column2: and protect native animals from hungry cats.

column1: The growing feral cat populations in Hawaii are a bigger issue
column2: Roselle said. Most of the Humane Society’s spay and neuter efforts are paused to insure veterinarians can practice social distancing.

column1: “That is probably the most challenging thing for us to accept
column2: ” he said. “We know it’ll have an impact later.”

column1: Cats are an invasive species
column2: and pose unique risks to native birds and reptiles in Hawaii that evolved without feline predators. Cats have contributed to the extinction of at least 33 native island species and are the main threat to dozens of endangered birds
column3: mammals and reptiles.

column1: And cats are indirectly killing species that don’t even live on land
column2: like the endangered Hawaiian monk seal.

column1: Anthony Quintano/Civil Beat
There are only about 1
column2: 400 monk seals in the world
column3: and a parasite from cat poop is the leading cause of death for seals who call the main Hawaiian islands home
column4: Cara Field
column5: medical director for the Marine Mammal Center
column6: said.

column1: “Other marine mammals definitely can catch it
column2: ” Field said. “Some whales
column3: dolphins mostly … so this is not just a problem for monk seals.”

column1: A parasite called toxoplasma gondii is found in a lot of cats. Unlike other mammals
column2: cats are rarely sickened by the parasite
column3: but the cat’s digestive tract does provide the perfect environment for the parasite to reproduce.

column1: “At this point
column2: there’s no other animal that we know that can spread it
column3: ” Field said.

column1: If a cat is pooping outdoors
column2: thousands of these parasites can make their way into streams
column3: rivers and the ocean — infecting any mammals along the way.

column1: And it’s not just feral cats causing problems. Pet cats that are allowed to roam outdoors also spread toxoplasma gondii and kill endangered wildlife.
A recent study found free-roaming pet cats can impact local ecosystems four to ten times more than a natural predator. Because domesticated cats often stick close to home
column2: their territory is much smaller than a wild predator and therefore the cat has an outsized impact.

column1: Claire Caulfield/Civil Beat
“This is not about blaming cats because I love my cats
column2: ” Field said. She built her pets an enclosed patio
column3: or “cat-io
column4: ” so they could enjoy the fresh air without hurting the environment.

column1: “Building yourself a cat-io would actually be a good project if you’re bored at home
column2: ” she said.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Two Hawaiian monk seals are back home on Laysan Island at Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument after more than six months of growth and rehabilitation at an animal hospital in Kailua-Kona.
Maiapilo
column2: a female
column3: and ‘Akulikuli
column4: a male
column5: are both doing well back at Papahanaumokuakea
column6: where they were first discovered as prematurely weaned pups.

column1: Both seals were fitted with new satellite tags to help researchers monitor them post-release. Maiapilo has been traveling around the atoll
column2: while ‘Akulikuli has stayed near shore.

column1: Kai Kai Ola
column2: The Marine Mammal Center’s monk seal hospital in Kailua-Kona
column3: works with National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration researchers to find malnourished pups and rehabilitate them before returning them to the wild.

column1: “Both Maiapilo and ‘Akulikuli were prematurely weaned pups that would have died without intervention

column2: RH38

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Thanks to a conscientious fisherman
column2: a Hawaiian monk seal no longer has a hook
column3: line and sinker in his stomach
column4: and is doing well back in the wild.

column1: Officials from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration were able to locate RW02
column2: an 11-year-old
column3: male monk seal
column4: and remove the contents from his stomach using endoscope technology.

column1: NOAA released RW02
column2: also known by the nickname of “Kauai Kolohe
column3: ” back into the ocean at Mokuleia on Oahu’s North Shore over the weekend.

column1: “We’re really excited today to tell you the happy ending of a monk seal story that could have gone really bad
column2: but it went really well
column3: ” said David Schofield
column4: NOAA’s stranding coordinator. “This poor monk seal really did swallow a fish hook
column5: fishing line and a sinker
column6: but with the quick action of the community and the experts at the NOAA Fisheries Service
column7: we were able to remove that material and release the seal back to the wild.”

column1: The fisherman
column2: who preferred to remain anonymous
column3: reported the hooking on June 23
column4: and NOAA is thanking him for it because as a result
column5: the team was able to take swift action and help RW02 within the next two weeks.

column1: “We really applaud the fishermen and fishing community who wants to work with NOAA on helping to protect the wildlife
column2: the sea turtles
column3: the whales
column4: dolphins and seals
column5: ” said Schofield.

column1: He emphasized that fisherman and other members of the public should call any time a seal is hooked or sighted with fishing line coming out of its mouth.
“We want people to call
column2: ” said Schofield. “We’re going to get out there and help the seal and there’s no reason not to call us. We want to partner with the fishing community on these types of things. And we understand that accidents happen.”

column1: Dr. Michelle Barbieri
column2: NOAA’s veterinarian
column3: said an endoscope — a flexible
column4: fiber-optic tube with a camera attached at the end — is typically used to plan a surgery
column5: which is much more invasive and requires more recovery time. Fortunately
column6: the team was able to use the endoscope and snare to remove the hook. As a result
column7: the team was able to release RW02 the next day.

column1: NOAA first discovered RW02 as a very young seal on Kauai in 2008
column2: and is familiar with him
column3: having attached a satellite tag to track him previously. In 2013
column4: he began hanging out mostly on Oahu.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Two years ago
column2: Jerry Schubel
column3: president and CEO of the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach
column4: California
column5: told me
column6: “If you want your kids to care about the ocean
column7: get them to care about the things that live in the ocean.” He invited my four children (ages twelve
column10: and one at the time) to the aquarium for a day of petting sharks
column11: feeding sea otters and manta rays
column12: enjoying the company of a precocious two-year-old Magellanic penguin
column13: and shadowing staff as they identified and logged aquatic life sightings aboard Harbor Breeze Cruises.

column1: On that cruise
column2: we fell in love with a family of five fin whales swimming in the ocean. We could hear each whale breathe
column3: and some of us got sprayed in the face by water from their blowholes. Today we still think about their well-being and what we can do to prevent threats to the second-largest species of whales.

column1: Now
column2: with shelter-in-place orders in effect
column3: I wondered how aquariums and ocean-conservation programs would continue sharing these kinds of experiences remotely. Fortunately
column4: the Aquarium of the Pacific and a number of other organizations throughout the country are offering families a variety of engaging activities online.

column1: Aquariums
The Aquarium of the Pacific’s Online Academy includes programs with its educators
column2: live webcams
column3: YouTube videos
column4: a guest-speaker series
column5: and a daily show. “The interaction between us and the audience is key
column6: ” says David Bader
column7: its director of education. “We are trying to use face-to-face teaching theories in a distance-learning platform. We are building connections and community among our viewers. We want people of all ages who are at home to engage with our exhibits and animals and learn about the ocean.”

column1: The aquarium’s free Pacific Visions EcoAlliance app challenges both adults and kids to sustainably consume food
column2: water
column3: and energy. Lola the cockatoo’s field trip around the aquarium is an especially popular post.

column1: Birch Aquarium is the public-outreach center for the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California at San Diego
column2: one of the largest research programs for ocean and earth science. Tune in to its Facebook events and watch behind-the-scenes videos of things like hatching weedy sea dragons or a giant kelp-forest tank that is pumped with sea water
column3: which facilitates the growth of algae.

column1: Each week the Georgia Aquarium premieres a new video in its Deep Sea Learning YouTube series. Check out its new at-home learning program
column2: which offers field guides and lesson plans for kindergarten through 12th grade. Its most popular posts feature puppies from the Atlanta Humane Society visiting the aquarium while it’s closed to the public.

column1: In Hawaii
column2: Waikiki Aquarium has set up new virtual experiences
column3: like how to draw marine animals with Hawaiian nature artist Patrick Ching and webcams of the Hawaiian monk seal named Hoailona
column4: the south shore of Waikiki
column5: and the aquarium’s galleries.

column1: “Engaging and inspiring the public about the wonders of our blue planet is central to our mission
column2: ” says Vikki N. Spruill
column3: president and CEO of the New England Aquarium. To continue those efforts during the pandemic
column4: her aquarium is hosting a new series of virtual visits
column5: daily live educational presentations on Facebook at 11 A.M. EST
column6: interviews with aquarists
column7: and at-home projects. The most popular video since its closure has been the African penguin feeding.

column1: Some unique opportunities have been made possible because aquariums are closed. From March 26 to April 14
column2: the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service granted Monterey Bay Aquarium in California a special exception to livestream what guests would normally not be allowed to see: resident sea otters taking care of stranded pups. Visit its Learning at Home page to find free self-paced online courses
column3: such as Tidepool Scientist for pre-K to second grade and Explore Like a Scientist for grades three through six. “Our education team helps students to think like a scientist while they learn about ocean animals and habitats and what they can contribute to conservation
column4: ” says Rita Bell
column5: its vice president of education.

column1: Nonprofits and Government Agencies
The Pacific Marine Mammal Center
column2: located in Laguna Beach
column3: California
column4: offers long-distance educational presentations that are normally only available to schools but are now open to everyone. Using the Seal Spotter app
column5: participants can take photos of tagged seals or sea lions in the wild so the center can see where the animals they once took care of are and how they’re faring.

column1: NOAA’s Office of National Marine Sanctuaries manages 14 national marine sanctuaries as well as the Papahanaumokuakea and Rose Atoll Marine National Monuments
column2: located in the North and South Pacific Oceans
column3: respectively. Start with Sanctuaries at Home for access to its interactive live webinar series
column4: which includes videos like “Bringing the Ocean to You
column5: ” early releases of its virtual-reality dives
column6: games
column7: a curriculum

column1: The Ocean Film Festival
column2: originally scheduled to run in March in San Francisco
column3: has released its films for free online. Movies like Alice in Borneo’s Wonderland
column4: about a 16-year-old learning to scuba-dive
column5: were added for middle school and high school students who were set to attend the festival. “Some of these kids have never been to the ocean. Our goal is to bring the ocean to our audiences
column6: since they can’t come to us
column7: ” says executive director Ann Blanco. “Our desire is to keep the conversation going
column8: so we can learn about the beauty of our ocean
column9: the amazing animals that live in the ocean
column10: and how we recreate with the ocean for our pleasure. The ocean brings us calm and reduces our stress
column11: so we’re trying to help during this critical time with the power of film.”

column1: Although virtual experiences provide similar benefits to reality
column2: we had such a fantastic once-in-a-lifetime experience with the whales that I wasn’t sure how virtual programs could compare. But after a week of introducing these resources to my family
column3: I noticed that my older kids would sometimes skip Fortnite meetups just to attend underwater livestreams. After working my way through the Aquarium of the Pacific’s lecture series Ocean to Table: Stories of Food
column4: Farming
column5: and Conservation
column6: I now serve my family only seafood from sustainable and responsible wild and farmed sources
column7: and I make smoothies with seaweed. And while watching the Monterey Bay Aquarium’s sea otter cam and listening to its social-media team answer questions about stranded pups one day
column8: my six-year-old giggled at the sight of Ivy
column10: pouncing on the back of a pup
column11: wrapping her arms around the pup’s waist
column12: and wrangling her down to a sleeping position. “Mom
column13: that’s what you do with us
column14: ” my daughter said. My three-year-old asked me to scratch her belly the way Ivy was calming down her pup. Then she pointed at the pup and said

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Federal wildlife officials have captured an adult female Hawaiian monk seal for monitoring after it was showing sick-like behavior in the Ko Olina area.
Seal RO28
column2: also known as Pohaku
column3: is being cared for by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Fisheries veterinary staff
column4: NOAA Fisheries said on its website. Pohaku was captured Wednesday after a volunteer saw her exhibiting a behavior called “logging
column5: ” in which a seal will lethargically float on the water and not swim.

column1: NOAA said “logging” can indicate a seal is injured or has underlying health problems.
Some seals
column2: including Pohaku
column3: can show this behavior for several hours even while appearing healthy. However
column4: after monitoring Pohaku
column5: NOAA staff decided to bring her in for further evaluation.

column1: NOAA will provide an update on her condition when test results come back.
Monk seals are a critically endangered species with about 1
column2: 400 in the wild
column3: living around the Northwestern and main Hawaiian Islands. The seals are endemic to Hawaii.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: NOAA reported earlier this month that a young monk seal that died in November may have drowned in a lay gillnet. RL36
column3: also known as Makoa
column4: was found dead on Oahu’s North Shore on Nov. 9.

column1: Tests showed Makoa had been healthy and had no underlying disease
column2: and photos taken before his death showed he appeared normal.

column1: With the available information and similarities with other monk seal drownings
column2: experts said the evidence points to drowning as the cause of Makoa’s death.

column1: However
column2: because of decomposition
column3: researchers could not completely rule out trauma.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Hawaiian monk seal RH38 is one very lucky pinniped.
The juvenile female seal that was rescued in a critically ill state in March
column2: was recently released back to the wild on Kauai
column3: according to Ke Kai Ola
column4: the monk seal hospital in Kailua-Kona run by the Marine Mammal Center. She was released in good health with a tracking tag attached to her back
column5: and appears to be doing well.

column1: It is her second time being rehabilitated and released from Ke Kai Ola in the past two years.
“For an endangered marine mammal like the Hawaiian monk seal
column2: the release of every individual is critical to help boost the overall population
column3: ” says Dr. Shawn Johnson
column4: the center’s Vice President of Veterinary Medicine and Science
column5: in a news release. “RH38’s recovery is an incredible success story that was full of medical complexities and highlights the importance of our ongoing partnerships to help save this species.”

column1: The first time RH38 was admitted to Ke Kai Ola in August 2017
column2: she was treated for malnutrition and a heavy parasite load.

column1: During this second round
column2: RH38 was treated for a slew of serious medical ailments including trauma
column3: pneumonia
column4: corneal damage and multiple organ infections due to sepsis.

column1: While providing her with care
column2: the center was trying to pinpoint the cause of her symptoms
column3: which included weakness
column4: broad-scale inflammation and malnutrition. So in April
column5: she became the first seal to undergo a CT scan at North Hawaii Community Hospital.

column1: The scan found that an infection in the seal’s back flippers
column2: believed to have been caused by some sort of trauma
column3: had spread to her bloodstream
column4: causing a wide range of other problems.

column1: RH38’s story highlights the seriousness of threats to this endangered species in the wild. Only an estimated 1
column2: 400 Hawaiian monk seals — a critically endangered species protected by state and federal laws – remain in the wild.

column1: The center partners with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to provide care for ill or malnourished monk seals
column2: and has rehabilitated and released 28 (which includes RH38 twice) since opening Ke Kai Ola in 2014. NOAA estimates about 30% of monk seals are alive today due to conservation efforts.

column1: Shortly following RH38’s release in late July
column2: Ke Kai Ola took in a seriously ill female pup from Kalaupapa
column3: Molokai
column4: with help from the U.S. Coast Guard.

column1: The weaned seal pup
column2: RL76
column3: was observed with severe head swelling
column4: and was displaying open mouth breathing behavior.

column1: Radiograph and ultrasound exams showed the pup was suffering from head trauma
column2: scratches and puncture wounds consistent with an interaction with another seal. Veterinary experts are watching her closely
column3: and will consider the next steps to take once her trauma and respiration improves.

column1: NOAA reminds the public to remain a safe distance from monk seals. Sightings of seals
