column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The mystery began about two years ago
column2: when Charles Littnan
column3: lead scientist of the monk-seal program
column4: got a strange email from researchers in the field. The subject line was short: ""Eel in nose.""

column1: A relaxed-looking juvenile Hawaiian monk seal lounges near a sandy white beach on some green foliage. Its eyes are half-closed and it has a serene expression on its face. But the seal’s calm demeanor is surprising.
Why? Well
column2: there’s a long
column3: black-and-white eel dangling from its right nostril.

column1: “It’s just so shocking
column2: ” Claire Simeone
column3: a veterinarian and monk-seal expert based in Hawaii
column4: told The Washington Post. “It’s an animal that has another animal stuck up its nose.”

column1: Simeone wasn’t the only person stunned by the photo of the seal and its unusual facial ornament that was shared last week on Facebook by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Hawaiian Monk Seal Research Program. The picture — taken this year in the remote northwestern Hawaiian islands
— went viral
column2: drawing attention to a rare phenomenon that continues to baffle scientists who wish the endangered seals would “make better choices.”

column1: It began about two years ago
column2: when Charles Littnan
column3: lead scientist of the monk-seal program
column4: woke up to a strange email from researchers in the field. The subject line was short: “Eel in nose.”

column1: “It was just like
column2: ‘We found a seal with an eel stuck in its nose
column3: do we have a protocol?'” Littnan said in a phone interview.

column1: There was none
column2: Littnan said
column3: and it took several emails and phone calls before the decision was made to grab the eel and try pulling it out.

column1: “There was only maybe two inches of the eel actually still sticking out of the nose
column2: so it was very much akin to the magician’s trick when they’re pulling out the handkerchiefs and they keep coming and coming and coming
column3: ” he said.

column1: After less than a minute of tugging
column2: a 2 1/2-foot dead eel emerged from the seal’s nostril.

column1: Since then
column2: Littnan said there have been at least three or four reported cases
column3: the most recent occurring this fall. In all the cases
column4: the eels were removed successfully and the seals are “doing great
column5: ” he said. None of the eels
column6: however
column7: survived.

column1: “We have no idea why this is suddenly happening
column2: ” Littnan said. “You see some very strange things if you watch nature long enough
column3: and this could end up being one of these little oddities and mysteries of our careers that 40 years from now
column4: we’ll be retired and still questioning quite how this happened.”

column1: Researchers have already determined this is not the result of a human with a personal vendetta against seals and eels because all the cases were reported from remote islands that are only frequented by scientists. Littnan said he does have a few theories about how an eel could naturally end up wedged in a seal’s nostril.
A seal’s preferred prey — usually fish
column2: octopuses and
column3: of course
column4: eels — like to hide within coral reefs to avoid being eaten
column5: and since the marine mammals don’t have hands
column6: they have to hunt with their faces.

column1: “They like to stick their faces into the coral reef holes and they’ll spit water out of their mouths to flush things out and they’ll do all sorts of tricks
column2: but they are shoving their faces into holes
column3: ” Littnan said.

column1: Perhaps
column2: he said
column3: a cornered eel decided that the only way to escape or defend itself was to swim up its attacker’s nostril and young seals that are “not very adept at getting their food yet” were forced to learn a tough lesson.

column1: But Littnan admitted that theory doesn’t make much sense.
“They’re really quite long eels
column2: and their diameter is probably close to what it would be for a nasal passage
column3: ” he said.

column1: He added that a monk seal’s nostrils
column2: which reflexively close when they are diving for food
column3: are very muscular and it would be difficult for any animal to push through.

column1: “I struggle to think of an eel really wanting to force its way into a nose
column2: ” he said.

column1: The other way eels might be ending up in nostrils is through throwing up. Similar to how people sometimes end up accidentally spewing food or beverages from their noses
column2: that could also happen to seals
column3: who often regurgitate their meals.

column1: Still
column2: Littnan said it doesn’t seem possible that a “long
column3: fat eel” would end up going through a seal’s nose rather than out of its mouth. The “most plausible” theory
column4: he said
column5: is that monk seal teenagers aren’t all that different from their human counterparts. Monk seals “seem naturally attracted to getting into troublesome situations
column6: ” Littnan said.

column1: “It almost does feel like one of those teenage trends that happen
column2: ” he said. “One juvenile seal did this very stupid thing and now the others are trying to mimic it.”

column1: Though no seals have died or been seriously affected by the eels
column2: having a dead animal up their noses for any extended time poses potentially adverse health impacts
column3: said Simeone
column4: director of Ke Kai Ola
column5: a monk-seal hospital in Hawaii run by the Marine Mammal Center.

column1: With an eel lodged in its nose
column2: a monk seal would not be able to close the blocked nostril when diving
column3: which means water could get into its lungs and cause problems
column4: such as pneumonia
column5: Simeone said. A decomposing eel carcass could also lead to infections
column6: she said.

column1: Littnan said the young seal “seemed apparently fairly oblivious to the fact that there was two feet of eel sticking out of its face.”
In general
column2: Simeone said marine animals are “very stoic
column3: ” adding
column4: “It’s amazing the kinds of things they can tolerate.”

column1: While “eel snorting” has yet to catch on in the seal community
column2: Littnan said he hopes it never does.

column1: “We’re hoping it’s just one of these flukes that will disappear and never be seen again
column2: ” he said.

column1: If monk seals could understand humans
column2: Littnan said he has a message for them: “I would gently plead for them to stop.”";"Endangered Hawaiian monk seals keep getting eels stuck up their noses; scientists want them to stop";https://news.google.com/articles/CBMipQFodHRwczovL3d3dy5zZWF0dGxldGltZXMuY29tL25hdGlvbi13b3JsZC9tYWtlLWJldHRlci1jaG9pY2VzLWVuZGFuZ2VyZWQtaGF3YWlpYW4tbW9uay1zZWFscy1rZWVwLWdldHRpbmctZWVscy1zdHVjay11cC10aGVpci1ub3Nlcy1hbmQtc2NpZW50aXN0cy13YW50LXRoZW0tdG8tc3RvcC_SAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://static.seattletimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/12102018_teaser_tzr_085643-780x501.jpg;12/07/2018;[{'sent': 'The mystery began about two years ago

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Another Hawaiian monk seal accidentally hooked by a fisherman has been rescued
column2: treated and released
column3: according to federal wildlife officials.

column1: Hawaiian monk seal R333 is alive and well
column2: and already back in the ocean
column3: according to National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration officials
column4: thanks to a fisherman who did the right thing.

column1: “One of the heroes in this story is the fisherman who reported the seal hooking
column2: ” said David Schofield
column3: NOAA regional marine mammal response coordinator. “His timely reporting as well as telling us the gear types
column4: and what experience he had with the seal as far as reeling it in and cutting the line helped to inform the response and treatment to the seal. So it’s a very happy story in that regard.”

column2: an adult male
column3: was accidentally hooked on the morning of Saturday
column4: July 27
column5: at Kaena Point on Oahu’s North Shore.

column1: The fisherman called NOAA’s hotline right away
column2: according to Schofield
column3: and volunteers from Hawaii Marine Animal Response were able to locate the seal that same day. They found him with line coming out of his mouth.

column1: NOAA officials caught R333 the next day and brought him in to remove the hook. He was released on Aug. 1 and outfitted with a satellite tag.

NOAA officials have known of R333 since 2015 and said he usually hangs out on Niihau but occasionally frequents shorelines around Kauai and Oahu. His satellite tag shows he headed back to Niihau following his release.
Dr. Michelle Barbieri
column2: NOAA Fisheries veterinarian
column3: said a barbed
column4: circle hook was lodged deep in R333’s stomach.

column1: The monk seal
column2: weighing almost 400 pounts
column3: was given anesthesia. Barbieri then used an endoscope and dehooking instrument that had been extended 16 inches to reach the hook
column4: free it
column5: slip a cover over it
column6: and pull it out without snagging — avoiding a more invasive surgical procedure requiring a much longer recovery time.

column1: It was the second seal hooking in the past two months. In June
column2: Hawaiian monk seal RW02 swallowed a fishing hook
column3: line and sinker.

column1: A conscientious fisherman also reported that hooking to NOAA
column2: and officials were able to track the male monk seal down on Oahu’s North Shore
column3: remove the hook from his stomach and release him within about two weeks.

column1: Schofield said fishermen by nature are conservationists
column2: and he found in both cases they were motivated to help the seals by calling for help. Both want to remain anonymous.

column1: Typically there are anywhere from six to a dozen hookings a year in the main Hawaiian Islands
column2: Schofield said. Anyone who is fishing and spots a monk seal is encouraged to remove their lines until the seal has departed.

column1: Hawaiian monk seals are a critically endangered species protected by state and federal laws. Only an estimated 1
column2: 400 Hawaiian monk seals remain in the wild.

column1: To report a hooked seal
column2: call NOAA’s hotline at 888-256-9840.";NOAA dehooks another monk seal thanks to helpful fisherman;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMic2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnN0YXJhZHZlcnRpc2VyLmNvbS8yMDE5LzA4LzA3L2JyZWFraW5nLW5ld3Mvbm9hYS1kZWhvb2tzLWFub3RoZXItbW9uay1zZWFsLXRoYW5rcy10by1oZWxwZnVsLWZpc2hlcm1hbi_SAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://www.staradvertiser.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/web1_R333-is-free.jpg;08/08/2019;[{'sent': 'Hawaiian monk seal R333 is alive and well

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"It was a grey and drizzling day last September when scientists on the island of Niihau discovered an emaciated female Hawaiian monk seal pup still sporting its black lanugo coat.
She was
column2: they thought at first glance
column3: a newborn. But instead of trying to suckle her mother for milk
column4: the hungry seal
column5: named Kilo
column6: approached another youngster
column7: eager to find sustenance from her. There was none.

column1: The Marine Mammal Center of Sausalito
column2: California
column3: opened Ke Kai Ola on Hawaii Island in 2014 for just this reason—to rehabilitate monk seals like Kilo and return them to the wild.

column1: When Dr. Michelle Barbieri
column2: veterinarian with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Hawaiian Monk Seal Research Program
column3: first examined Kilo
column4: she discovered a healed umbilicus and teeth erupting through the pup’s gums. That put Kilo’s age older than the black newborn fuzz would normally indicate—more like 3 to 4 weeks old. “She was so skinny
column5: ” Barbieri said. “But she was also so fierce. She’d survived long enough for certain developmental things to be happening
column6: but she was not

column1: well-nourished enough for everything to be happening at the same time.”
Kilo
column2: in the foreground
column3: looks like a pup
column4: but she's only a few weeks younger than the other seal and clearly

column1: starving. Photo courtesy NOAA/Tracy Mercer
While it’s unclear what happened to Kilo’s mother
column2: there was a rotting monk seal carcass on the beach; but
column3: in general
column4: it’s young monk seals like Kilo that struggle to survive on their own to adulthood after being weaned at about six weeks of age. Scientists have found if a seal makes it to 2 years old
column5: it has a good chance for a long life
column6: contributing to the species’ survival. By that time
column7: the seal has figured out how to forage
column8: and it’s grown to a size where it can compete with other apex predators for food.

column1: At the same time Kilo was found
column2: another five underweight female pups and one yearling were picked up around the uninhabited islands northwest of Niihau
column3: where an estimated 85 percent of the endangered marine mammal’s population live. This remote area—known as Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument
column4: a protected conservation area—stretches some 1
column5: 300 miles beyond Honolulu.

column1: Adding seven new patients to its roster
column2: Ke Kai Ola has now treated 16 patients in less than two years. That’s 1 percent of the entire species
column3: and it’s part of an aggressive intervention plan that seems to be paying off for the endangered animal.

column1: After nearly 70 percent of the monk seal population died off during a 50-year period beginning in the 1950s
column2: its decline has slowed—from an annual drop of 8 percent in the 1980s to 2.8 percent in the past decade. Dr. Charles Littnan
column3: lead scientist with the Hawaiian Monk Seal Research Program
column4: reports that 30 percent of the 1
column5: 200 monk seals alive today are a result of his team’s efforts to remove hooks from seals caught on fishing lines
column6: free seals entangled in marine debris
column7: move young seals to areas of higher survival and
column8: now with the help of Ke Kai Ola
column9: rehabilitate individual seals abandoned or weaned at a weight that decades of data indicate will result in the animal’s eventual demise.

column1: But Kilo was not just underweight. She was emaciated. “We tube-fed her five times a day
column2: ” Deb Wickham
column3: operations manager at the facility
column4: also known as the “monk seal hospital
column5: ” said. Kilo arrived weighing 17 kilograms
column6: or 37 pounds. “Six days later
column7: she’d lost two kilos
column8: and that’s when I really got worried. It was another four days before she gained it back.”

column1: Wickham has worked with elephant seals
column2: harbor seals
column3: and California sea lions at The Marine Mammal Center for 24 years. She knows pinnipeds. “But it took a while to get this seal moving forward.”

column1: Eventually Kilo did move forward
column2: her black coat replaced by a grey and creamy combination
column3: and it was time to get her to eat whole fish.

column1: Kilo is one of the 16 Hawaiian monk seals Ke Kai Ola has treated in less than two years.
Photo courtesy NOAA/ Julie Steelman
The facility is designed to limit human interaction so seals retain their wild ways. Thus
column2: a video-camera system allows Wickham and her volunteers to monitor her patients from another room. To simulate foraging in a natural environment
column3: fish are hidden in a box weighted down with rocks on the bottom of the pool that seals have to flip over to find their meal.

column1: Kilo wasn’t one of Wickham’s easiest patients. When she was first given live fish
column2: she’d chase it
column3: catch it
column4: chew it up and toss the bits around her pool
column5: but she wouldn’t eat it. Eventually
column6: to Wickham’s and Barbieri’s relief
column7: Kilo caught on and
column8: by the time she left Ke Kai Ola seven months later

column1: The plan was to release Kilo at her natal site
column2: the beach on Niihau where she was born. But
column3: seven months after Kilo was rescued
column4: when the Hawaiian Monk Seal Research Program arrived to find six-foot seas and 25-knot winds
column5: the result was something like the agitation cycle on your washing machine
column6: and it was deemed unsafe to launch small-boat operations from the NOAA research ship Hi‘ialakai for transporting Kilo to shore. Forecasts for subsequent days indicated conditions would deteriorate more. Because there were six other monk seals on board the ship and a team of monk seal researchers to be dropped off at islands throughout Papahānaumokuākea for their summer field season
column7: the ship motored on.

column1: Five days later
column2: the Hi‘ialakai arrived at Laysan
column3: a northwestern Hawaiian island
column4: about 900 miles northwest of Honolulu. There were sunny skies
column5: warm breezes and
column6: most important
column7: calm seas. A shore pen was erected for Kilo
column8: a place for her to acclimatize to her new life for a few days before being given freedom to explore the wide expanse of the Pacific Ocean.

column1: “Once we put her in the pen
column2: she bolted out onto the soft white sand
column3: then rolled on her back
column4: her favorite body orientation
column5: and proceeded to completely cover herself with sand
column6: ” Barbieri said.

column1: Now
column2: Kilo faces the same challenges as any seal in the wild. Barbieri expects her to lose a little weight at first but stabilize in the weeks and months ahead as she gets to know her new surroundings. Fortunately
column3: Laysan’s juvenile survival rates are some of the highest in the entire archipelago.

column1: “It’s hugely satisfying to release Kilo in her natural surroundings
column2: where her instincts can fully lead the way from now on
column3: ” Barbieri said
column4: leaving Kilo on the island with field researchers who observed Kilo for several days. “I walked away hearing her barking behind me
column5: her typical Kilo attitude
column6: like a bookend to the vocal attitude she had when I first met her.”

column1: A healhty Kilo returns to the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands. Photo courtesy NOAA/Michelle Barbieri
When the gate to the shore pen was opened four days later
column2: Kilo galumphed straight for the water
column3: chasing small fish in the shallows
column4: and rolling in the onshore break. Within a few minutes
column5: she’d found another cruising seal
column6: and the two headed north around the island and out of the researchers’ view.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"When we ponder the idea of the circle of life — the interconnectedness between all natural life on Earth

column3: 400 Hawaiian monk seals left in the world

column2: which is when scientists observed the first fatality directly linked to the parasite

column6: told Salon

In Hawaii
column2: feral cats run rampant. That’s because the Hawaiian islands have the perfect combination of conditions for feral cat breeding: pleasant weather
column3: lots of prey
column4: and no predators
column5: meaning their population keeps growing.

column1: Yet Hawaii’s status as a feline paradise could further endanger the monk seal species. Toxoplasmosis is the biggest threat to the large sea mammals
column2: followed by interactions with shorecasting gear
column3: unattended nets
column4: and human-inflicted trauma.

column1: Toxoplasmosis is specific to cat feces because cats are the only animals that can defecate Toxoplasma gondii eggs

column3: a professor of parasitology at the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of California
column4: Davis
column5: said this is not meant to “demonize cats
column6: ” but the parasite in its fatal form is specific to cats because of how the single-cell moves through their intestines.

column1: Advertisement:
“All mammals and all birds are thought to be possible toxoplasma carriers
column2: and can be infected by the parasite
column3: they have proven it in over 250 species
column4: ” Conrad told Salon. “The things about cats is that cats are the only animals in which the parasite multiplies sexually; it has a whole different stage of its life cycle
column5: the cell multiplies in the intestine.”

column1: Conrad said that researchers do not currently know why this process is specific to cats
column2: but are studying it.

column1: Advertisement:
Toxoplasmosa gondii frequently pops up in news stories about cat-human transmission
column2: as humans
column3: particularly cat owners
column4: can and often do become infected. The organism evolved to alternate between rodent and the cat guts
column5: mating in one and laying its eggs in the other; yet because rodents are naturally afraid of cats
column6: the organism supposedly alters the brain of the rodent in order to make it attracted to the scent of cat urine. Humans can be infected with toxoplasmosis
column7: though it is thought to be mostly benign and only dangerous for pregnant women. Some research has suggested infection can alter humans’ brains

column1: As NOAA explained
column2: while seals’ toxoplasmosis infections might seem like a natural occurrence — and a natural death for the monk seals — the threat is sustained by human cat owners.

column1: “While disease may seem like a ‘natural’ cause of mortality
column2: toxoplasmosis is perpetuated by free-roaming cats
column3: and thus linked to human alteration of the environment
column4: ” NOAA states on its website.

column1: Advertisement:
Cats usually only get infected by the parasite when they eat raw meat
column2: which is why Conrad recommends that people keep their cats indoors. Kitty litter is fine to use

column1: “When cats are kept indoors
column2: they are not going to be to killing mice
column3: rats and birds
column4: so their chances of even getting infected are extremely low
column5: ” Conrad said. ""And the reality is
column6: unlike dogs where we make people pick up the feces
column7: cats can poop anywhere
column8: they discreetly find a spot and cover it up with dirt
column10: cat feces can get washed into fresh water ways or directly into the ocean.

column1: The threat is not specific to Hawaiian monk seals. In California
column2: cat feces–borne toxoplasmosis threatens the Southern Sea Otter Population. The sea otters were so rare that they were believed to be extinct in the late 1930s

column1: Advertisement:

The parasite has also been found in the tissue of beluga whales. The journal Diseases of Aquatic Organisms published a study that found 15 of 34 whales tested positive for the parasite. While that didn’t mean they died from it

column1: Conrad emphasized that not every animal that has it
column2: like humans or whales

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Pohaku
column2: a female Hawaiian monk seal suffering from toxoplasmosis
column3: remains in stable
column4: but guarded condition a week after she was moved from Oahu to Kona.

column1: The U.S. Coast Guard last week transported Pohaku aboard an HC-130 Hercules airplane to Ke Kai Ola
column2: a Hawaiian monk seal hospital run by The Marine Mammal Center in Kailua-Kona.

column1: Pohaku
column2: or RO28
column3: was first taken in Jan. 22 by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration officials for intensive care at Ford Island after a volunteer saw her floating lethargically off Ko Olina a few days earlier and called to report it.

column1: She was diagnosed with toxoplasmosis
column2: a parasitic disease spread primarily through cat feces
column3: and considered one of the three largest threats to the endangered seals. Her condition slowly improved
column4: and she was transferred to Ke Kai Ola for long-term care.

column1: “Toxoplasmosis is a complex disease that requires daily management for an affected Hawaiian monk seal
column2: ” said Megan McGinnis
column3: animal care program manager at Ke Kai Ola. “Pohaku’s prognosis remains guarded but our team is dedicated to providing the best quality care for this endangered patient.”

column3: juvenile monk seal named Sole

column1: She has so far survived longer than any other monk seal diagnosed with the disease

column2: including to and from the remote Northwestern Hawaiian Islands. On average
column3: the Coast Guard transports six marine mammals per year in conjunction with training.

column1: Pohaku joins four other monk seals from the Northwestern Hawaiian islands that are already at Ke Kai Ola
column2: but will remain in a separate pen due to her weak and lethargic state.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"An Alabama man was fined $1

column3: and then posting the videos to Instagram

column1: The Alabama resident
column2: who was vacationing on Kauai last year
column3: agreed to pay the fine
column4: NOAA said.

column1: NOAA’s Office of Law Enforcement in Hawaii used the man’s social media accounts to track down his home address
column2: then issued the penalty in an effort to educate him about the federal laws protecting marine wildlife.

column1: Hawaiian monk seals — with a population of about 1
column2: 400 remaining in the wild — are a critically endangered species protected by both state and federal laws
column3: including the Marine Mammal Protection Act. All species of sea turtles in U.S. waters are listed as either threatened or endangered under the Endangered Species Act (ESA)
column4: according to NOAA.

column1: In recent years
column2: NOAA Fisheries in the Pacific Islands has been monitoring social media for potential violations of both acts.

column1: In the video posted on Instagram with #monkseals
column2: the Alabama man walks up to a sleeping monk seal on Poipu Beach at night
column3: and strokes it with his hand. The startled seal quickly turns toward him
column4: and he runs away.

column1: As further evidence that he knew what he was doing was wrong
column2: he panned his camera to a sign from NOAA urging beachgoers to maintain a safe distance from wildlife.

column1: Adam Kurtz
column2: NOAA Fisheries wildlife management coordinator
column3: said most visitors who make these violations have no ill will toward the animals or any intention to harm them.

column1: “Violations are usually the result of things like tourists wanting to get a good
column2: close picture with a seal or a thrill-seeker trying to get a rush
column3: ” said Kurtz in a statement. “But it’s really frustrating when you see people harass these animals.”

column1: Also
column2: the man could have been injured
column3: he said
column4: because Hawaiian monk seals are wild animals that can act unpredictably. The seal could have lunged at the man instead of simply turning toward him.

column1: While investigating the man’s Instagram account
column2: NOAA’s officer also found a video of him aggressively pursuing a sea turtle while snorkeling at Poipu.

column1: NOAA’s guidelines for responsible marine wildlife viewing recommends a distance of 10 feet for sea turtles

column8: seals and dolphins in the U.S.

column3: which also includes the pink-headed duck and the Himalayan quail which are considered extinct for all practical purposes.

column3: says that there have been no confirmed sightings of these two species in the past few decades. “But since they were supposed to live in isolated areas

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"SCIENTISTS are celebrating after an animal that hasn’t been seen in over 30 years was photographed in the wild.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;""" "" Entomologist and bee expert Eli Wyman with the first rediscovered individual of Wallace’s giant bee (Megachile pluto) in the Indonesian islands of the North Moluccas. Clay Bolt
Advertisement
Around 285 million years ago
column2: if you had been walking through a Permian floodplain
column3: you might have seen a griffinfly — a dragonfly-like insect the size of a crow. It was huge
column4: partly because atmospheric oxgen during this time was something like 31-35 percent (it's around 21 percent today)
column5: and it turns out oxygen is the limiting factor in how big a bug can get.

column1: Although we no longer have dragonflies flying around with 2-foot (0.6-meter) wingspans
column2: there are some standouts among modern insects. Take Wallace's giant bee (Megachile pluto)
column3: the world's largest bee
column4: which can grow up to the size of an adult human's thumb — five times the size of the European honeybees you're used to seeing — with large mandibles used for scraping up tree resin to line their nests. It was recently thought to have gone the way of the griffinfly — nobody had seen Wallace's giant bee since 1981
column5: and before that
column6: no scientist had clapped eyes on it since its discovery in 1858 by Alfred Russel Wallace
column7: the English biologist who independently conceived of the theory of evolution through natural selection at the same time as Charles Darwin. Of course
column8: researchers knew this didn't mean it was extinct — it's just very difficult to prove an organism exists if you can't find it alive.

column1: But in January 2019
column2: a team of researchers traveled to a collection of little islands in Indonesia called the North Moluccas
column3: and they found the bee behemoth nesting in a termite nest on a tree trunk.

column1: To actually see how beautiful and big the species is in life
column2: to hear the sound of its giant wings thrumming as it flew past my head
column3: was just incredible
column4: said Clay Bolt
column5: a natural history photographer who captured the first photos and video of a live giant bee
column6: in a press release.

column1: Over the years
column2: a few research expeditions have set out to find Wallace's giant bee
column3: but they came up empty-handed until now. In the meantime
column4: however
column5: specimens would show up for sale — a specimen showed up on eBay in 2018 that auctioned for $9
column6: 100. In case you were wondering
column7: that's more than what the corpse of an insect usually goes for.

column1: The exact island on which the bee was found is a secret because
column2: as you can imagine from the price tag
column3: if the researchers published that information
column4: the remaining Wallace's giant bees might not be long for this world.

column1: Since the bee has only been viewed a few times in the wild
column2: not much is known about its habits and life history
column3: other than that it seems to like to live in termite nests in lowland forest. Indonesia lost 15 percent of its tree cover between between 2001 and 2017 to make way for agricultural fields
column4: so our rekindled romance with Wallace's giant bee might not last long if conservation efforts aren't put in place soon.

column1: But in the meantime
column2: it's nice to know Megachile pluto is still buzzing through the forest like a tiny helicopter. The giant griffinflies of the Permian would have wanted it that way.";Wallace's Giant Bee
column3: World's Largest

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"With years of selective breeding
column2: South African scientists have revived an extinct sub-species of zebra
column3: known as the quagga. (Photo : The Quagga Project )

column1: Scientists recently revived a South African sub-species of zebra known as the quagga. This odd-looking zebra lacking stripes on its hind legs has been extinct for more than 100 years.
The last known quagga died in a zoo in Amsterdam in 1883. Inspired to resurrect the species
column2: Reinhold Rau from the University of Cape Town founded The Quagga Project in 1987.

column1: When analyzing DNA from original quagga skin
column2: researchers found the extinct creature was genetically the same as the zebra. This means that the only true difference between the quagga and modern plains zebra (Equus Quagga) is their superficial markings.

column1: In addition to the lack of black and white stripes on its hindquarters
column2: the quaggas' coat turns to a darker brown color towards the back part of its body.

column1: So Rau and his team looked for plains zebra that fit the profile -- less vivid black and white stripes on their hindquarters. Then
column2: they selectively bred zebras to bring forth more and more quagga-like qualities.

column1: It's an attempt to try and repair ecological damage that was done a long time ago in some sort of small way
column2: Eric Harley
column3: a retired professor of chemical pathology at the University of Cape Town
column4: said in a statement. ""It is also to try and get a representation back of a charismatic animal that used to live in South Africa.""

column1: After several years of rebreeding the species
column2: researchers claim that the quagga are back in action. It took five generations
column3: but the selectively bred animals boast all the same traits as the quaggas once did.

column1: To all intents and purposes they are the quagga back again. The project has been a complete success
column2: Harley added.

column1: Quaggas were hunted to near extinction in the 19th century. Therefore The Quagga Project was an attempt to right wrongs and return a native South African species to the world after it was wrongly killed.
In response to ethical concerns raised
column2: Harley said: ""We don't do genetic engineering
column3: we aren't cloning
column4: we aren't doing any particularly clever sort of embryo transfers-it is a very simple project of selective breeding.""

column1: To appease critics
column2: the team has decided to name the new animal Rau-quagga to set it apart from its predecessors. The hope is to keep the project running and to create a substantial herd of Rau-quagga to be released in their native homeland of South Africa.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"More than a century ago
column2: in the wetlands around Kolkata
column3: India
column4: there lived a shy type of duck with a bright pink head. It was named
column5: appropriately
column6: the pink-headed duck. The males of the species had rosy pink bills and pink plumage covering their heads and necks. Some of them had light
column7: blush-colored feathers; others were as bright as Pepto-Bismol. They were never particularly common
column8: but hunters spotted them and on occasion bagged them while hunting bigger game. One of the last times anyone saw a pink-headed duck in the wild
column9: it was in the mouth of a hunting dog
column10: who delivered its carcass to Charles M. Inglis
column12: outside the Indian city of Darbhanga in June 1935.

column1: Officially
column2: the pink-headed duck is listed as critically endangered. The last confirmed sighting in the wild was in 1949. Though there have been reports of pink-headed ducks here and there in the decades since
column3: many people now believe the birds are not just rare and shy
column4: but extinct.

column1: Richard Thorns is not among them. For years now
column2: he has been searching for the pink-headed duck
column3: and
column4: since 2009
column5: he has traveled six times to Myanmar
column6: where he believes a flock of about 50 birds might live. Thorns
column7: an enthusiastic
column8: 53-year-old Englishman whose look can range from scholarly nerd to rugged adventurer
column9: first learned about the pink-headed duck around 1997
column10: from a library book on vanishing birds. At the time
column11: he was working as a shop assistant. As he read about these stunning
column13: and the elephant grasses and lotus flowers that they lived among
column14: he had a realization. “I didn’t want to be a shop assistant anymore
column15: ” he says. “I decided to look for the pink-headed duck. So I did
column16: and I’ve been after it ever since.”

column1: Richard Thorns
column2: in search of the pink-headed duck. Courtesy of Richard Thorns

column1: From his journeys in Myanmar
column2: Thorns has developed a theory about exactly where the pink-headed duck could be hiding
column3: and this fall he plans to return for a seventh search
column4: as part of the Search for Lost Species. The campaign
column5: created by Austin-based nonprofit Global Wildlife Conservation
column6: will attempt to relocate a handful of more than 1
column7: 200 species considered “lost to science”—long unseen
column9: and feared extinct. A century ago
column10: pink-headed ducks could be found in Myanmar
column11: and Thorns believes that it’s very possible the ducks are living there still
column12: in parts of the country long closed to outsiders
column13: out of sight of birdwatchers and conservation organizations.

column1: To some
column2: there’s little point in a quixotic search for a lost duck. These birds supposed to be extinct
column3: after all. “The people who hope for the pink-headed duck are people prepared to think in a different way
column4: ” Thorns says. “It’s like a detective story. Have we just missed it? Or is it hidden where no one can go?”

column1: Thorns is not the first to go looking for the elusive waterfowl. In the 1980s
column2: Rory Nugent
column3: an American adventurer and writer
column4: heard about the duck from a friend. By two months later
column5: he had sold his apartment
column6: had put his belongings in storage
column7: and was on his way to India. Like Thorns
column8: Nugent believed he could find the duck in a part of the world troubled by violent conflict and usually off-limits. He waited for months for permission to travel the Brahmaputra River in Assam
column9: which he spent searching for the duck in the bird markets of Kolkata (then still called Calcutta)
column11: and on the border of India and Tibet. Finally
column13: an artist and photographer whom he met in New Delhi
column14: set out down the Brahmaputra and scoured the river for weeks. He never got a clear glimpse of his quarry
column15: but by the end of the journey Nugent insisted
column16: “We’ve seen it. We just didn’t notice it. … They’re not extinct
column17: just hard to find.” His book about the adventure ends with a reported sighting and the author heading back upriver.

column1: Part of the mystery surrounding the pink-headed duck is why it disappeared to begin with. Most species are driven to extinction by habitat loss
column2: hunting
column3: or predation by an invasive species
column4: but there’s no obvious cause for the pink-headed duck’s disappearance. Though its habitat has diminished and it was hunted
column5: other birds have survived the same circumstances. Since the pink-headed duck was always relatively rare
column6: it is possible to imagine the bird is still hiding somewhere out there. Nugent’s report
column7: another from Myanmar in 1968
column8: and other more recent sightings are not considered robust enough to count as evidence for the duck’s continued survival. But stories of pink-headed duck sightings keep popping up
column9: and some of the most recent come from the exact area of Myanmar where Thorns has been searching.

column1: Pink-headed ducks were once found in Southeast Asian wetlands like these. Courtesy of Richard Thorns

column2: a pink-headed duck
column3: now stuffed and held at the American Museum of Natural History in New York
column4: turned up at a bazaar in Mandalay
column5: one of the country’s largest cities. Since then
column6: unconfirmed reports of the ducks have come from the country’s northern districts. In the early 2000s
column7: two conservation groups—BirdLife International and Myanmar’s Biodiversity and Nature Conservation Association (BANCA)—began surveying rivers
column9: and wetlands in the region for pink-headed ducks.

column1: In December 2004
column2: the team was in the Nawng Kwin wetlands
column3: north of vast Indawgyi Lake
column4: when they met a young man named Saw Aung
column5: who said he was familiar with the duck. One morning
column6: the group went out into the grasslands
column7: and Saw Aung flushed a flock of ducks from a wetland pool. A few dozen mallards rose into the air
column8: and as three foreign birdwatchers peered through telescopes
column9: one duck “broke off from the flock
column12: and then descended into the grassland
column13: ” the team later wrote in a published report. The three men agreed: The bird
column15: had a pale head and neck

column1: In that part of the world
column2: though
column3: there is another bird with similar features
column4: the spot-billed duck. The men discussed the features that would distinguish one bird from another—in particular
column5: white feathers on the underside of the wing
column6: a characteristic of the spot-billed duck. Had they seen those feathers? One of the three observers thought he had. Though another thought it was “very likely” they had seen a pink-headed duck
column7: the other two weren’t so sure. They couldn’t rule out the possibility that they’d seen a variety of spot-billed duck. “On balance
column9: this record should be treated as a possible but unconfirmed sighting of Pink-headed Duck
column10: ” they wrote. The thrilling moment had passed too quickly for any semblance of certainty.

Before beginning his search
column2: Thorns was not a serious birder. “My brother is the person to talk to there
column3: ” he says. “He is a real hotshot birder.” But once he heard of the pink-headed duck
column4: he never forgot about the bird
column5: its beauty
column6: and the beauty of its habitat. “I inherited my grandfather’s instincts as an explorer
column7: ” he says. “I think a lot of it was … I wasn’t doing very much. I didn’t really feel fulfilled. The pink-headed duck is like some sort of mythical thing. It is so iconic and beautiful.” The idea of finding something missing for so many years gave him a mission.

column1: In his first visits to Myanmar
column2: Thorns tried to keep himself and his purpose as well concealed as the fowl he was searching for. Before 2011
column3: the country was still ruled by the military junta that had been in power since 1962
column4: and even today the government restricts the movements of foreign travelers in certain parts of the country. Myanmar is rich in jade
column5: gold
column6: and other treasures. Some of the most resource-rich areas are off-limits
column7: and in the north ethnic independence armies are still in conflict with government forces. But for pink-headed duck seekers
column8: those same areas are some of the most promising targets

column1: All that risk-taking had an impact. On his third trip

column1: That year Thorns spent part of his trip relaxing on the beach and in Mandalay’s public baths

column5: and never had much money. Financing the trips required single-minded purpose—between each he worked as much as possible to pay off debts from the previous one and save for the next. It’s been a very long time

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"A lost species of salamander has been rediscovered alive and well in Guatemala.
The Jackson's Climbing Salamander (Bolitoglossa jacksoni)
column2: a brilliant yellow-and-black amphibian
column3: was last seen in 1975 and feared extinct. But this month
column4: a guard at the Finca San Isidro Amphibian Reserve (also called the Yal Unin Yul Witz Reserve) in the Cuchumatanes Mountains spotted a juvenile of the species while out on patrol. The guard
column5: Ramos León
column6: snapped a photo and sent it to Carlos Vasquez
column7: a curator of herpetology at USAC University in Guatemala

column1: Vasquez himself had spent more than 3
column2: 000 hours hunting for the salamander since 2005
column3: and trained León and his fellow guards on how to search for it.

column1: We had started to fear that the species was gone
column2: and now it's like it has come back from extinction
column3: he said. ""It's a beautiful story and marks a promised future for the conservation of this special region."" [Golden Wonder: Photos of the Jackson's Climbing Salamander]

column1: Stunning rediscovery
The Jackson's Climbing Salamander is known as the ""golden wonder"" for its bright-yellow body
column2: which is topped by a black streak running from its head to most of the way down its tail. It's named after its discoverer
column3: Jeremy Jackson
column4: who first identified it while exploring the Cuchumatanes with his friend Paul Elias
column5: who was a college student at the time. They found three new species of salamander on that trip
column6: including the long-limbed salamander (Nyctanolis pernix) and the Finca Chiblac Salamander (Bradytriton silus). Those species were found again on expeditions in 2009 and 2010
column7: but the Jackson's salamander stayed missing.

column1: The nonprofit group Global Wildlife Conservation put the Jackson's salamander on its Top 25 ""most wanted species"" list as part of its Search for Lost Species initiative. The initiative
column2: which launched in April
column3: aims to seek out 25 species that have not been seen for years or decades but aren't confirmed extinct. Among them are the Wondiwoi tree kangaroo (Dendrolagus mayri)
column4: seen only once in 1928 in Indonesia
column5: and the pink-headed duck (Rhodonessa caryophyllacea)
column6: last seen in Myanmar in 1949.

column1: Finding lost species
It was shocking to find the Jackson's salamander so quickly
column2: said Lindsay Renick Mayer
column3: a spokesperson for Global Wildlife Conservation. The group had planned an expedition to the region to search for the salamander in January
column4: but León found the amphibian first.

column1: The night I got the news from Carlos that Bolitoglossa jacksoni had been rediscovered
column2: I flew off the couch where I'd been falling asleep
column3: let loose a string of expletives (in a good way)
column4: and did a little happy dance
column5: Jackson
column6: the salamander's original discoverer
column7: said in a statement. He went on to praise the reserve that has protected the unwitting salamander species throughout the years.

column1: I'm more than delighted that Yal Unin Yu Witz exists so that Jacksoni and other wonders can survive
column2: and I'm so pleased to hear that it was a guard protecting the preserve who found this beauty
column3: he said.

column1: I love this story because it conveys how protecting habitat gives species a fighting chance to survive on this planet
column2: Don Church
column3: the president of the Austin
column4: Texas-based Global Wildlife Conservation
column5: said in the statement. ""This rediscovery can only be a good omen for the future of the Search for Lost Species campaign. It's a sign that if we get out there and work at it
column6: many of these species can be found and saved.""

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"A duck with a pink head
column2: a tree-climbing crab
column3: and a monkey with red thighs are among the targets of a new global hunt for ""lost"" species.

column1: Global Wildlife Conservation (GWC)
column2: an organization based in Austin
column3: Texas
column4: with a focus on biodiversity and wildland preservation
column5: has launched a new initiative to search for 25 species that have not been seen for years or decades — or
column6: in the case of the Fernandina Galapagos tortoise
column7: more than a century. The goal is to see if any of the species still survive and

column1: While we're not sure how many of our target species we'll be able to find
column2: for many of these forgotten species
column3: this is likely their last chance to be saved from extinction
column4: GWC spokesperson Robin Moore said in a statement. [10 Extinct Giants That Once Roamed North America]

column1: Lost but not forgotten
A conservation organization is launching a global hunt for 25 ""lost"" species that could be saved. (Image credit: Global Wildlife Conservation/Alexis Rockman)
The group is focusing on species that have not been seen since at least 2007. Collaborating with the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)
column2: GWC actually came up with a list of 1
column3: 200 ""lost"" species but chose the charismatic creatures with decent chances of being saved
column4: if they can be found.

column1: On the list is the Syr-darya shovelnose sturgeon (Pseudoscaphirhynchus fedtschenkoi)
column2: a fish once found only in the Syr Darya river of Kazakhstan
column3: Tajikistan and Uzbekistan that has not been seen since the 1960s. Both the silvery Zug's monitor (Varanus zugorum) and the Wallace's giant bee (Megachile pluto)
column4: the latter of which is considered the world's largest bee
column5: have been missing from Indonesia since the early 1980s. Another lost denizen of Indonesia is the Wondiwoi tree kangaroo (Dendrolagus mayri)
column6: a teddy-bear-faced marsupial missing since 1928.

column1: Also on the most-wanted list are the Sierra Leone crab
column2: a freshwater
column3: tree-climbing crustacean not seen since 1955; the elusive Pondicherry shark (Carcharhinus hemiodon)
column4: not seen in its Indo-Pacific coastal habitat since the late 1970s; and the riotously colored Sinu parakeet
column5: missing from Colombia since 1949.

column1: Scientists will also be searching for the pink-headed duck (Rhodonessa caryophyllacea) — a brown diving duck with a distinctive pink head and neck. The species was last seen in 1949 in Myanmar. They'll also hunt in the Ivory Coast for Miss Waldron's red colobus (Piliocolobus waldronae)
column2: a monkey known for the scarlet fur on its thighs and forehead
column3: which has not been seen since 1978.

column1: Hope for the missing
Some species on the list threaten to slip out of living memory. The Fernandina Galapagos tortoise lived on Fernandina
column2: the least-disturbed island in the Galapagos archipelago. The first specimen was collected in 1906
column3: and the turtle hasn't been seen since.

column1: Missing doesn't mean extinct
column2: however. The Omilteme cottontail rabbit (Sylvilagus insonus) from Guerrero
column3: Mexico — one of the top 25 animals on the wanted list — disappeared from humanity's radar soon after its discovery in 1904. In 1998
column4: however
column5: researchers went looking and found two dead specimens. Now
column6: GWC hopes to find living examples of the shy rabbits.

column1: One species on the list has never been seen in the wild. Hippocampus minotaur
column2: the bullneck seahorse
column3: is known from four museum specimens collected between 1927 and 1981
column4: according to the IUCN. No one knows anything about its behavior in the wild
column5: its habitat or its population numbers.

column1: The Search for Lost Species project is currently in the fundraising phase
column2: with a goal of launching expeditions by the fall. More information can be found at lostspecies.org.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"TERA
column2: KUTCH
column3: India - One-metre tall and weighing up to 15kg
column4: it is the Robocop of big birds
column5: steadily stalking the vast grasslands
column6: its head swivelling rhythmically as it sweeps the surroundings and scans the ground.

column1: It seems to never break stride
column2: its long legs walking almost as fast as a man's. I saw one last week with a big scorpion; it had the formidable 13cm-long black insect clamped in its beak
column3: helplessly dangling by one of its pincers.

column1: The only problem is the grasslands
column2: its natural habitat
column3: are now not so vast. The Great Indian Bustard is in deep trouble
column4: and nearing the end of its days.

column1: Today its population
column2: in just three Indian states and a handful in Pakistan
column3: is estimated at about 200 to 300. Experts put the number lower
column4: at around 150.

column1: This makes the GIB
column2: as it is sometimes referred to
column3: one of the rarest birds in the world.

column1: Population estimates... suggest that the species has undergone a decline equivalent to around 82 per cent over 47 years
column2: says BirdLife International
column3: a non-profit group.

column1: A confluence of factors is against the big bird. And while people dither about what to do to save it
column2: the GIB is striding
column3: seemingly inexorably
column4: towards its own extinction - and in our lifetime.

column1: The Great Indian Bustard was once plentiful
column2: but hunting drove it to low numbers. After being protected from hunting since the 1970s
column3: it is newly beleaguered.

column1: For one thing
column2: it has a slow reproduction rate
column3: nesting on open ground
column4: laying only one egg
column5: and in rare cases two
column6: just once a year.

column1: For another
column2: the grasslands
column3: often classified as wasteland in government records and thus vulnerable to exploitation from mining
column4: industry and agriculture
column5: have shrunk dramatically.

column1: In the Kutch district of Gujarat state
column2: where I saw the bird with the scorpion
column3: farmers from as far away as Punjab are ploughing the grasslands to grow crops like cotton and castor. This destroys an entire ecosystem. Roads crisscross the habitat; giant wind turbines
column4: their blades slicing the air around them
column5: punctuate it. The low-flying bird has collided with high tension wires and died.

column1: Chicks have a hard time surviving not just natural predators but also packs of free-ranging stray dogs from nearby villages. And there remains occasional poaching. ""The Great Indian Bustard is the only bird species in India which has nine protected areas designated for its conservation
column2: writes scientist Dr Pramod Patil
column3: who has won a Whitley Award for his work for the species. ""Unfortunately
column4: we have lost the bustard from four of those. At all these places community resentment seems to be the major reason.""

column1: Wildlife scientists Sutirtha Dutta
column2: Asad R. Rahmani and Y.V. Jhala wrote in a 2010 paper: ""The declining rate of GIB populations calls for immediate commencement of ex situ conservation breeding programmes."" In other words
column3: breeding the birds in a captive facility.

column1: Five years on
column2: the federal government in New Delhi
column3: and the governments of the states of Maharashtra
column4: Gujarat and Rajasthan
column5: where the birds are found in the wild
column6: are still edging towards a captive breeding programme. But there remains no real agreement on what is to be done.

column1: Conservationists are divided over a breeding programme
column2: which would mean taking eggs from the wild and hatching them in a special facility.

column1: Studies say a captive breeding programme would need around eight to 10 eggs a year to be removed from the wild - for a gain that is at best uncertain and at worst could turn into a disaster for the species if the breeding fails. Some say with so few GIBs
column2: a failed programme would drive the bird faster into extinction. Focus on restoring and securing the GIB's natural habitat should be uppermost
column3: they argue.

column1: In a paper published in the journal Applied Ecology in June 2015 titled ""Ark or Park"" that specifically modelled captive breeding scenarios for the GIB
column2: scientists Paul M. Dolma
column3: Nigel J. Collar
column4: Keith M. Scotland and Robert. J. Burnside wrote: ""When species face extinction
column5: captive breeding may be appropriate.""

column1: But it added: ""However
column2: captive breeding may be unsuccessful
column3: while reducing motivation and resources for in situ conservation. For the great Indian bustard… rapid implementation of in situ conservation offers a better chance to avoid extinction.""

column1: The pro-breeding lobby argues that Saudi Arabia has had success breeding Houbara bustards
column2: and that Britain has a captive-bred great bustard programme that has released some birds into the wild. In a classic example involving the California condor
column3: the few remaining birds were taken from the wild in 1987and put into a captive breeding programme. At first controversial because of the risk
column4: the programme has been successful; there are roughly 150 birds in the wild now.

column1: On one thing the experts on both sides of the divide are agreed: It is imperative to preserve and better still restore some of the bird's habitat
column2: and ensure the support of local communities by still giving them their rights
column3: to grazing for instance.

column1: Saving the bird in the wild is the preferable option
column2: the experts agree. At the very worst
column3: cynics say
column4: that may ensure there is some habitat left for any the captive stocks to be introduced into.

column1: Most if not all grasslands (whatever is left) are open to people where overgrazing is a huge issue
column2: says Dr Asad Rahmani
column3: former principal and director of the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS) - who has been studying bustards for 30 years.

column1: We need many totally protected grasslands where GIBs can breed successfully; and after the breeding season is over these grasslands can be open for grazing by livestock of nearby villages.""
There are only two options for us - the GIB is extinct
column2: or is extinct in the wild
column3: he says. But a captive breeding programme could not afford to be a failure
column4: he added.

column1: Setting up a breeding programme from scratch is a complicated business
column2: requiring resources and specialised training. Much depends on the governments of the two main GIB states - Rajasthan and Gujarat. Both do want to save the Great Indian Bustard ; it is Rajasthan's state bird. But Rajasthan has said it will not allow any eggs to be taken for artificial incubation in Gujarat.

column1: Both states may end up going it alone if they cannot overcome their differences and mutual scepticism. That is not necessarily a bad thing. ""The rate of decline of grasslands
column2: and with them now GIBs
column3: is so fast now that we should encourage out-of-the-box thinking
column4: and try multiple approaches in different areas
column5: says Dr K.S. Gopi Sundar
column6: a scientist with the Cranes and Wetlands Programme of the Nature Conservation Foundation in Bangalore
column7: India.

column1: Thus to ensure there are birds - and habitat - left to save by the time any captive breeding gets started
column2: it is critical to protect the last of the GIB's habitat
column3: and do it now.

column1: Habitat conservation and restoration are very urgently needed
column2: underlines Dr Gopi Sundar. ""The classification of grasslands as 'wastelands' by the Indian government is fuelling conversion to agriculture and other uses. This must stop.""

column1: The state forest departments and conservationists are already taking measures to protect the Great Indian Bustards. In Kutch
column2: the department bans vehicle movement through the birds' habitat in the breeding months
column3: employs men on motorbikes to watch over the birds
column4: and has built fences to keep agricultural encroachment at bay from the little protected grassland that is left.

column1: But it is currently a holding battle spread across sporadic and in some cases only tenuously connected and shrinking islands of habitat.
The money is available for more to be done; it just needs the political will.
Gujarat
column2: for instance
column3: is building a statue which will be the tallest in the world at 182m
column4: of independence hero and native son Vallabhbhai Patel
column5: at a cost of over US$250 million (S$352.7 million). A small fraction of that kind of money could buy back the iconic GIB's habitat in Gujarat
column6: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's home state.

column1: Not saving the Great Indian Bustard will be a particularly dreadful failure.
It would be the first species in India since the pink-headed duck in the 1950s to pass into permanent oblivion.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Text Size: A- A+
New Delhi: In December 2013
column2: the United Nations declared 3 March — the day the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora was signed in 1973 — as World Wildlife Day. The aim was to celebrate and raise awareness about the world’s wild flora and fauna and promote conservation efforts.

column1: World Wildlife Day has now become the most important global annual event dedicated to wildlife. The theme for this year is the rather broadbased ‘Sustaining All Life on Earth’
column2: encompassing all wild animal and plant species as key components of the world’s biodiversity.

column1: What causes extinction?
Extinction of wildlife can be natural or due to human activity. However
column2: in today’s times
column3: the latter far outweighs the former. It is estimated that we are losing 200 to 2
column4: 000 species every year
column5: at the very least. Human activity could be indirect
column6: such as its contribution to climate change
column7: or direct
column8: such as poaching. When the tiger population in India fell from 100
column12: the main reason was poaching. In Australia
column14: 000 years ago when humans arrived on the continent.

column1: Prehuman events such as the Ice Age have also caused mass extinctions
column2: but contemporary threats to wildlife are often a combination of human activity and natural factors. Two such examples are the Amazon fires and the Australian bushfires
column3: which occurred last year. They were perhaps natural
column4: but accelerated to unprecedented levels because of human activity
column5: notably deforestation and climate change. It is estimated that 2.3 million animals died in the Amazon
column6: and more than a billion in Australia.

column1: Also read: Planting a trillion trees will not stop climate change
Where does India stand?
India
column2: home to four biodiversity hotspots and a variety of ecosystems and terrains
column3: including mountains
column4: rainforests
column5: coasts
column6: plains and deserts
column7: has about 7.6 per cent of the world’s mammals
column11: and 6 per cent of flowering plant species.

column1: According to reports
column2: four species of fauna and 18 species of flora have gone extinct in India in the past few centuries
column3: including the cheetah
column4: the Sumatran rhinoceros
column5: the Himalayan quail and the pink-headed duck. Protecting tigers
column6: leopards and pangolins (the last is reportedly the most trafficked animal in the world) is difficult
column7: given the huge demand for them from neighbouring China
column8: but this may change as Beijing is reportedly willing to crack down on wildlife trade following the coronavirus outbreak.

column1: India has seen a few conservation successes lately. The population of leopards
column2: tigers and lions fell sharply in the 20th century
column3: but is now seeing a recovery. India’s tiger population has doubled in the past 12 years. Experts give the credit to protection efforts by government and nongovernment organisations. The development of the tourism industry around wildlife has also helped the cause. Several former poachers now protect wildlife and have become safari guides.

column1: Like tigers
column2: India has seen success in many other species. The Gir forest in Gujarat is home to the only surviving population of Asiatic lions in the world. In the late 1960s
column3: there were only about 180 Asiatic lions. As of 2018
column4: there are more than 600. India must continue this effort to fulfil its responsibility and stay true to Article 51A (g) of the Constitution
column5: which says “it is the duty of every citizen of India to protect and improve the natural environment including forests
column6: lakes
column7: rivers
column8: and wildlife and to have compassion for living creatures”.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"After the Pink-headed Duck and the King Vulture
column2: the magnifient White-bellied Heron (WBH) in Assam is all set to go the Dodo way. The absence or disappearance of the White bellied Heron is a matter of grave concern for conservationists. The bird is on the edge of extinction or may have gone extinct in Assam since sighting of the bird becomes very rare. Ornithologists say
column3: there may be a few White bellied herons left in Manas National Park along the Bhutan border
column4: but not sure whether they are resident or flew in from the Bhutan side. A few years back
column5: photograph of this rare bird with a noose around its neck in a village in lower Assam sent shock waves among bird lovers of the state. There was also a news of a rare heron pair seen hanging from electric lines in the Bhutan side a couple of years back.

column1: Once a resident and also a locally migratory species in Assam
column2: shrinking of habitat brought the bird to the edge. These birds are often seen along the banks of Punatshangchu basin in central Bhutan and there are occasional sightings in the Assam-Bhutan border areas and in the Assam-Arunachal Pradesh border areas. There has been no report of nesting of this recluse bird in the Assam side for the last ten years.

column1: The survival of the White-bellied heron (Ardea Insignis)
column2: one of the 50 rarest birds in the world that has an estimated global population of less than 250
column3: greatly depends on the existence of their wetland habitat.

column1: Distribution and habitat:
The White-bellied Heron is Critically Endangered in the IUCN list
column2: with a population as low as 50–249 individuals. These birds exist in very low numbers over a large area comprising Bhutan
column3: Yunan in China
column4: northern Myanmar and northeast India. The species is found in the wetlands of tropical and subtropical forests in the foothills of the eastern Himalayas -- in India and Myanmar. It is spotted in Bhutan's sub-tropical areas and was also once found in Nepal. Traces of heron chicks were sighted in Zhemgang in Central Bhutan also. Herons mostly dwell in Southeast Asian countries and Bhutan shelters a little over 30 herons in the Himalayan region. Once eight nesting sites were identified amongst lofty flowing waters with pebbly substrates and Chir pine forests in Bhutan. A nesting site of this extremely rare White bellied Heron was also discovered in the Namdapha Tiger Reserve in Arunachal Pradesh. This is the first known nesting site of the WBH in India. Nest of the bird was found about 18 metres above ground on an East Indian almond (Terminalia myriocarpa) tree. In 2015
column5: ornithologists observed the courtship of a pair of white-bellied heron.The courtship begins in the winter from January to February as the river water recedes. The birds chase after each other playfully with sticks and calling out to partners. The pair went on to build a nest at the site. This is the first nesting site of the bird to be scientificly identified in Namdapha
column6: Arunachal Pradesh
column7: India. Before the discovery of this site
column8: Bhutan was (thought to be) the only country in the world to have a breeding population of the White-bellied Heron. Bhutan is home to about 10 per cent of the world’s total population of these birds.

column1: The black-necked crane is another rare bird that breeds on the Tibetan Plateau and winters mainly in the lower altitudes of Quinghai
column2: on the Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau
column3: north-eastern Bhutan and Zemithang and Sangty Valley in West Kameng district of Arunachal Pradesh. It is the only high altitude crane amongst the 15 species found in the world.

column1: Dr Anwaruddin Choudhury
column2: a renowned orinithologist and author said that Unlike the Black-necked stork
column3: that has a wider range from Bangladesh to Myanmar
column4: the White bellied Heron's range is constricted. While the number of Black-necked stork in Assam is highest (about a 100)
column5: the number of White bellied Heron is thought to be only about 50 in India that also includes a few in the Manas National Park in the Assam side of the Indo-Bhutan border. But the number and nesting of the bird in this side remains unpredictable.

column1: An “extremely shy” bird
column2: the White bellied Heron feeds on fish in clear fast flowing rivers and wetlands. The confluence of Noa-Dihing and Namdapha rivers in the Namdapha Tiger Reserve supports a few individuals of white-bellied heron by providing them with freshwater fish.

column1: Threats
Poaching is one of the main causes for the disappearance of the species. Since it is a big bird and easy to kill people hunt it for meat. Further
column2: development activities in hilly terrains in the Indo-Bhutan border constricted its habitat and nesting sites.

column1: Climate change is adding to the loss of habitat for many swampy birds. In a survey conducted by a local NGO Nature's Foster
column2: it was found that many Asian water fowls are now on the brink of danger due to degradation of wetlands. No existence could be found of more than 20 wetlands in western Assam in the survey either due to climate change impacts or conversion of these wetlands for other activities.

column1: The major factors for the decline in the population of the species include---loss
column2: modification
column3: fragmentation and degradation of habitat
column4: poaching and land use patterns
column5: particularly conversion of large areas for cultivation
column6: harvesting of wetland resources etc. Other significant threats in key protected areas e.g. Namdapha National Park in north-east India
column7: Bhutan and Myanmar are high levels of disturbance and developmental activities like sand mining

column1: The dams have already destroyed some nesting habitats of the species. The uppermost dam seen under construction in Bhutan will not have a large reservoir but reportedly may back up water into some of the areas considered prime White- bellied Heron habitat. With hydropower plant construction breaking ground in the last two decades
column2: the once-stable heron population started dropping in thir last bastion.

column1: Survey
The Centre for Conservation
column2: Education and Research-- a conservationist group based in Guwahati has been engaged in the survey of wetland birds since the last 10 years. In the survey
column3: no sighting was recorded of the WBH from its earlier known as habitats. There were reports of sighting of only two birds in Chirang and Baksa districts in the winter of 2011-12.The birds
column4: flew in from the Bhutan side. The bird that was sighted in Baksa district was captured and killed in a village bordering Bhutan. In an earlier instance
column5: a juvenile bird from Koilamoila in Manas Reserve Forest
column6: Assam
column7: near the foothills of Bhutan was rescued sometime in 2007. Reportedly one more heron was captured in Baksa near Assam-Bhutan border and the bird died in captivity before it was rescued.

column1: Attacks on the bird and their eggs by predators remains a major cause in the reduction of their numbers. Lack of scientific approach and poor awareness among the local communities has also brought doom to the beautiful bird.
Conclusion:
There has been no major initiative for protecting the habitat of a critically endangered species. Government of India
column2: had funded a three-year study on the species with a view to document the foraging behaviour of the bird
column3: but the study did not cover the cause of decline of the species properly.

column1: Develoment activities brought the White-bellied Heron to the verge of extinction. It was observed that the bird collect their food in the wetlands in day time and build their nest or take rests at night in trees in nearby forest. If one component is disturbed the bird moves to another secure place. For the survival of the species
column2: therefore
column3: both wetland and forest ecosystem are necessary. The thrust should therefore be more on the protection
column4: restoration and preservation of wetland areas and the forest canopies.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"An unusual species of waterfowl
column2: adorned with pink head feathers was last seen in the wild in India in 1949. Until recently
column3: however
column4: researchers were unsure how the extinct species - Rhodonessa caryophyllacea - got its vivid plumage.

column1: In the latest study
column2: Daniel Thomas of Massey University in New Zealand and Helen James of the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History used a taxidermied specimen from the Smithsonian's collection to unravel the mystery. They used a non-destructive technique known as Raman spectroscopy
column3: which allowed them to thoroughly investigate the bird's feathers without needing to pluck or otherwise damage them - this is rather important when examining an extinct or rare creature.

column1: Their analysis ultimately revealed the Pink-headed Duck used the same organic pigments - carotenoids - as flamingos and cardinals to produce their pink feathers. (Scroll to read more...)
Interestingly
column2: however
column3: carotenoids are rather rare among gamebirds. In fact

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Editor’s note: A previous version of this article said that the Great Indian Bustard was extinct
column2: rather than critically endangered
column3: and that the main cause of extinction of the other species was desertification. After clarifying with the Zoological Survey of India Director Kailash Chandra
column4: we have updated our piece to reflect the findings. VICE regrets the error.

column1: Although human actions are the ones primarily responsible for the effects of climate change
column2: the threat of extinction isn’t just coming for our kind. Researchers at the Conference of Parties to the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD COP 14) have said that if desertification—where fertile land degrades significantly as a result of deforestation and agricultural practices—and improper use of land continue
column3: critically endangered species could become extinct.

column1: While some animal species like the Asiatic Cheetah and the pink-headed duck have been extinct for decades
column2: mainly due to human activities like hunting
column3: habitat destruction and deforestation
column4: others that are on the verge of extinction now face the same threat.

column1: “Species like the Great Indian Bustard
column2: which only has about 150 of its population left
column3: are critically endangered
column4: and if land is not managed properly
column5: desertification could be one of the reasons they become extinct
column6: ” Kailash Chandra
column7: Director of the Zoological Survey of India

column1: At the conference
column2: Chandra mentioned that they had a database of more than 5.6 million specimens
column3: collected from all over India and also from the neighbouring countries before independence
column4: and said that
column5: “They give a lot of information about how things have changed in more than 100 years. If you see their distribution in geo-special platforms
column6: you'll realise how much changes have occurred because of the impact of deforestation and desertification.”

column1: Chandra pointed out that even the use of insecticides pesticides
column2: conversion of forest to agricultural land
column3: industries and chemicals
column4: and indiscriminate chopping of nature in the name of development (we’re looking at you
column5: Aarey authorities)
column6: are responsible for triggering this deadly desertification. This doesn’t mean development must come to a screeching halt
column7: but rather stresses the need to regulate such practices and minimise the damage done to the environment. He also said that such degradation doesn’t just threaten the survival of animals
column8: but also that of humans and other microscopic beings.

column1: The entire food chain is affected due to this
column2: says Chandra
column3: stressing that a lot of land in India continues to degrade
column4: with more than 30 percent of its land resources being affected by over-cultivation
column5: soil erosion and depletion of wetlands.

column1: What’s even more worrying is that India isn’t the only one having aridity issues. At the conference held in Greater Noida from September 2 to September 13
column2: more than 196 countries and 94 environment ministers got together to acknowledge this crucial issue and work towards conserving the environment
column3: especially in terms land management.

column1: In fact
column2: a recent UN report estimates that over a million plant and animal species are at risk
column3: especially iconic endangered ones because of reasons ranging from pollution to overfishing
column4: meaning that it’s all happening as a result of human activities. It also pointed out that ecosystems such as coral reefs and mangroves that protect the surrounding area from hurricanes
column5: and wetlands that absorb water to reduce flooding
column6: have declined dramatically
column7: which is why natural disasters are now being increasingly reported. Apparently it’s not too late to unfuck the planet but we have to act now by incentivising the protection of natural resources and shift our development focus to nature-based planning.

column1: At the conference last weekend
column2: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi delivered a speech promising cooperation in addressing climate change and land degradation
column3: while the other ministers present are expected to announce their targets for land restoration soon and unilaterally agree on ways to deal with threats like forced migration
column4: sand and dust storms
