column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"It was 1813
column2: when John James Audubon
column3: the renowned American bird painter who created ‘The Birds of America’ had this amazing experience while riding to Louisville
column4: Kentucky. Along the 55-mile journey all Audubon could see was a sky eclipsed with billions of birds. They were flying even after he reached his destination and continued flying for the next three days. “The light of noon-day was obscured as by an eclipse
column5: the dung fell in spots
column6: not unlike melting flakes of snow; and the continued buzz of the wings had a tendency to lull my senses to repose
column7: he later wrote.

column1: The bird that Audubon saw that day was the grey-blue winged passenger pigeon. It was one of the commonest birds in North America when Audubon wrote about it. But after a century of Audubon’s delightful encounter
column2: the entire species of passenger pigeon was wiped out from earth
column3: with the captive bird Martha
column4: the last passenger pigeon
column5: dying on 1 September 1914 in the Cincinnati Zoo. With her death Martha
column6: became the symbol of the threat of extinction of species in the West. From teeming billions in the 1800s
column7: with the largest documented nesting reported in Wisconsin in 1871
column8: estimated 136 million breeding birds in 850 square miles of forest
column9: the passenger pigeon became extinct. In 1860
column10: a report stated that the flight of passenger pigeons near Toronto filled the sky for 14 hours straight and held perhaps 3.5 billion birds.

column1: The last wild passenger pigeon was reported in 1900.
What seemed unimaginable
column2: the extinction of a species found in abundance
column3: happened due to widespread hunting and environmental destruction for development in North America in the second half of the 19th century. Martha symbolizes the ecological price North America paid for its development.

column1: Something similar to the passenger pigeons in North America
column2: in India
column3: two resident species — the Himalayan Mountain Quail and the Pink-headed Duck have not been sighted for many decades. The last sighting of the Himalayan Mountain Quail was reported in 1876 in Nainital
column4: Uttarakhand. As for the Pink-headed Duck
column5: once found in abundance in the Gangetic plains
column6: its last sighting was in 1949.

column1: As India surges forward to become a global superpower
column2: aspiring to be one with the West
column3: is it also on th path of ecological destruction like the latter? A recent study by Zoological Society of London (ZSL) and Yale University has identified 100 evolutionary distinct and globally endangered bird species from around the world. Of these 15 species occur in India whose habitats are under threat from unsustainable human activities. All the birds represent millions of years of unique evolutionary history. For example
column4: the Great Indian Bustard
column5: a bird once considered to be India’s National Bird
column6: is on the brink of extinction. No more than 200 Great Indian Bustards exist in the wild today and conservationist evaluate that by 2030 the species will become extinct.

column1: The question is how many more Marthas will be sacrificed at the altar of human development?

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"analysis
Updated: Feb 03

column2: the Supreme Court (SC) delivered a judgment on lions in India. The judgment directed that the wild lion population confined to Gir in Gujarat should be given a second habitat in Madhya Pradesh within six months. This was to ensure the population’s survival in the case of catastrophic events. The same judgment also said a separate proposal to “reintroduce” cheetahs to India should not go ahead as cheetahs from Africa
column3: available for the reintroduction
column4: were not the same as the Asiatic cheetah
column5: which became locally extinct in India after Independence. The 2013 judgment is considered a landmark because it laid out several progressive tenets
column6: including the “species-best-interest standard”—stressing that policy should implement what is best for a wild species rather than what was best for people.

column1: Seven years later
column2: the SC
column3: in a January order
column4: has said that cheetahs from Africa can be brought into India
column5: an active move to associate cheetahs with India once again. This is interesting on two counts. First
column6: the January judgment frames the introduction of the African cheetah as an “experimental basis in carefully chosen habitat”. This is new for conservation; an experiment which works towards de-extinction of a species gone for decades
column7: rather than gradually setting up tones for “natural progression”. Second
column8: the cheetah order comes in the shadow of the fact that the 2013 order on lions was never followed.

column1: The 2013 judgment hinged on the alien-ness of the African cheetah
column2: as the subspecies is different from the Asiatic one. The Asiatic cheetah is now found only in Iran
column3: which has too few cheetahs to send any to India. The new judgement stresses that bringing African cheetahs will not be a “reintroduction”
column4: but an introduction. This is a bringing forth rather than a bringing back; an act that seeks to address extinction through a next-best substitute. The cheetah is considered part of Indian culture; the word chitra standing for variegated patterns. It is also the first notably Indian animal that went extinct in recent memory (other animals that went extinct from India were the pink-headed duck and Sumatran rhino
column5: but they were not as well-known as cheetahs.) Thus
column6: the cheetah inhabits a cultural box which is outside of purely scientific conservation.

column1: The question now is: What should be the species best-interest standard for cheetahs? Any move to address extinction is complex
column2: and it becomes even more layered when it comes to large carnivores.

column1: The cheetah should not be brought to India if certain issues are not addressed. Equally
column2: bringing the cheetah to India can address problems typical to carnivore conservation and neglected habitat. The question of habitat is important as we have shown a historical skew towards protecting lush green forests. The cheetah is a creature of drier
column3: more neglected spaces — grasslands and thorn forest. Not looking particularly green nor with dense canopy cover
column4: both grasslands and thorn forest have been burnt
column5: cleared
column6: converted into industrial zones or decreed as wasted areas. Bringing the cheetah to India should have a minimum requirement of setting up a grassland policy. Sites in discussion for cheetah colonisation include Nauradehi sanctuary in Madhya Pradesh or the Shahgarh landscape near Jaisalmer; but we shouldn’t consider cheetah introduction as a tightly-managed “experiment” only in these sites.

column1: Instead
column2: a new grassland policy should address issues with grasslands sites specifically
column3: and thorn forest more broadly. Grasslands need grazing policies and protection against conversion; and thorn forests need protection from being mined or sold.

column1: Both grasslands and thorn forests are legitimate
column2: living ecosystems with iconic species such as the Great Indian Bustard
column3: caracal and the Indian wolf but the fact that these species are declining is because their habitat is not valued.

column1: Conserving cheetahs will also mean dealing with conflict with people outside and in protected areas. While the relatively small cheetah is unlikely to have negative encounters with people
column2: it may eat livestock. The model of co-existence with a carnivore constantly needs innovation and fine tuning. Studies show that where authorities are responsive in compensating kills or damage
column3: there is less conflict with carnivores. Creating effective and quick conflict-resolution models should benefit the Indian wolf which shares a similar habitat. We also need to strengthen responses to invasive threats like domestic dogs forming packs and attacking wildlife
column4: particularly outside protected areas.

column1: Some would say India should focus on the species it has; especially the ones that are in neglected areas like grasslands. Yet
column2: if we admit that conservation is also cultural
column3: bringing cheetahs to India — with a grassland policy and innovation in place — may be the shot of conservation optimism that grasslands and ‘degraded’ forests need. What we don’t need is patriotism through animals; but what we still do need are new ways of seeing places that don’t look impressive to us.

column1: Neha Sinha is with the Bombay Natural History Society

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"An artist's interpretation of Rusingoryx atopocranion on the Late Pleistocene plains of what is now Rusinga Island
column2: Lake Victoria. Scientists have found many links between Rusingoryx and hadrosaur dinosaurs -- particularly the large
column3: hollow dome that makes a crest on top of the animal's skull. (Photo : Todd S. Marshall)

column1: An extinct relative of the wildebeest boasted a trumpet-like nose similar to the strange hollow nasal crests of hadrosaur or duck-billed dinosaurs
column2: according to a new study. Researchers say this discovery offers ""a spectacular example"" of convergent evolution between two very distantly-related animals across tens of millions of years.

column1: The nasal dome is a completely new structure for mammals- it doesn't look like anything you could see in an animal that's alive today
column2: Haley O'Brien
column3: a paleophysiology student at Ohio University
column4: Athens
column5: said in a news release. ""The closest example would be hadrosaur dinosaurs with half-circle shaped crests that enclose the nasal passages themselves.""

column1: The ancient wildebeest-like animals
column2: Rusingoryx atopocranion
column3: lived about 65 thousand years ago
column4: during the late Pleistocene era. Duck-billed dinosaurs
column5: Lambeosaurine hadrosaurs
column6: lived closer to 65 million years ago
column7: during the late Cretaceous. Yet
column8: both animals evolved the same strange nose – which developed the same way as the animals grew from juveniles to adults.

column1: When I first saw the complete skulls
column2: I was blown away
column3: vertebrate paleontologist David C. Evans
column4: who was not part of the study
column5: writes in an email to The Christian Science Monitor. ""The resemblance between Rusingoryx and some hollow-crested dinosaurs in the form of their nasal structures is truly striking
column6: and there are clear parallels in how they evolved and grew. Both groups elongated their noses to such a degree that they evolved highly domed skulls to house their nasal passages on top of their heads
column7: above their eyes.""

column1: Based on an anatomical analysis and acoustical modeling
column2: researchers believe the trumpet-like nasal tube may have allowed Rusingoryx to deepen its normal vocal calls and communicate with others across fairly large distances. In fact
column3: the animals might have been able to call at levels very close to infrasound
column4: such that other animals may not have been able to hear individuals in the herd calling back and forth to each other.

column1: Vocalizations can alert predators
column2: and moving their calls into a new frequency could have made communication safer
column3: O'Brien added. ""On top of this
column4: we know that [both] Rusingoryx and hadrosaurs were consummate herbivores
column5: each having their own highly specialized teeth. Their respective
column6: remarkable dental specializations may have initiated changes in the lower jaw and cheek bones that ultimately led to the type of modification we see in the derived
column7: crest-bearing forms.""

column1: In future studies
column2: researchers hope to learn what led to the once-thriving Rusingoryx's mass exit.

column1: Their study was recently published in the journal Current Biology.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Dipankar Ghose
We often don't pay attention to the fact that our day-to-day existence is inextricably connected with the natural world
column2: the resources it has to offer and the species that thrive on it. Our health
column3: food
column4: and security depend largely on biodiversity. From medical treatments to our daily food requirements
column5: species plays a critical role. Species are a group of living organisms that are similar and can exchange genes or interbreed with each other. ""Species"" is the basic unit of taxonomy used to classify every known organism into. The number of species matters — considerably — to the health of ecosystems
column6: and the world at large.

column1: At a very basic level of interconnectivity
column2: we see this in the medicines that we use
column3: a large portion of it derived from plants species
column4: and more than a third of food crops dependant on pollination by insects. According to the Living Planet Report 2018 (LPR) it is estimated that globally nature provides services worth around USD 125 trillion a year! With a growing human population and increasingly consumerist society
column5: a corresponding increase in primary productivity from trees
column6: plants and marine organisms that convert the solar energy to food is a must. This is possible only if we protect the diversity of species in the world.

column1: From the depth of the deepest oceans to the top of the highest mountains
column2: life in the form of microbes
column3: algae
column4: fungi and arthropods to large mammals
column5: species can be found in nearly every corner of our planet. The species composition on our planet includes 7.3 percent animals
column6: 7.4 percent fungi
column7: 0.02 percent plants
column10: according to research conducted by Larsen et al. (2017). Every species has a role to play in maintaining a balance in the natural world.

column1: Plant species help harness the power of the sun and fix carbon through a process called photosynthesis. It is at the base of the food chain for other life forms and plants are
column2: therefore
column3: known as primary producers. Any change in plant species’ composition and richness affect this basic requirement. One species differs from the other in the way they use natural resources
column4: physical and biological and the way they respond to environmental issues that threaten their basic existence.

column1: What are some of the threats to species?
The decline of species has been phenomenal in recent times. According to the LPR 2018
column2: terrestrial animal and marine animal populations have fallen by 40 percent since 1970. Freshwater ecosystems lost 75 percent of their biodiversity in 1970. Insect populations have declined by 75 percent too
column3: and coral reefs have been damaged beyond repair. What poses a grim challenge to food security is that there have been dramatic reductions in pollinator species like bees
column4: with pollinators helping produce 35 percent of crops globally. Soil biodiversity has also seen a drastic reduction
column5: which affects multiple ecosystem services.

column1: The challenge with species extinction is that it is irreversible. Once a species is extinct from the face of the Earth
column2: there is almost no way to bring them back. Species extinction occurs when a particular species’ numbers decline drastically due to habitat loss
column3: habitat degradation
column4: natural calamity or overexploitation of the species by human beings. In recent years
column5: a tragic example of extinction due to hunting is that of the Northern white rhino in Africa. As of March 2018
column6: only two female northern white rhinos are left in a private conservancy in Kenya. This near extinction has been caused by poaching of this species for rhino horn.

column1: Two species that went extinct from India in the last century include the Asiatic cheetah and the pink-headed duck
column2: a bird that was seen in this country last in 1950. In the present century
column3: another species of bird
column4: that is slowly moving towards a bleak future is the great Indian Bustard. Found in western parts of India and adjoining regions of Pakistan
column5: the global population of the species today stands at less than two hundred. Even with such low numbers
column6: every day there is a continuous fear of more of these birds dying due to anthropogenic pressures like electrocution from power transmission lines that crisscross its habitat. This kind of species loss is irreversible.

column1: One of the biggest reasons that could be attributed to species’ loss
column2: therefore
column3: is the loss or destruction of its habitats. Large scale land use change like forests being destroyed due to either infrastructural developments like roads and highways or even agriculture and urbanisation
column4: and sea beds being drilled for oil have led to large patches of wildlife habitats being wiped out.

column1: Fragmented habitats isolate species populations
column2: which affects their long-term survival due to inbreeding. Large territorial animals are affected mostly by this
column3: where their habitats are fragmented and even the interconnecting corridors are blocked or chocked due to land use change that threatens species survival. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) states that the rapid loss of species that is happening now is estimated to be between 1
column5: 000 times higher than the expected natural extinction rate; and unlike the historical mass extinction events
column6: human populations are entirely responsible for the current phenomenon of extinction.

column1: The rate of species extinctions occurring across the planet is high and climate change and other anthropogenic pressures like land use change and related habitat fragmentation are only aggravating this loss. Climate change adaptation and mitigation thus becomes essential to halt species loss
column2: or even to maintain species diversity.

column1: The way forward for species & landscape conservation
With studies showing a 60 percent decline in wildlife populations in about four decades
column2: it is time that we need to collectively work to halt this decline of different species which is essential for the well-being of human populations. It is nature and her inhabitants that have provided everything to build a modern human society. Recent research has shown the importance of the natural world for our health
column3: wealth
column4: food and security. Landscape-level conservation of species helps in slow down the trend provided
column5: all actors are working with equal dedication and in tandem. Protection of species and their natural habitats need to be a priority for all stakeholders to build a world in which humans live in harmony with nature.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Hope is the thing with feathers
column2: poet Emily Dickinson wrote. For Richard Thorns
column3: the feathers are pink.

column1: Thorns' hope? To prove that a colorful duck is not extinct. This week
column2: he launches a seventh expedition into the inaccessible wilds of Myanmar to search for the pink-headed duck that hasn't been seen alive since 1949
column3: and that was in India. No one has seen the bird alive in Myanmar in more than a century.

column1: Thorns
column2: a British writer who quit his shop clerk job 20 years ago after reading about the pink-headed duck in the book ""Vanishing Birds
column3: has spent $20
column4: 000 of his own money on previous fruitless trips. His birder brother called him mad.

column1: I could have had a lot of nice things
column2: the 53-year-old said. ""I don't want nice things. I want to see a pink-headed duck.""

column1: This time
column2: he is backed by the Global Wildlife Conservation group
column3: which launched a hunt for ""lost species"" — 25 quirky and elusive plants and animals beginning with the duck. A sports optic company and cheesemaking company are also helping pay.

column1: Thorns and three others plan to head to the wetlands north of the vast Indawgyi Lake during the rainy season where they believe they have a better chance of spotting the duck. And Thorn thinks he has a secret weapon: elephants.
He used canoes in the past and thinks he probably spooked the shy birds. Now he plans to bring elephants stomping through the wetlands.
Clearly a bird isn't going to hunker down if there are 2-ton elephants
column2: said Thorn.

column1: As crazy as it may seem
column2: Thorns may be onto something
column3: said ornithologist Kevin McGowan at Cornell University who isn't part of the expedition.

column1: Fairly regularly birds get rediscovered
column2: says McGowan
column3: who has gone on unsuccessful expeditions for the ivory-billed woodpecker. ""We don't see all the world that is in front of our eyes.""

column1: A Cornell student found Bermuda petrels
column2: rare seabirds thought to be extinct for 300 years. Other rediscovered animals include a crow species in Asia and a nocturnal parrot in Australia. These birds survive by not being noticed ""so what's your certainty that it's gone?"" said McGowan.

column1: One thing that keeps Thorns going is the thought that someone else might find the pink-headed duck first.
Every time he goes out
column2: the bird ""breaks my heart
column3: he said. column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The future seems to be bleak for the Najafgarh jheel
column2: and it’s all because of governmental apathy. The Delhi government and the Haryana government are apparently not much bothered about the restoration of the lake — a wetland vital for the revival of the water table in Gurgaon and South Delhi.

column1: While the Delhi government plainly says that the lake does not exist anymore within the boundary of the Capital
column2: the Haryana government is completely indifferent to the matter.

column1: About seven months back the Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage (INTACH) had filed a petition before the National Green Tribal
column2: seeking direction to the governments of Delhi and Haryana to take necessary steps for the lake’s revival.

column1: A file picture of Najafgarh jheel. The lake was eventually drained after Delhi’s flood control department kept widening the Najafgarh drain to save the Capital from floods. The lake has a huge eco-tourism potential
The NGO had previously presented a blueprint for the revival of the lake
column2: and the plan was accepted by the two state governments.

column1: However
column2: beyond that no action was initiated by the governments for actual revival of the wetland.

column1: About half of the jheel once existed within Delhi’s boundary. But replying to the petition
column2: the Delhi government said
column3: “no such water body exists” at the marked location now.

column1: On its part
column2: the Haryana government did not even bother to send a counsel to represent itself in six successive hearings before the National Green Tribunal.

column1: The next date of hearing before the Tribunal is on April 13.
Najafgarh jheel
column2: another name for Sahibi river
column3: tributary of river Yamuna
column4: once occupied more than 300 square kilometres of area in southwest Delhi.

column1: It finds a mention in the Delhi Gazetteer of 1883
column2: and the Survey of India Map of 1911. Before Independence it used to be a rich habitat for birds and other wildlife
column3: often visited by the British parties for hunting.

column1: Allan Octavian Hume
column2: the British ornithologist
column3: reported sightings of birds like the Pink-headed Duck and Siberian Crane here.

column1: These birds are not sighted in the Indian subcontinent anymore.
After the 1960s
column2: the Flood Control Department of Delhi kept widening the Najafgarh drain on the pretext of saving Delhi from floods
column3: and eventually drained the Najafgarh jheel completely.

column1: INTACH had previously presented elaborate blueprints for the revival of the lake
column2: recommending use of floodwaters from the Kakraula regulator and treated effluents from the Gurgaon sewage treatment plant.

column1: After the 1960s
column2: the Flood Control Department of Delhi kept widening the Najafgarh drain on the pretext of saving Delhi from floods

column1: These recommendations were accepted by both the Delhi and Haryana governments
column2: but not acted upon.

column1: INTACH’S petition now prays for directions to the two concerned state governments to take steps to restore the lake to its natural condition.
In a two-page affidavit to National Green Tribunal
column2: the Delhi government has said: “No jheel exists on the land pointed out by INTACH.

column1: There is habitation on the said site which will be difficult to remove. It will also be difficult to demarcate the original lake land. While there is little water left on the Haryana side
column2: there is nothing within the Delhi boundary.”

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Nature's Most Wanted: Conservationists Launch New Quest for Lost Species
Expeditions will delve into the wild
column2: looking for species that haven’t been seen for at least a decade.

column1: Brian Owens
column2: Contributor

column1: (Inside Science) -- Somewhere deep in the remote and largely inaccessible wetlands of northern Myanmar
column2: Richard Thorns hopes to find a ghost. This fall
column3: the ambulance driver and amateur ornithologist plans to leave his home in Crowborough
column4: England to launch his seventh expedition in search of the elusive -- and quite possibly extinct -- pink-headed duck.

column1: The striking but shy bird was always a rare sight in the marshes of India
column2: Bangladesh and Myanmar
column3: and little is known about its behavior and habits. Its large
column4: dark brown body
column5: with characteristic pink plumage adorning its head and neck
column6: has not been conclusively seen in the wild since 1949. But Thorns has made it his personal mission to prove that the bird is still out there.

column1: Pink-headed duck_inline.jpg Pink-headed duck Philip Nelson

Thorns was working in a department store when a chance encounter with the story of the pink-headed duck in a library book captured his imagination nearly 20 years ago. “There wasn't a lot going on in my life career-wise or ambition-wise then
column2: ” he said. “When I read that book
column3: I decided I didn't want to be shop assistant anymore. I wanted to find the pink-headed duck.”

column2: after years of planning and saving money
column3: Thorns made his first trip to Myanmar
column4: a Southeast Asian country formerly known as Burma
column5: which for years has suffered from ethnic strife and from 1962 until 2011 was ruled by the military. “I flew in naive
column6: ” Thorns said. “I didn't realize so much of [the country] was so fiercely guarded and locked down.”

column1: With help from Myanmar's Biodiversity and Nature Conservation Association
column2: he found a promising location to begin his quest
column3: along the Irrawaddy River north of the town of Bhamo in Kachin State. The search was filled with difficulties -- at one point
column4: he and his unlicensed local guide learned that the authorities were looking for them
column5: and had to sneak back into the village after dark. Still
column6: Thorns persisted
column7: embarking on five more expeditions in the subsequent years.

column1: While Thorns has never spotted his quarry on any of his trips
column2: he has encountered several locals who claimed to have seen the ducks in the wild. So he is optimistic about his chances on the upcoming trip. He believes the closed nature of the country favors the bird’s survival
column3: since areas remain where few people are allowed to travel.

column1: For his seventh duck hunt
column2: Thorns has devised a new plan of attack. And he has the backing of a new global project to seek out and protect “lost species.”

column1: Lost and found
The pink-headed duck is just one of many species that have gone AWOL
column2: with no definitive proof whether they are extinct or still alive. In an effort to find some of the missing and draw attention to their stories
column3: Global Wildlife Conservation
column4: an Austin
column5: Texas-based environmental group
column6: has launched the “Search for Lost Species” -- a worldwide hunt for animals and plants that haven't been seen for years.

column1: GWC spent almost a year consulting conservation specialists from around the world on which lost species they would most like to see found. Their initial list included more than 1
column2: 200 options. “It wasn't easy to choose
column3: ” said Robin Moore
column4: a conservation biologist based in Austin and the project's leader.

column1: They eventually narrowed it down to the 25 “most wanted” species: 10 mammals
column2: three birds
column3: three reptiles
column4: three fish
column5: two amphibians
column6: one insect
column7: one crustacean

column1: “The top 25 is a way to capture the public's imagination
column2: ” said Moore. “They are fascinated by the mystery surrounding them.”

column1: Some choices were a no-brainer -- the duck
column2: for example
column3: was nominated multiple times. Others had been missing for an impressive amount of time
column4: like the Himalayan Quail
column5: which has not been seen for 141 years. Or they were extra compelling mysteries
column6: like the Bullneck Seahorse
column7: which has never been spotted alive in the wild and was last collected
column8: perhaps by accident in a fishing net

column1: In building the list
column2: GWC worked to ensure that it included not only a wide variety of animals
column3: but also a wide geographic spread covering many types of habitat and places where there are local partners who can help lead the search.

column1: GWC has some experience with this type of project. In 2010
column2: the group launched the “Search for Lost Frogs” in partnership with Arlington
column3: Virginia-based Conservation International
column4: aimed at finding the top 10 missing amphibians. Within the first year they had rediscovered three -- including one from Borneo that hadn't been seen for more than 100 years
column5: and one in Israel that had been declared extinct after 55 years without a sighting.

column1: They learned from those successes that the excitement that comes with a species rediscovery can provide a big boost for their work
column2: attracting attention and money for ongoing preservation efforts. “The stories it generates can create these emblems of hope and resilience
column3: ” said Moore. “People are more likely to engage with conservation if it's not always doom and gloom.”

column1: There is a debate in the conservation community over whether high-profile
column2: expensive campaigns focused on a few flagship species -- especially ones that may no longer exist -- are the best use of scarce resources. Ernest Small
column3: a botanist with the Canadian department of agriculture in Ottawa who has written about conservation's fixation on flagship species
column4: said he finds the lost species idea a bit gimmicky. “Now I don't mind gimmicks
column5: but as ideas go this one seems a bit far out
column6: ” he said.

column1: He added that by focusing on large
column2: attractive animals conservationists lose an opportunity to educate the public and politicians about the importance of preserving habitats and planetary ecosystems -- though he admitted that is a tough sell at the best of times. “[Focusing on big animals] is probably the best we can do” to get people's attention
column3: he said.

column1: He wonders
column2: then
column3: if this collection of mostly small creatures that live in far-flung corners of the globe will be successful at getting donors in the Western world to open their wallets. “People like to support things that are big and exciting
column4: like elephants
column5: or that live close to home
column6: like monarch butterflies
column7: ” he said.

column1: Jean-Christophe Vié
column2: deputy director of the species program at the International Union for the Conservation of Nature in Gland
column3: Switzerland
column4: is a big believer in the power of an individual species' story to get through to the public. “We need stories to reconnect people to nature
column5: ” he said. “We're not going to reconnect to them with fuzzy concepts like carbon sequestration and ecosystem services.”

column1: But finding a lost species is only the first step
column2: warns Vié. The discovery can give the impression that perhaps the species is not in as much trouble as thought -- when in fact it is likely highly vulnerable
column3: and will require protection.

column1: “Finding one is
column2: in itself
column3: not that useful
column4: ” said Vié. “Finding it and doing something about recovery
column5: that is interesting.”

column1: Small agrees. “If they find one
column2: what are they going to do? These species are really at the brink
column3: it will be hard to keep them going
column4: ” he said.

column1: Moore said GWC's commitment to a species will not end with rediscovery. They will also work to identify the threats it faces
column2: and to preserve the habitat. During the frog search
column3: for example
column4: they helped to set up the first private nature preserve in Haiti to protect the six lost and new species of frog they found. Efforts like this have the added benefit of protecting everything else that lives nearby
column5: noted Moore.

column1: For both the frog and new lost species project
column2: GWC was careful to choose species that represent areas that are important to protect
column3: he said.

column1: WallaceBee_inline.jpg Eli Wyman with one of the only known Wallace's Giant Bee specimens. © Clay Bolt
GWC is currently raising funds to support expeditions
column2: and finding local partners that can help with the search and take the lead for ongoing conservation efforts. Thorns' duck hunt this fall will be one of the first
column3: followed by an expedition to Indonesia early next year by nature photographer Clay Bolt in search of Wallace's Giant Bee -- the world's biggest bee
column4: originally described by famed naturalist Alfred Russel Wallace in 1858. It was not seen again until 1981
column5: and hasn't been seen since.

column1: All of the searches are probably pretty long shots
column2: said Moore. But there are signs of hope. Local reports from Indonesia in 2007 provide some evidence for the survival of Attenborough's Long-beaked Echidna
column3: named after naturalist David Attenborough and missing for 56 years. And though the Fernandina Galápagos Tortoise hasn't been seen since 1906
column4: a 1964 expedition found possible droppings of the long-lived reptile
column5: as well as cactuses that appeared to have been chewed by a tortoise. That search in particular fascinates Moore. “How do you lose a giant tortoise on an island?” he asked.

column1: Bolt
column2: for his part
column3: is cautiously optimistic for his bee hunt. The bee's habitat on a remote Indonesian island chain seems to be mostly intact
column4: and he has been in touch with the 1981 team to learn about where and how to look. “It's certainly a vulnerable species
column5: but most likely it's only missing because no one has gone looking for it
column6: ” he said.

column1: Heart of duckness
Moore thinks the pink-headed duck is one of the project's more speculative efforts. “Lots of people have been looking for it quite intensively for a long time
column2: so the odds are extremely long
column3: ” he said. “But it's high-risk
column4: high-reward. If we were to find it
column5: it would be absolutely incredible.”

column1: Thorns
column2: though
column3: figures he might be on the verge of a breakthrough. He has a theory that the ducks migrate seasonally within Myanmar
column4: living in the wetlands of Kachin State during the wet season
column5: then moving somewhere else during the dry season -- perhaps one of the numerous totally restricted military areas. Since most searches by ornithologists have been conducted during the dry season
column6: it's possible the ducks have simply been elsewhere.

column1: “No one is looking in the wet season. The only people who have described seeing it to me have been fishermen or farmers
column2: locals who are there year-round. So it must migrate somewhere no one is allowed to be
column3: ” he said. “I'm not thinking like a birdwatcher
column4: but a cryptozoologist
column5: ” he said
column6: referring to people who aim to prove the existence of creatures from folklore
column7: like Bigfoot or the Loch Ness Monster.

column1: So on this trip
column2: accompanied by the writer Errol Fuller and photographer John Hodges
column3: Thorns will search the wetlands around Indawgyi Lake at the tail end of the wet season
column4: when any ducklings will have fledged but should still be hanging around the nest.

column1: Thorns_inline.jpg Richard Thorns at Indawgyi Lake in Myanmar on a previous expedition. Courtesy of Richard Thorns
And he's changing his search technique. Previous trips have involved paddling about in boats
column2: which can only gently nose into the dense elephant grass where the birds nest. The retiring ducks
column3: if they were there
column4: likely just hunkered down and waited for the boat to move on
column5: Thorns thinks. So this time he and his companions will use elephants to ride right through the grassy swamps
column6: hoping to flush the birds out.

column1: “We're replicating the techniques of the British Raj
column2: ” he said. India's colonial rulers used to spot -- and shoot -- the ducks while hunting tigers from elephant-back in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Thorns said the birds are probably used to wild elephants in that area
column3: so should not be unduly stressed by the search. “We might have to almost be on top of them before they break cover
column4: ” he said.

column1: With his new theory and new search plan ready
column2: Thorns has high hopes that this trip will be the one that makes history. “I think I can almost say that the search is over
column3: ” he said.

column1: If the search for the duck
column2: or any of the other most wanted species
column3: indeed proves successful
column4: it will be a huge boon for conservation efforts
column5: said Moore. And it will provide an opportunity for us to do a better job of protecting these fascinating species this time around. “If we give them a second chance
column6: they can surprise us
column7: ” he said.";Nature's Most Wanted: Conservationists Launch New Quest for Lost Species;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiZWh0dHBzOi8vd3d3Lmluc2lkZXNjaWVuY2Uub3JnL25ld3MvbmF0dXJlcy1tb3N0LXdhbnRlZC1jb25zZXJ2YXRpb25pc3RzLWxhdW5jaC1uZXctcXVlc3QtbG9zdC1zcGVjaWVz0gEA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://www.insidescience.org/sites/default/files/favicon_0.png;05/26/2017;"[{'sent': 'Brian Owens

column6: Khushwant Singh
column7: Ruskin Bond and Bulbul Sharma are lively presences in these pages.

column1: Winged Fire
Author: Valmik Thapar
Publishers: Aleph
Pages: 486 (Hardcover)
Price: 2
While every sixth person alive is Indian
column2: every sixth species of bird is found in India. The third volume in a series edited by Valmik Thapar
column3: Winged Fire
column4: is devoted to the airborne sixth
column5: a community about 1
column6: 400 species strong. Serious birders may scorn this book
column7: though
column8: since it contains scrumptious pictures but none of the arcana of field guides
column9: such as how to tell bushchats from stonechats by their superciliaries or coverts

column1: To expect a real birder to appreciate this book is like expecting a Shakespearean scholar to curl up with a Mickey Spillane. But the laity with deep pockets would find this collection an enjoyable introduction to the simple pleasures of birdwatching
column2: with vibrant photography and classical colour plates. The liveliest image is a stop-action photograph by Ramki Sreenivasan of the extremely rare Bengal florican taking flight and descending.

column1: Some of the accounts accompanying the pictures explain why birds have been quitting nature to populate picture books — rampant hunting. In 1949
column2: Monica Martin wrote of tables groaning under the weight of exotic meats in the shooting season — roast peacock in such abundance that after a month
column3: everything but the breast went to the servants
column4: partridge
column5: junglefowl (she calls it “wild chicken”) and green pigeon stuffed with olives
column6: in port wine sauce.

column1: Thapar’s accent is on the social rather than the ornithological. Frank B Simson’s little piece on the “rare pink-headed duck of Purneah” ends with the approved practice for catching them for the table. Men waded into their midst while hiding their faces in earthen pots
column2: then grabbed the stupid
column3: trusting creatures by the legs. There are also extracts about murgabaazi (cockfighting
column4: by Pran Nevile) and ishqbazi
column5: a term coined by Akbar for pigeon fancying
column6: according to Abu’l Fazl. The imperial sport degenerated to kabootarbazi in our era
column7: and the word now signifies risky speculation.

column1: Fazl delves into the technicalities of feeding hawks in imperial Fatehpur Sikri: “In Kashmir and in the aviaries of Indian amateurs
column2: the birds are generally fed once a day; but at Court they are fed twice.” They got meat for lunch and about half a dozen sparrows for dinner. Did the sparrow extinction wave we see today begin in Mughal times
column3: on the dietary prescription of a monarch?

column1: But there is something cock-eyed about the meticulous bibliography of this book. Fazl’s quotation is dated to 1871
column2: when the man had been in the grave for 269 years. Chronologically
column3: the closest translation is that of H Blochmann and Col HS Jarrett
column4: which was printed by the Asiatic Society at Calcutta’s Baptist Mission Press two years later
column5: in 1873. Dating sources to the lifetime of the author is more indicative than quoting the particular edition one has read. It is creepy to find Salim Ali writing about village waterfowl in 2008
column6: from beyond the veil.

column1: Never mind
column2: here’s another excellent sideshow: Mrs Murray Mitchell writes in 1876 about a huge adjutant bird pacing her boundary wall in Calcutta
column3: to which an urchin hurls a live kitten
column4: which vanishes into its bag-like gizzard. She reports that a fine of Rs 50 is imposed on those who kill these enormous scavengers. An early green tax
column5: or an English nod to the Indian notion that adjutants house the souls of Brahmins?

column1: Lest you think this is a compendium of Mughal and Raj accounts
column2: Indian voices like I Allan Sealy
column3: Khushwant Singh
column4: Ruskin Bond and Bulbul Sharma are lively presences in these pages.

column1: Thapar’s own introduction is a personal account recalling his childhood in Delhi. The spacious
column2: gracious Delhi of half a century before the crowded
column3: polluted concrete jungle
column4: when every garden came with a mandatory pair of hoopoes on the lawn and a pair of red-vented bulbuls in the pomegranate tree. After that homely initiation
column5: Delhi’s children traditionally made first contact with the wild in Bharatpur
column6: teeming with painted storks
column7: cormorants and darters. And then

column1: But soft
column2: it is dawn. And perched on a TV cable slinging earthwards past my apartment window is a grey hornbill
column3: looking strangely postnuclear as always. India’s birdscape may be a shadow of its former raucous
column4: robust self
column5: but our birds still have the element of surprise.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"This is the MYANMAR GOLD LIST by Sampan Travel.
This is our edit of the most exciting
column2: most extraordinary people
column3: places and initiatives in Myanmar travel. The sights
column4: the smells
column5: the movements. The game-changers and the go-getters.The innovators
column6: the pioneers. The trend-setters going further
column7: diving deeper
column8: and helping anyone travel better through Myanmar.

column1: Now is not the time to travel. But now can be the time to plan. The time to wish and to daydream.
So while you’re at home
column2: thinking about travel
column3: have a look at what these people are doing. Right now you can’t follow them in real life so go follow them online: read about them
column4: post about them
column5: share
column6: tweet
column7: and pin. Fire them a message to ask them a question or just to say “Hey! What you’re doing is awesome!”

column1: Bookmark this page; tear it out
column2: fold it up and keep it somewhere secure. And then when it is safe to do so
column3: strap on your boots … and go travelling once more.

column1: The MYANMAR GOLD LIST will look at the Game Changers
column2: the Trends
column3: the Hotels and the Activities. But before any of that
column4: we are looking at The Destinations.

column1: The Highlands: Nagaland and Mogok

Since the first missionaries and privateers arrived on the shores of Burma tales of the head-hunters of Nagaland have thrilled the drawing rooms of Europe. The British fought them and eventually managed to subdue most of the tribes but the fierce traditions of Naga – the tattoos
column2: the drums
column3: the head dresses – endured.

column1: The Naga fought with the British in the Second World War and the young Tommies from the Yorkshire Dales arriving in Kohima and Imphal found themselves guided through the jungle by richly painted Naga warriors with titanic spears.

Most people visit Nagaland in January to see the dancing and festivities of Naga New Year. We recommend avoiding this time unless you have a yearning for crowds and forced jollyment. At another time of year
column2: find a trusted local guide
column3: rent a 4x4 and travel from Hkamti over the Chindwin River to Lahe. Trappings of the outside world such as shirts from the English Premier League are evident but you will also be offered novel specialties such as testicle of cockerel.

column1: The cuisine is more prosaic in Mogok but in raucous restaurants such as Lu Do travellers can sample new tastes washed down with Black Shield and wedges of lime. Around the centre of the town bloom 172 cherry blossom trees and at the adjacent market travellers sit down for Mogok mee shay
column2: steamed mustard leaf and freshly squeeze soy milk.

column1: You must visit the ruby mines and the gem markets but don’t neglect other delights of the town such as the coffee plantations and the macadamia fields; the British Cemetery of the 1800s and the Agape church where young Lisu with earnest
column2: stilted English strum Christian rock.

column1: Go North: Indawgyi Lake and the Pink Headed Duck Café
The town of Lonton sits upon the western banks of Indawgyi
column2: Myanmar’s largest lake. Indawgyi is not only larger than Inle but also much quieter. One of the most pleasant things to do at Inle is rent a kayak and paddle from village to village
column3: stopping for tea in monasteries amongst indifferent cattle.

column1: Indawgyi has long been a honey-spot for bird-watching. The most intrepid twitchers may be on the hunt for the elusive pink-headed duck
column2: believed to have been extinct since the 1940s but rumored to still splash about somewhere in the marshes of Kachin State.

column1: In honour of the duck
column2: Face of Indawgyi are soon to be opening the Pink Headed Duck Café
column3: before breaking ground on the region’s first eco-hotel.

column1: Today
column2: the most exciting hotel at Indawgyi is In Daw Mahar Guesthouse – an angular characterful dwelling with a large terrace stretching out onto the lake. Indawgyi Motel is a tidier option; Mother’s Home a cosier one. All are near to local restaurants serving Kachin honey and coffee from the hills.

column1: Off-piste
column2: on the beach: Gwa and Gaw Yan Gyi

column1: Ueli and Arakan Nature Lodge put Gwa on the map for Yangonites seeking an alternative to the clipped resorts of Ngapali and the boozy vibes of Ngwe Saung Beach.
Arakan Nature Lodge is not so much a place to do things
column2: but a place to be. An idyll to listen to the sounds of the sea and allow your mind to wander.

column1: Other hotels are cropping up along this stretch of coastline. Lalay Lodge is situated just south of Thandwe in the village of Maung Shwe Lay. The staff are from the village
column2: the cuisine from Rakhine State
column3: and one of the hotel’s three dogs – Bro
column4: Blaize and Wonky – are likely to join guests on their hike up to the adjacent hill to watch the sun set into the Bay of Bengal.

column1: Further south still
column2: on the other side of Ngwe Suang Beach is the Gaw Yan Gyi peninsula. It is possible to ride down by motorbike from Ngwe Saung or hire a boat. However most commonly travellers take the bus from Pathein. Arrive at dawn and arrange bikes to take you down the peninsula
column3: through misty glades and to the twin beaches of Gwa Yan Gyi
column4: one for fishing
column5: the other for pleasure.

column1: The Retro Come Backs: Pindaya and Pyin Oo Lwin
Pindaya and Pyin Oo Lwin are undergoing a renaissance.
Pindaya used to be promoted as just a day-trip from Inle. This is no longer the case. Better to stay a few nights
column2: sleeping at Cottage House – aka La Maison de Pindaya - where the garden overflows with lavender and orchids and giant pinkpomelos
column3: bulge and hang low from the trees. Each room has been designed with an exquisite aesthetic taste: the cushion covers are made with Pakokku fabric and the bed-side table books include titles like La Vallée des rubis and Un Françaisen Birmanie.

column1: Pyin Oo Lwin was described by one unimpressed traveler in the 1950s as exaggeratively nationalistic and excessively dull. Its drizzle made it deserving of the moniker “Little England.”
The waxworks in the Aureum Palace are turning green and the European cemetery is in a further state of decrepitude. The Candacraig remains closed and
column2: most likely
column3: haunted.

column1: But today
column2: in the fields of The Croft Farm children can skip about filling little wicker baskets with plump strawberries. Coffee can be enjoyed from the faux windmill or saved for the delightful Pan Taw Win restaurant while making plans for day treks.

column1: Akimomo Hotel with its Japanese spa is breathing fresh life into the hotel scene. Alternatively one can stay at The View
column2: hiking down the crevasse to the plunge pool of the Anikasan Falls and at December Restaurant cows can be petted and guinea pigs cuddled while waiters and waitresses in oversized cowboy hats serve creamy milkshakes and oh-no khaoswe.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The Pink Headed Duck has remained elusive since it was last seen in 1949. MUST CREDIT: Philip Nelson via Global Wildlife Conservation.
The scarlet harlequin frog was last seen in 1990. MUST CREDIT: Enrique La Marca via Global Wildlife Conservation.
The Himalayan Quail is the longest-missing species on the list. It was last seen in 1876. MUST CREDIT: National Museum of Natural History Naturalis via Global Wildlife Conservation.
Once upon a time
column2: a subspecies of giant tortoise lived on Fernandina
column3: the least-explored island in the Galapagos.

column2: explorers with the California Academy of Sciences found one male Fernandina Galapagos tortoise — and killed it to preserve as a specimen. The next sign came in 1964
column3: when an expedition to the island reported the presence of tortoise scat. An aerial survey in 2009 spotted something resembling a tortoise. But for all practical purposes
column4: this reptile has been lost for 111 years.

column1: Now the quest to find it — and two dozen other “lost species” — is about to be renewed. Global Wildlife Conservation
column2: a Texas-based organization
column3: is launching a global search for what it calls the top 25 “most wanted” animals (and one plant). None is officially extinct. But
column4: collectively
column5: the species have not been seen in more than 1
column6: 500 years.

column1: The list
column2: which was compiled in consultation with experts from the International Union for Conservation of Nature
column3: includes a bat
column4: a bee
column5: a parakeet
column6: a sea horse and a type of coral. The experts were asked to nominate species that had not been spotted in more than 10 years and had cultural significance. Species already declared extinct were not considered.

column1: Most important
column2: project lead Robin Moore said
column3: was a “glimmer of hope
column4: ” for their rediscovery.

column1: “We are in an extinction crisis
column2: and I think people need to feel at least there’s some hope
column3: ” said Moore
column4: a biologist and director of communications at GWC. “Hope is a more powerful motivator than despair.”

column1: From an initial list of 1
column2: 200 nominations
column3: the organization narrowed the list to what Moore called 25 “quirky
column4: charismatic” poster species that
column5: if they still exist
column6: are found in 18 countries across the globe. It does not include species for which many people are already looking
column7: Moore said
column9: a bird reported to have been seen in Arkansas in 2004 (although that sighting is in doubt).

column1: Moore said the organization hopes to start expeditions in the late summer
column2: after an initial effort to raise $500
column3: 000. The kind of search will vary
column4: he said. Scientists might launch a two-week quest in the grasslands and swamps of Myanmar
column5: also known as Burma
column6: to look for the pink-headed duck
column7: which has been “lost” for 68 years. Larger mammals
column8: like the Wondiwoi tree kangaroo of Indonesia
column9: might be best spotted with remote cameras. Talking to locals could be key to finding the scarlet harlequin frog in the cloud forest of Venezuela. Divers and vessels will be required for the search for Wellington’s solitary coral
column10: which was abundant in some parts of the Galapagos until an El Niño in the early 1980s.

column1: Moore has firsthand evidence this campaign could work. In 2010
column2: when he was at Conservation International
column3: he and colleagues launched “The Search For Lost Frogs
column4: ” which took scientists across the world in search of 10 missing frogs. Within a year
column5: they had located three and rediscovered 12 others.

column1: Species on the list include the Namdapha flying squirrel
column2: which has been missing for 36 years. A single specimen collected in a national park in northeast India is the only evidence it ever existed.

column1: The Syr Darya shovelnose sturgeon was last seen in the 1960s in Kazakhstan.
Despite vigorous searches for the pink-headed duck in Myanmar after unconfirmed sightings in 2006
column2: it has remained elusive since it was last seen in 1949.

column1: The Himalayan quail is the longest-missing species on the list. It was last seen in 1876.
The scarlet harlequin frog was last seen in 1990
column2: but anecdotal reports suggest it could still live in a remote area scientists have not yet examined.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"For field biologists Mahesh Babu and Ganesh Pallela
column2: it was a routine survey of marine biodiversity along River Godavari in Kakinada
column3: Andhra Pradesh when they spotted an unusual shark. It was no longer than three feet and had distinct black markings on its dorsal
column4: pectoral and tail fins. Still
column5: it was hard to pinpoint the exact species as minor morphological differences play a major role in identification. Not taking any chances
column6: and with an imminent feeling that this was not a common sighting
column7: the two asked Anil Mohapatra
column8: a scientist from the Zoological Survey of India
column9: for help. He came back with surprising results — the duo had spotted the critically endangered Pondicherry shark
column10: last seen 39 years ago in India!

column1: Unlike the Pondicherry shark
column2: it would seem impossible to confuse the peacock spider aka the Gooty tarantula with any other arachnid. This peacock of the spider world is not only of a mammoth size but also has a noticeable blue lustre that makes it quite easy to spot. And yet
column3: it took scientists 102 years to rediscover the tarantula after it was first spotted in 1899 in a railway timber yard. It looks like species such as these — the Pondicherry shark and the Gooty tarantula
column4: the pink-headed duck and the Himalayan quail — have lied low
column5: as if deliberately from prying human eyes
column6: hardly observed or documented in the millions of years of earth’s existence. While remaining elusive could be a survival instinct
column7: the changing character of the habitats and the ecosystems themselves could place them in more mortal danger than ever before if they continue to stay hidden.

column1: Living in oblivion
There are many animals and plants in India
column2: especially those that have been listed as endangered or critically endangered by the International Union of Conservation of Nature (IUCN)
column3: which have also remained elusive for a very long period of time. The pink-headed duck was last seen in 1935 and then again claimed to have been spotted in 2009
column4: but many believe it is already extinct. In 1987
column5: the Zoological Survey of India received skin samples of the rare Malabar civet. Since then
column6: the civet has not been seen. The Himalyan quail is a medium-sized bird belonging to the pheasant family
column7: with distinctive red or yellow bill and legs
column8: and prominent white spots around the eyes. It has a long covert tail which is longer than most other quails. However
column9: this description is based on 10 specimens that were seen
column10: shot or collected between 1836 and 1876 in India
column11: around Uttarakhand. It has been 142 years since the Himalayan quail was last seen.

column1: In an era of GPS tracking
column2: it might seem unusual that so many species still remain untraceable
column3: but there could be plenty of reasons. According to Asad R Rahmani
column4: former director of Bombay Natural History Society and noted ornithologist
column5: the Himalayan quail for instance was a rarity even during the days when it was seen in Uttarakhand. Same is the case with the pink-headed duck which was uncommon even during the time when its presence around West Bengal
column6: Bihar and Myanmar was fairly known. With lack of scientific studies
column7: greater descriptions of the habitat these species are found in
column8: and probably hunting sprees by locals and colonial empires
column9: these animals and birds have been surviving in virtual oblivion.

column1: Another reason for the continued disappearance could be the absence of a constant field study to track them. In India
column2: for example
column3: the scientific study of the Gooty tarantula and other such giant spiders is relatively recent and began after measures to curb illegal trade of the species were taken in the late 1990s. An international team of experts was brought in during that time to not just search for tarantulas in India
column4: but also train some of the local scientists to continue the work. Efforts like this eventually led to the rediscovery of the peacock spider by Sanjay Molur and his colleagues
column5: inside a tree hole
column6: thousands of metres above the ground
column7: completely protected from human interference but finally spotted by scientists who armed with ladders and dental mirrors had the one-point mission of finding the spider again.

column1: What is worrying is that missions like these to exclusively trace a lost species are few and far between as they need huge funding
column2: time and effort. An area cannot be notified as protected unless there is an evidence of a special species existing in that locality. In the meantime
column3: the habitat is vulnerable to being lost forever as urban needs takeover natural landscapes. For marine animals like the Pondicherry shark that was discovered by chance
column4: the threat also comes when fishermen who unknowingly catch and kill them.

column1: Fishermen who spoke to the scientists in Andhra Pradesh confessed that sharks were sometimes sold in the area but they had no idea about this particular one being so rare. The peacock spider has gained quite a reputation in the exotic pet world adding to the list of threats such lesser known creatures might face. While it is still a rarity in the wild
column2: many pet owners in the US have been known to breed them in captivity and sell them
column3: thanks to an unknown and illegal supply of a few spiders from Sri Lanka to the US in the 90s!

column1: Lost Species Project
Fearing deeper repercussions if a species was never found again
column2: like the loss of an entire ecosystem
column3: Global Wildlife Conservation
column4: an international organisation
column5: started the Lost Species Project a couple of years ago. They listed 1
column6: 200 species
column7: including many from India
column8: that had been lost for decades or centuries
column9: and are now collaborating with IUCN to find them. The idea is that if we can rediscover these hidden jewels of nature
column10: then there is still hope to regain what we have lost of wildlife and the environment around us. column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"More than just numbers We often frame negative human impacts on animal species in terms of numbers of individuals reduced or numbers of regions from which species are absent. However
column2: human activities are likely affecting species in more complex ways than these figures can capture. Kühl et al. studied behavioral and cultural diversity in our closest relative
column3: the chimpanzee. They found that human-mediated disturbance is reducing these complex traits. Human influence thus goes well beyond simple loss of populations or species
column4: leading to behavioral change even where populations persist. Science
column5: this issue p. 1453

column1: Abstract Chimpanzees possess a large number of behavioral and cultural traits among nonhuman species. The “disturbance hypothesis” predicts that human impact depletes resources and disrupts social learning processes necessary for behavioral and cultural transmission. We used a dataset of 144 chimpanzee communities
column2: with information on 31 behaviors
column3: to show that chimpanzees inhabiting areas with high human impact have a mean probability of occurrence reduced by 88%
column4: across all behaviors
column5: compared to low-impact areas. This behavioral diversity loss was evident irrespective of the grouping or categorization of behaviors. Therefore
column6: human impact may not only be associated with the loss of populations and genetic diversity
column7: but also affects how animals behave. Our results support the view that “culturally significant units” should be integrated into wildlife conservation.

column1: Many animals show population-specific behavioral variation
column2: with chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) exhibiting exceptionally high levels of behavioral diversity (1
column3: 2). This diversity has been documented in a variety of contexts
column4: including communication
column5: thermoregulation
column6: and extractive foraging (table S1). Chimpanzees are also proficient tool users
column7: using sticks
column13: and algae (table S1). Many of these behaviors are inferred to be socially learned and therefore cultural (2)
column14: although the influence of genetic and environmental variation cannot always be ruled out (3). Culture in chimpanzees is supported by the occurrence of local traditions irrespective of resource or tool abundance (1
column15: 2) and by controlled experiments demonstrating that naïve chimpanzees can socially learn new behaviors (4
column19: are regularly discovered when observing previously unstudied populations (5).

column1: Cultural behaviors in great apes
column2: notably chimpanzees (1) and orang-utans (6)
column3: are maintained by cultural processes including innovation
column4: diffusion
column5: and vertical and horizontal transmission (2
column6: 7). These behaviors are vulnerable to environmental disturbance
column7: in that if crucial conditions are modified
column8: the overall rate of opportunities for social transmission may be reduced (7). This proposition
column10: ” predicts that under anthropogenically disturbed conditions
column11: behavioral traditions in great apes may disappear not only with the complete extinction of a population
column12: but also when the population remains
column13: owing to resource depletion or a breakdown in opportunities for social learning (7). Major elements of human impact include habitat loss

column1: In the current Anthropocene era
column2: Earth’s biosphere is being heavily degraded by unsustainable resource use and high rates of biodiversity loss (8). This overexploitation is substantially affecting chimpanzees and their habitat
column3: namely African tropical forests and savanna woodlands (9). All four chimpanzee subspecies are severely threatened by deforestation and poaching
column4: caused by a rapidly growing human population (8–10). These factors have already led to major population declines
column5: fragmentation and regional extirpations (10)
column6: and reduced genetic diversity (11).

column1: The large behavioral diversity of chimpanzees
column2: coupled with rapid population decline
column3: makes investigation of the disturbance hypothesis timely: To what extent are chimpanzee behavioral and cultural diversity affected by habitat fragmentation and population loss resulting from human activities? To address this question
column4: we applied a range of noninvasive techniques to collect a wide spectrum of environmental
column5: social
column6: demographic
column7: and behavioral information on previously unstudied chimpanzee communities
column8: or communities not fully habituated to human observers
column9: at 46 locations (Fig. 1). The actual number of chimpanzee communities represented is likely to be higher
column10: as individuals from more than one community may have been observed at a location. Therefore
column11: we define a chimpanzee community as those individuals that occur at a specific geographic location
column12: with associated observations on behaviors. With few exceptions
column13: we collected data over a minimum of one annual cycle (observation period between 12 and 30 months at 37 locations; observation period from 1 to 10 months at 9 locations) in a systematic grid design (grid size range: 9 to 143 km2).

column1: Fig. 1 Locations of all 144 unique chimpanzee communities for which information on select behaviors was collected for this study. This dataset includes 46 communities from the Pan African Programme (PanAf) and 106 communities for which information was also available from the published literature (non-PanAf). Of these
column2: eight communities had both PanAf and non-PanAf data available. Habitat type represented as biomes modified from the Terrestrial Ecoregions of the World Map 2001.

column1: We compiled presence and absence data on 31 known chimpanzee behaviors (table S1) from these 46 chimpanzee communities and complemented the dataset with additional information about these same behaviors on another 106 chimpanzee communities from the published literature. In total
column2: 144 unique chimpanzee communities comprised the full dataset (Fig. 1 and data file S1). We recorded observations on these behaviors by (i) extensive camera trapping; (ii) fecal samples that provided evidence of ingestion of insects
column3: algae
column4: and honey
column5: resources often exploited with the aid of tools; and (iii) artifacts of tool use identified during reconnaissance
column6: line
column7: and strip transect surveys. We selected behaviors that were detectable through indirect evidence (e.g.
column8: tools and artifacts) or direct evidence from camera traps and that exhibit variation across populations rather than being universal traits of chimpanzees (1
column10: 12) (table S1). Although we do not explicitly test for cultural transmission
column11: we infer that much of chimpanzee behavioral diversity reflects cultural diversity owing to an accumulation of observational and experimental evidence (1
column16: many behaviors included here have already been classified as cultural (1).

column1: According to the disturbance hypothesis
column2: potential behavioral diversity loss is expected to manifest across multiple chimpanzee generations
column3: so human impact should be assessed over long time periods. We used the “human footprint
column4: ” a spatial composite layer integrating human impact over time by combining infrastructure
column5: human population density
column6: forest cover
column7: and remoteness
column8: to provide a geographically explicit variable quantifying the overall effect of humans on the environment with a 1-km-grid resolution (14). We used both Bayesian regression (BR) and maximum likelihood (ML) mixed models to test the hypothesis that variation in human impact among chimpanzee populations predicts variation in the number of behaviors present (12). We controlled for observation effort in number of months
column10: and chimpanzee subspecies in the analyses (12) (tables S2 to S6 and figs. S1 to S5).

column1: We found that chimpanzee communities located in areas with a high degree of human impact exhibited an 88% lower mean probability of occurrence
column2: across all behaviors
column3: compared to communities with the least human impact observed {Fig. 2
column4: estimate (mean of the posterior distribution) = −0.40
column5: CI (95% credible interval) = [−0.73
column7: P =0.009}. We found this effect irrespective of the grouping of behaviors
column9: when behaviors were grouped into broader categories such as foraging for termites or thermoregulation (table S1
column14: or when considering non–tool use behaviors only (estimate = −0.75
column21: P = 0.018; Fig. 2 and tables S1 to S4). We assessed the reliability of our analyses by testing various subsets of the data and by removing a single behavior at a time
column22: which showed that no single behavior was responsible for our results (figs. S3 and S4 and table S6). The control predictor “subspecies” showed highly overlapping effects
column23: indicating minimal subspecies-specific effects. As expected
column24: the control variable observation months revealed a strong positive effect for all models (figs. S1 and S2 and tables S2 to S5).

column1: Fig. 2 The probability of occurrence of a behavior per chimpanzee community decreases with human impact. Human impact negatively affects the probability of occurrence of behaviors (top left)
column2: irrespective of grouping behaviors by category (bottom left)
column3: or by tool use and non–tool use behaviors (top and bottom right
column4: respectively). The probability of occurrence across behaviors is depicted by 67
column6: and 97% credibility intervals (green areas) of the mean predicted posterior distribution (dashed line)
column7: plotted excluding random effects and for all subspecies combined. The area of the points corresponds to the respective number of chimpanzee communities constituting that data point (range: 1 to 36 communities).

column1: Several potential mechanisms may explain the observed pattern. First
column2: areas with high human impact generally have decreased chimpanzee density and abundance (10). As has been shown for humans (3
column4: population size can play a major role in maintaining cultural traits
column5: although this relationship is debated (16). A similar mechanism may occur in declining chimpanzee populations (17). Second
column6: chimpanzees may reduce the frequency of conspicuous behaviors as human impact increases (7). Third
column7: climate change may play a role. For example
column8: nut production is strongly dependent on weather conditions and a changing climate is causing greater interannual variation in nut availability (18)
column9: stochastically increasing the potential loss in nut cracking behavior over time. Fourth
column10: habitat degradation and resource depletion may lead to a lower carrying capacity of individuals
column11: thereby reducing opportunities for social learning. This may eventually lead to the disappearance of the behavior. Most likely
column12: a combination of these mechanisms interacts with environmental stability
column15: to create the overall loss of chimpanzee behavioral diversity associated with human impact.

column1: Some studies on chimpanzees living in human-dominated landscapes suggest that a reduction in behavioral diversity will eventually be partially compensated for by new inventions (9). Moreover
column2: genetic and ecological variation are expected to continue to be important drivers of behavioral and cultural diversity (3). Chimpanzees do show adaptations to modified environments (9)
column3: and one may ask whether the processes of behavioral loss and innovation act on similar
column4: or different
column5: time scales
column6: and at which point they might reach equilibrium (7).

column1: We are currently witnessing a decline in great ape populations at a rate of 2.5 to 6% per year due to human impact (10
column2: 19). Our results suggest that chimpanzee populations are losing their characteristic sets of behavioral traits and that a number of as-yet undiscovered behaviors may be lost without having ever been described. Considerable effort is urgently needed to protect these populations if we are to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and drivers of their cultural diversification. As such
column3: our findings support the concept of “culturally significant units
column4: ” whereby a more integrative approach to conservation is needed that considers behavioral diversity in addition to population size and trends for wildlife management (20
column5: 21). Given our limited understanding of the potentially adaptive value of local traditions
column6: we advocate using the precautionary principle of aiming for maximal protection of behavioral variation. We suggest that
column7: for chimpanzees
column8: specific interventions are needed to protect their natural resources and tool-use sites in order to maintain behavioral plasticity and safeguard their capacity for cultural evolution. Therefore
column9: we anticipate the necessity for a new concept
column11: ” with which the behavioral and cultural diversity of this species might be recognized and protected. Such a concept could easily be extended to other species exhibiting a high degree of cultural variability
column12: such as orang-utans (6) and whales (20). This proposition is in accordance with the Convention on Biological Diversity
column13: as well as recent recommendations by the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals
column14: of the United Nations Environment Programme (22)
column15: which calls for the protection of physiological
column17: and behavioral diversity of culturally rich wildlife.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"• The second part the trip exploring Kabalega’s Kingdom in Uganda takes us through an indigenous forest to a church built by Polish World War II refugees.
By RUPI MANGAT
More by this Author
At first glance Masindi gives the impression of a one-street
column2: nondescript town with relics of colonial architecture. But is has an interesting history: Sally Wareing
column3: a retired octogenarian teacher runs the New Garden View Court Hotel.

column1: “In the 1920s
column2: the East Africa Railways and Harbour transported people and cargo by road between Butiaba (on Lake Albert) to Masindi
column3: ” Wareing says as she gives me a tour of the town.

column1: The cargo included ivory and pelts being taken from the Congo to Masindi Port on Lake Kyoga
column2: and then by rail to Mombasa. Masindi town
column3: 45 kilometres from the port
column4: had a customs shed for registration of goods.

column1: With profits running high in 1923
column2: the now defunct East African Railways and Harbours Corporation built the Masindi Hotel where we enjoyed a morning coffee.

column1: In the 1950s
column2: Hollywood stars Humphrey Bogart and Katherine Hepburn stayed here during the filming of the African Queen.
American author Ernest Hemingway also spent time here after crashing his plane twice at Murchison Falls.

column1: Advertisement
Chimpanzees at Kinyara
It is 6am. An hour’s drive from Masindi has taken us to Kinyara Sugar
column2: one of Uganda’s largest manufacturers to meet its famous residents
column3: a family of chimpanzees living in the riverine forest on both edges of the sugar plantation.

column1: We follow the guide along a path through the indigenous forest that once was part of Budongo forest stretching from Murchison Falls.
Two hours later
column2: the chimpanzee family appears. They are chasing a troop of colobus monkeys. One falls to the ground into the waiting circle of apes and the feast begins.

column1: Our guide informs us that the chimpanzees are allowed to eat the sugarcane courtesy of the sugar millers.
Today there are only 5
column2: 0 00 chimpanzees in Uganda
column3: from a population of tens of thousands a century ago. Spread across Africa’s rainforest
column4: the global population is 30

column1: Farther along the route
column2: we see a white-washed church in the middle of green fields. It’s a church built in the late 1940s by Polish refugees after the Second World War.

column1: After the war
column2: thousands of Poles were brought to East Africa by the British and Polish government-in-exile in London.

column1: The church stands strong with the original framed paintings of the Christ’s story
column2: and outside lie the graves of those who died here.

column1: Murchison Falls
Finally
column2: I travel to Murchison Falls. From the gate to the top of the falls the road is tarmacked and cars are speeding on it.

column1: Felled trees lie on the ground along the road to the ferry
column2: where a large bridge is being built over the Nile. Signboards dot the road as Chinese surveyors supervise the construction work.

column1: Kabalega’s aka Murchison’s waterfall thunders down 43 metres through a seven-metre gap in the rocks. The Ugandan government plans to build a dam on Uhuru Falls
column2: which is just a few feet away from Murchison. column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Share this
