Chimpanzees that use a multi-step process and complex tools to gather termites are more likely to share tools with novices
column2: researchers report.

column1: For most wild chimpanzees
column2: tool use is an important part of life—but learning these skills is no simple feat. Wild chimpanzees transfer tools to each other
column3: and this behavior has previously been shown to serve as a form of teaching.

column1: The study helps illuminate chimpanzees’ capacity for prosocial—or helping—behavior
column2: a quality recognized for its potential role in the evolution of human cultural abilities.

column1: “Non-human primates are often thought to learn tool skills by watching others and practicing on their own
column2: with little direct help from mothers or other expert tool users
column3: ” says Stephanie Musgrave
column4: assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Miami and first author of the study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

column1: “In contrast
column2: the results from this research indicate that social learning may vary in relation to how challenging the task is: during tasks that are more difficult
column3: mothers can in fact play a more active role
column4: including behaviors that function to teach.”

column1: Beginning with Jane Goodall in the 1960s
column2: researchers have been studying chimpanzee tool use for decades at the Gombe Stream Research Center in Tanzania. The Gombe chimpanzee study is one of the longest running studies of animal behavior in the wild. This year marks the 20-year anniversary of the study of chimpanzees in the Goualougo Triangle
column3: Republic of Congo
column4: where researchers have documented some of the most complex tool behaviors of chimpanzees.

column1: The study is distinctive because it applies standardized methods to directly compare how processes of cultural transmission may differ between two populations of wild chimpanzees. In both populations
column2: the chimpanzees use tools to target the same resource—but the task varies in complexity.

column1: The findings of the current study are important on a number of levels
column2: Musgrave says. “First
column3: chimpanzee populations may vary not only in the complexity of their tool behaviors but in the social mechanisms that support these behaviors
column4: ” she says. “Second
column5: the capacity for helping in chimpanzees may be both more robust and more flexible than previously appreciated.”

column1: Chimpanzees as teachers
Among animals
column2: chimpanzees are exceptional tool users. Different groups of chimpanzees use different types of tools—and likewise
column3: researchers have suggested the teaching process might be customized to facilitate these local skills.

column1: In this study
column2: researchers examined the transfer of tools between chimpanzees during termite gathering
column3: and compared the population in the Goualougo Triangle
column4: Republic of Congo
column5: with the population in Gombe
column6: Tanzania.

column1: Termites and other insects are a valuable source of fat and protein in the diet of wild chimpanzees and also contribute important vitamins and minerals. Termites build complex nest structures that encompass a network of below-ground chambers
column2: sometimes topped with a towering
column3: freestanding mound reaching several meters high.

column1: Chimpanzees in both locations use fishing-probe style tools to harvest termites
column2: but Goualougo chimpanzees use multiple
column3: different types of tools sequentially. They also make tools from specific plant species and customize fishing probes to improve their efficiency.

column1: The researchers found differences in the rate
column2: probability
column3: and types of tool transfer during termite gathering between these two populations.

column1: At Goualougo
column2: where the fishing tasks were more complex
column3: the rate of tool transfer was three times higher than at Gombe
column4: and Goualougo mothers were more likely to transfer a tool in response to a request. Further
column5: mothers at Goualougo most often responded to tool requests by actively giving a tool to offspring.

column1: Such active transfers were never observed at Gombe
column2: where mothers most often responded by refusing to transfer tools. Given that offspring in both populations made comparable requests for tools
column3: these differences suggest that mothers at Goualougo were in fact more willing to provide tools.

column1: “We have previously documented that tool transfers at Goualougo function as a form of teaching
column2: ” says Crickette Sanz
column3: associate professor of biological anthropology at Washington University in St. Louis. “The population differences we observed in the present study suggest that teaching may be related specifically to the demands of learning to manufacture tools at Goualougo
column4: where chimpanzees use multiple tool types
column5: make tools from select plant species
column6: and perform modifications that increase tool efficiency.”

column1: “An increased role for this type of social learning may thus be an important component of the transmission of complex tool traditions over generations
column2: ” she says.

column1: “While Gombe and Goualougo chimpanzees both fish for termites
column2: we suspected that there might be differences in how this skill is acquired
column3: ” says Elizabeth Lonsdorf
column4: associate professor of psychology at Franklin & Marshall College. “But only after many years of accumulating these data were we able to rigorously quantify these differences.”

column1: “To date
column2: prosocial helping in chimpanzees has been principally examined in captivity or using differing methods in the wild
column3: ” says Stephen Ross
column4: director of the Lester E. Fisher Center for the Study and Conservation of Apes at Lincoln Park Zoo. “This study provides novel evidence for helping behavior in wild chimpanzees and demonstrates that chimpanzees can help flexibly depending on context.”

column1: Passing it on
Understanding how chimpanzees pass on tool traditions over generations can provide insights into the evolutionary origins of complex cultural abilities in humans.
“Human evolution is characterized by the emergence and elaboration of complex technologies
column2: which is often attributed to our species’ aptitude for passing skills onto one another through mechanisms such as teaching and imitation. However
column3: the evolutionary origins of these capacities remain unclear
column4: ” Musgrave says.

column1: “Our research shows that the human propensity to assist others in acquiring complex skills may build at least in part upon capacities that we share with our closest living relatives.”
Conservation efforts are fundamental to this research and future studies. “Chimpanzees and their cultures are endangered
column2: ” says Emma Stokes
column3: director of the Central Africa Program at the Wildlife Conservation Society.

column1: “Recent research shows that human activity imperils the survival of chimpanzee cultures. Studying our closest living relatives offers a unique opportunity to gain insights into the evolutionary origins of cultural behavior—but this privilege depends on long-term efforts to conserve these apes and their habitats.”
Additional researchers are from Washington University in St. Louis

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Introducing Rakewell
column2: Apollo’s wandering eye on the art world. Look out for regular posts taking a rakish perspective on art and museum stories

column1: When the art of Congo the chimpanzee was first exhibited in London in the 1950s – at the ICA
column2: among other venues – it immediately won fans. His first collectors included Miró and Picasso
column3: as well as the Duke of Edinburgh. Now a new generation of collectors have the opportunity to acquire a sample of Congo’s unique brand of ‘lyrical abstract expressionism’
column4: as one critic has called it. The zoologist and Surrealist painter Desmond Morris is selling off his collection of paintings and pastels by the chimp
column5: in an exhibition opening this December at the Mayor Gallery.

column1: While researchers have made plentiful attempts to get animals to paint – and there’s even an online gallery selling the endeavours of elephants – few other undomesticated creatures have managed to follow Congo in igniting their artistic spark. Rakewell wonders whether their milieus haven’t been sufficiently creative – unlike that of the pets of artists such as William Wegman
column2: who in a recent interview with the Guardian waxed lyrical about his canine collaborators: his dressed-up Weimaraners. ‘Really serious and so concentrated and funny
column3: ’ Wegman said of his first dog
column4: Man Ray. When the dog started getting older
column5: Wegman stopped photographing him
column6: and ‘He’d come into my studio and just slump down on the floor
column7: like

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"On a sunny day in early August 2019
column2: screams broke the calm of a national park in East Africa. Researchers ran to find Kidman – an adult female chimpanzee – and her child being attacked by the dogs of poachers. In their desperate attempt to save them
column3: the researchers fought off the dogs and removed a spear that poachers had lodged in Kidman’s back. She died shortly after the researchers had arrived
column4: her infant a few days later.

column1: Primatologists around the world were in awe of the researchers’ heroic efforts
column2: but we were also shocked that such a vicious attack could happen on the Ngogo apes of Kibale Forest in Uganda – one of the world’s best-known community of chimpanzees in one of Africa’s most famous national parks.

column1: Less than two months later
column2: tragedy struck again. On September 13
column3: less than 1
column4: 000km south of Kibale Forest in the Issa Valley of Tanzania
column5: researchers found another two chimpanzees being attacked by dogs. Kitu
column6: a two-year old infant
column7: was mauled by four dogs while her mother
column9: fought another six. The Issa chimpanzees live outside of national park boundaries and only became accustomed to human presence in 2018.

column1: The researchers beat the dogs back
column2: killing one and badly wounding the others. By the time the last dog limped away
column3: Kila was bleeding badly and couldn’t stand. Kitu called despondently from a few trees away
column4: but Kila didn’t look in her direction as she sat struggling to breathe. Eventually she recovered enough to stand and walk through the forest. Our team decided to stay with Kitu
column5: monitoring the infant chimp
column6: and assumed that Kila would return for her in time. They left her late in the day
column7: with no sign of Kila.

column1: Caroline Fryns/GMERC
column2: Author provided

column1: Like humans
column2: infant chimpanzees nurse through the first years of their lives and rely on their mothers for transport and safety to show them what is safe to eat – and who is an ally and who an enemy. While chimpanzees often adopt orphans in their community
column3: we knew Kitu was too young to survive long without Kila.

column1: The next morning
column2: the team found Kitu not far from where they had left her
column3: having travelled in the same direction as her mother the previous day. She was on the ground and seemed to have slept there – something chimpanzees rarely do when they live around predators. They’ve never been observed doing this at Issa. She could only muster groans
column4: too weak to call. She died a few hours after the researchers found her
column5: less than 24 hours since the dog attack.

column1: Chimpanzees led researchers to a feeding tree four days later
column2: under which lay Kila
column3: dead from her injuries.

column1: Scientists on the frontline
Chimpanzees and their cultures are under threat across Africa. Their forest habitats are being converted to farmland while human-transmitted diseases proliferate and decimate populations.
Chimpanzees are also hunted for the bushmeat trade – likely the single most acute threat to their survival in the wild. At Ngogo and Issa
column2: it’s probable that bushmeat hunters were the culprits.

column1: Combined
column2: these threats have pushed chimpanzees onto the IUCN red list of endangered species. In some parts of Africa
column3: chimpanzee populations have declined by 80% since 1990.

column1: Scientists are often forced into being advocates for the species they study – those who study primates often more so than others
column2: simply because we share so much in common with our evolutionary cousins. To protect chimpanzees from the many threats to their survival
column3: we often risk our own safety. Researchers at Issa advise armed patrols and support these teams when in the forest.

column1: Though we couldn’t save Kitu and Kila
column2: the mere presence of researchers here helps protect chimpanzees. Besides collecting data on them
column3: we monitor the forest for other wildlife
column4: including leopards and antelope. We keep an eye on threats such as illegal logging and sponsor Tanzanian postgraduate students – the next generation of chimpanzee researchers.

column1: Caroline Fryns/GMERC
column2: Author provided

column1: In all this
column2: we work closely with the district government
column3: and the Tanzania Wildlife Research Institute (TAWIRI)
column4: a government research body that oversees all research in the country. TAWIRI expends tremendous effort to protect Tanzania’s chimpanzees
column5: recently publishing a national conservation action plan.

column1: We were too late to save Kila and Kitu
column2: but as great ape scientists and conservationists
column3: we’re determined to protect their community. If you would like to help us
column4: please consider contributing to our cause. Our project - GMERC - has a registered non-profit sister group based in California that can receive your support – every dollar
column5: euro
column6: and pound which will go directly to facilitating anti-poaching patrols. column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Western chimpanzees are adapting to survive in severely degraded habitat
column2: a new study says.

column1: However
column2: the study also finds the abundance of western chimpanzees in Sierra Leone is impacted by even secondary roads.

column1: Ensuring the long-term survival of western chimps calls for changes in agriculture
column2: roads and other development
column3: researchers say.

column1: A new study of western chimpanzees in southwestern Sierra Leone finds they are adapting to survive in severely degraded habitat. But researchers say this doesn’t obviate the need to minimize the impacts of development such as roads and promote less-damaging approaches to farming by local people.
Despite the gradual loss of most of their original habitat
column2: the chimpanzees in Moyamba district have survived thanks to a particular set of conditions
column3: according Tatyana Humle
column4: a senior lecturer in conservation and primate behavior at the University of Kent
column5: U.K.
column6: and one of the authors of the study.

column1: “In this case
column2: the main driver of forest loss in the locality is slash and burn agriculture which has taken place over generations
column3: and some key natural resources remain in the landscape
column4: ” Humle told Mongabay. “The study area is dominated by semi-domesticated oil palm: the oil palm is native to West Africa
column5: and people tend not to cut them down as they are also useful to people for the fruit
column6: palm leaves for construction materials
column7: and local wine production.”

column1: Oil palm (Elaeis guineensis) is a key species for the chimpanzees
column2: which typically build a new nest every night: in the study area
column3: all the nests were built in oil palms in the absence of other mature nesting tree species. Another tree species usually spared by farmers because they eat the fruit is the Guinea plum (Parinari excelsa); the plums are also a preferred food item for chimpanzees.

column1: The relatively small human settlements in the area and local tolerance for the chimps’ presence are also key factors. “[People] do not persecute or kill the chimps out of fear or because they forage on their crops — which chimpanzees do in this study area
column2: probably because wild food resources are limited
column3: ” Humle said.

column1: Chimps in the anthropocene
The western chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes verus) is today found in eight West African countries
column2: with the greatest numbers found in Guinea
column3: Liberia and Sierra Leone. The subspecies vanished from parts of its historic range in Benin
column4: Burkina Faso and Togo during the 20th century. Today
column5: it is all but extinct in Ghana
column6: and populations in Côte d’Ivoire have also declined sharply in recent decades.

column1: Sierra Leone is home to perhaps 10 percent of the 53
column2: 000 western chimpanzees still in the wild; more than two-thirds of that number live outside of the country’s protected areas.

column1: Western chimps are found in a variety of habitats
column2: including savanna grasslands and dense rainforest. But habitat loss across their range due to expansion of human populations and agriculture
column3: mining and development of infrastructure
column4: is the principal threat to the survival of the subspecies. Combined with diseases such as Ebola and the hunting of the apes for bushmeat and traditional medicine — or in retaliation for the animals’ raids on crops — destruction or degradation of habitat has seen western chimp numbers crash
column5: placing them on the IUCN’s Red List of critically endangered species.

column1: Researchers from the Autonomous University of Barcelona
column2: Spain’s Institute of Game and Wildlife Research
column3: the University of Kent
column4: and Sierra Leone’s Tacugama Chimp Sanctuary set out to investigate how anthropogenic factors (roads
column5: settlements
column6: abandoned settlements and human presence) and available habitat (swamps
column7: farmlands and mangroves) affected the abundance of chimpanzees in Moyamba.

column1: In this part of the country
column2: the original forest has largely been replaced with active and abandoned farmland and stands of semi-wild oil palms; the district is lightly veined with unpaved roads and some relatively undisturbed areas of swamps and mangroves remain. It is a common pattern across West Africa’s forest zones
column3: where a mosaic of farmland
column4: fallow land and remnant forest has become the dominant landscape as human population growth
column5: industrial agriculture and urban expansion encroach on natural habitat.

column1: The team set up 24 infrared camera traps in farmlands
column2: swamps and mangroves across the district during an eight-month period between 2015 and 2016
column3: and captured about 75
column4: 000 images.

column1: As expected
column2: the camera trap data showed Moyamba’s chimps preferred to stay close to swamps and tended to avoid roads. But contrary to expectations
column3: chimpanzees’ abundance appeared unaffected by human presence or settlements
column4: be it used or abandoned. The primates were captured on camera in locations close to human settlements
column5: sometimes carrying domesticated fruits like pineapples and mangos. However
column6: the chimps foraged these sources of nutritious food early in the mornings and late in the day
column7: appearing to time their visits to avoid contact with humans who were active in the same areas at midday.

column1: The chimpanzees’ avoidance of the district’s roads stood out for several reasons.
Earlier studies in Central Africa (where a different subspecies of chimpanzee lives) suggested that chimps’ abundance was negatively affected only by the presence of tarmacked main roads
column2: wider than 15 meters (50 feet)
column3: and relatively heavy traffic. But the study in Moyamba district found that chimpanzees avoided even the unpaved secondary roads here.

column1: “This has a major implication when it comes to road infrastructure development
column2: which is predicted to increase significantly in the coming years across Africa
column3: including West Africa
column4: ” Humle said.

column1: Other researchers in the field express similar concerns.
“This paper highlights that we need to better understand the impact of infrastructural development
column2: such as roads
column3: on chimpanzee distribution and behaviour
column4: especially in light of the future road development across West Africa. It’s unlikely to be good news
column5: ” Kimberly Hockings
column6: a conservation scientist at the University of Exeter
column7: who was not involved in the new study

column1: Hockings
column2: whose research focuses on interactions between human and nonhuman great apes
column3: said this and other research showing how some chimpanzee populations live in proximity to humans under certain conditions in no way justifies further destruction of ape habitat. “This needs to be made crystal clear
column4: ” she said.

column1: The sensitivity of Moyamba’s chimps to even secondary roads has implications for governments in Sierra Leone and elsewhere in Africa
column2: a region seeking to rapidly build much-needed infrastructure. Such infrastructure development can increase loss of habitat
column3: as well as chimpanzee mortality
column4: either directly through road kill or indirectly by enabling poaching
column5: the study said.

column1: Alongside care in planning infrastructure development
column2: the research team would like to see local communities set aside areas in which fruiting trees
column3: such as wild figs
column4: can regenerate. “This could potentially help reduce chimpanzees reliance on crops for food. These areas would also benefit people when it comes to medicinal plants and other useful resources which they acknowledge are longer available due to forest loss
column5: ” said Humle.

column1: “If we want to secure their long-term survival
column2: it is crucial that successful protection measures should benefit people and chimpanzees alike
column3: ” Humle said. “Conservation actions should focus on education and helping farmers to implement alternative agricultural methods to slash and burn farming and environmentally-friendly revenue generating activities to ensure coexistence between the two species.”

column1: Long-term solutions
Sierra Leone’s government says it is stepping up efforts to protect the chimpanzee. In March
column2: it declared the western chimpanzee the country’s national symbol and promised to open two new sanctuaries for them.

column1: But with the majority of the country’s chimpanzees living outside of protected areas
column2: the creation of new refuges may be missing the point.

column1: Lincoln Larson
column2: an expert on human-wildlife interactions and conflict at North Carolina State University
column3: U.S.
column4: argues that with the huge expansion of humankind’s ecological footprint
column5: animals are forced to adapt or perish.

column1: “This might mean occupying
column2: and in some cases even thriving
column3: in land dominated by human infrastructure
column4: ” he told Mongabay. “The chimps in Sierra Leone
column5: the leopards in Mumbai
column6: and the mountain lions in Los Angeles are all good examples of this.”

column1: Species may change their behavior
column2: patterns of activity
column3: and even their diets to survive in human-dominated landscapes. But
column4: Larson cautions
column5: the consequences of these changes are unknown. “Confining wildlife to protected areas and/or waiting – hoping – for animals to adapt when they venture outside of parks are not viable ecologically or socio-economically viable options
column6: ” Larson says.

column1: “To achieve coexistence
column2: we must be proactive. We must search for creative solutions that support local livelihoods and community develop while simultaneously achieving conservation goals. And we must craft interventions that culturally compatible with the context in which a conflict emerges. All species might be at a crossroads at this point in time
column3: but it is humans who determine where the path forward might lead.”

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Chimpanzees dancing a 'conga' could hold the secret to the evolution of human dance and how people learnt to respond to rhythm
column2: researchers claim.

column1: Psychologists from the University of Warwick studied the movement of a pair of chimpanzees called Holly and Bahkahri at Saint Louis Zoological Park in Missouri
column2: US
column3: that showed them moving in sync.

column1: The team then found other videos online showing similar 'dance-like' behaviour in chimps which is similar to a human conga-line.
The chimps' synchronised body movements
column2: seemingly for no other reason than an expression of emotion
column3: could reveal clues about how - and why - humans started to dance
column4: according to Dr Adriano Lameira from the University of Warwick.

column1: Researchers say the levels of motor co-ordination
column2: synchrony and rhythm between the two matched the levels shown by orchestra players performing the same musical piece.

column1: Scroll down for video
A pair of chimpanzee females called Holly and Bahkahri have been 'dancing' at St Louis Zoo for a number of years. They walk around the enclosure in perfect sync (pictured)
Researchers found that the chimps were able to move in sync for an extended period of time with each of the pair taking it in turns to 'lead'
The team started their study by watching the movement of two chimpanzees in a video filmed at Saint Louis Zoological Park in Missouri
column2: USA.

column1: In the video you can see two chimps moving in sync one foot at a time while carrying a bag between their legs to the sound of a shaker making a beat.
They walk around the enclosure in perfect harmony with the rear chimp holding on to the first with one arm while the other holds the bag or hangs by its side.
In the video (seen here in a screenshot) you can see two chimps moving in sync one foot at a time while carrying a bag between their legs to the sound of a shaker making a beat
'The newly described behaviour probably represents a new form a stereotypy in captivity in this great ape species'
column2: researchers confirmed.

column1: They said the behaviour also forces scientists interested in the evolution of human dance to consider new conditions that may have started 'the emergence of one of human’s most exuberant and richest forms of expression'.

Their enclosure has an outside area of several thousand square foot of space and a range of different climbing structures. They are surrounded by rocky cliffs. The pair (pictured) were born in the same year - 1998
'Dance is an icon of human expression'
column2: said Dr Lameira
column3: from the Department of Psychology at the University of Warwick.

column1: 'Despite astounding diversity around the world's cultures and dazzling abundance of reminiscent animal systems
column2: the evolution of dance in humans remains obscure.

column1: 'Dance requires individuals to interactively synchronise their whole-body tempo to their partner's
column2: with near-perfect precision
column3: this explains why no dance forms were present amongst nonhuman primates.'

column1: He said this new research could help researchers reconstruct the earliest 'proto-stages' of human dance.
'This is evidence for conjoined full-body rhythmic entrainment in great apes that could help reconstruct possible proto-stages of human dance is still lacking.'
The two chimpanzees in the original video that sparked this study into dance and synchronised movement were called Holly and Bahkahri.
They were both born in 1998 at different zoos then transferred to St Louis one day apart in the same year when they were less than four months old.
'The behaviour exhibited by Holly and Bahkahri may have developed at the St Louis Zoo
column2: where the two females have lived throughout virtually all their lives
column3: although the exact timing of the behaviour’s inception is uncertain'
column4: says Dr Lameira.

column1: Their enclosure has an outside area of several thousand square foot of space and a range of different climbing structures. They are surrounded by rocky cliffs.
While the zoo used to display chimpanzee entertainment shows until 1982
column2: researchers say this had no bearing on the conga dance.

column1: 'The development of the behaviour in Holly and Bahkahri was not
column2: therefore
column3: the result of human training by caretakers or staff as they arrived at the zoo 16 years later after such performances ceased.'

column1: They say dancing chimps provide tentative empirical evidence for evolutionary history of human dance - which may have been rooted in mechanisms of social cohesion among small groups that might have granted stress-releasing benefits. Holly and Bahkahri are pictured here demonstrating their dance
The team were able to find 23 videos showing the same pair of chimpanzees 'dancing' at St Louis between October 2011 and April 2015.
The researchers say that by studying videos they found that synchronisation between individuals was non-random and predictable.
They found that the chimpanzees movement was maintained with instantaneous centi-second precision and jointly regulated.
The individual chimps were also taking turns as 'pace-makers' in the 'dance'.
Researchers say the 'conga-line' chimps found in Missouri is the 'first case of spontaneous whole-body entrainment between two ape peers'.

They say this provides tentative empirical evidence for evolutionary history of human dance - which may have been rooted in mechanisms of social cohesion among small groups that might have granted stress-releasing benefits.

The research has been published in the journal Scientific Reports.";Chimpanzee 'conga' sheds light on how early humans learnt to respond to rhythm and move in sync;https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEAFa5FLnnAtruMLCML560w4qGQgEKhAIACoHCAowzuOICzCZ4ocDMPX1qQY?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2019/12/12/11/22150462-0-image-a-112_1576151745167.jpg;12/12/2019;"[{'sent': 'Psychologists from the University of Warwick studied the movement of a pair of chimpanzees called Holly and Bahkahri at Saint Louis Zoological Park in Missouri
