column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"This story first appeared in the August 1963 issue of National Geographic magazine.
Up on the mountains the midday sun glared fiercely
column2: but down in the valley near the swift-running stream it was cool and still. I stood listening until I heard a faint rustling of leaves—the only sound to betray the presence of the group of chimpanzees I was trying to approach.

column1: Slowly and quietly
column2: but making no attempt to hide
column3: I moved toward the great apes until I was only 30 feet away. As I sat down
column4: they watched me
column5: staring rather hard
column6: and a young female who had been lying on the ground climbed a little way up a tall fig tree.

column1: View Images David Greybeard
column2: a wild chimpanzee
column3: gets a handout of bananas from author Goodall
column4: who studies the apes under a National Geographic Society grant. This scene near her camp represents a triumph for Miss Goodall; at first the animals fled if she came within 500 yards. Her knapsack holds a camera and notebook. She carries a whistle in her pocket to summon searchers in case of accident in the rugged Tanganyika hills. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column5: National Geographic

column1: One of the males stood upright to watch more closely. He was a superb specimen
column2: standing about four and a half feet in height
column3: his massive shoulders and bull neck suggesting the tremendous strength in his arms. He must have weighed a good 130 pounds
column4: and he was strong enough to snap with one hand a branch so tough that a man would be hard put to break it with two.

column1: Later I was to learn how it feels to be slammed on the head from behind by a large male chimpanzee
column2: but fortunately for me he did not continue his attack.

column1: After a moment or two
column2: the group stopped looking my way
column3: recognizing me for the strange hairless primate they had grown accustomed to seeing amid the other mountain fauna. The six adults rested on the ground or stretched out along the branches of a wild fig. Nearby
column4: four youngsters played quietly.

column1: View Images A bellicose youngster glares down from a fig-tree larder. Toes gripping a slender branch
column2: Spray stretches high to reach fruit-bearing sprigs. Thick side whiskers identify him and fellow troupers as the long-haired
column3: or eastern
column4: chimpanzee. This animal is about six years old. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column5: National Geographic

column1: I thought then
column2: as I always think when I am face to face with mature chimpanzees in their native forests
column3: of the striking difference between the wild apes and those in captivity. The chimpanzee imprisoned behind bars is bad tempered in maturity
column4: morose
column5: moody
column6: and frequently rather obscene; in his freedom he is majestic even when excited and
column7: for the most part
column8: dignified and good natured. (Discover how a captive orangutan learned a ""human way of life."")

column1: For about an hour I sat with the group. Then one of the males stood up
column2: scratched thoughtfully
column3: and moved off down the valley. One by one the others followed
column4: the infants riding astride their mothers’ backs like diminutive jockeys. The females and youngsters stared at me as they passed. The males scarcely glanced in my direction.

column1: Africa fulfills a life’s ambition
To be accepted thus by a group of wild chimpanzees is the result of months of patience. In England
column2: before I commenced my field study
column3: I met one or two people who had seen chimpanzees in the wild.

column1: “You’ll never get close to chimps—not unless you’re very well hidden
column2: ” they told me.

column1: View Images Gombe Stream Game Reserve spreads across 60 square miles of forested valleys and treeless ridges north of Kigoma
column2: Tanganyika. Chimpanzees on the reserve belong to the subspecies Pan satyrus schweinfurthi. Map by Irvin E. Alleman
column3: National Geographic

column1: At first it seemed they were right
column2: but gradually I was able to move nearer the chimpanzees
column3: until at last I sat among them
column4: enjoying a degree of acceptance that I had hardly dreamed possible.

column1: At this intimate range
column2: I observed details of their lives never recorded before. I saw chimpanzees in the wild hunt and kill for meat. Though this had been suspected
column3: nobody dreamed that a chimpanzee would attack an animal as large as a bushbuck
column4: until I saw an ape with his kill.

column1: Most astonishing of all
column2: I saw chimpanzees fashion and use crude implements—the beginnings of tool use. This discovery could prove helpful to those studying man’s rise to dominance over other primates.

column1: Chimps threatened by civilization
I cannot remember a time when I did not want to go to Africa to study animals. Therefore
column2: after leaving school
column3: I saved up the fare and went to Nairobi
column4: Kenya. There I was fortunate in meeting and working for Dr. Louis S. B. Leaky
column5: then curator of the Coryndon Museum. After a year
column6: Dr. Leakey asked me if I would undertake a field study of chimpanzees.

column1: Although the chimpanzee has been known to science for nearly three centuries
column2: and although
column3: because of its striking resemblance to man
column4: it has been used extensively as an experimental animal in medical and other fields
column5: no attempts had been made to study this ape in its natural habitat until Dr. Henry W. Nissen made his pioneer study in French Guinea. I found his 1931 report invaluable as I prepared my own program.

column1: The primary aim of my field study was to discover as much as possible about the way of life of the chimpanzee before it is too late—before encroachments of civilization crowd out
column2: forever
column3: all nonhuman competitors. Second
column4: there is the hope that results of this research may help man in his search toward understanding himself. Laboratory tests have revealed a surprising amount of “insight” in the chimpanzee—the rudiments of reasoned thinking. Knowledge of social traditions and culture of such an animal
column5: studied under natural conditions
column6: could throw new light on the growth and spread of early human cultures.

column1: Nineteen months after Dr. Leakey suggested the field study
column2: I had received funds for a preliminary investigation from the Wilkie Foundation
column3: Des Plaines
column4: Illinois
column5: which supports studies of man and other primates. I was ready to set out for a three-month visit to Lake Tanganyika region. The authorities were unwilling to allow a single European girl to go off into the bush by herself
column6: and so my mother accompanied me. (Read how Jane Goodall overcame gender barriers in her field.)

column1: Bumps and dust for 840 miles
From Nairobi it took us more than five days to reach the Gombe Stream Game Reserve in Tanganyika
column2: a 60-square-mile protected area set aside by the British where I would do my research. The Land-Rover was heavily overloaded
column3: and most of the 840 miles of earth roads were in terrible condition.

column1: View Images Pressure lamp glowing as lure
column2: Africans off the shore of the reserve harvest sardine-sized dagaa that they will sun-dry for market. Although the men may camp along the beach of the reserve
column3: game law forbids their going more than 60 yards inland. Lake Tanganyika is one of the world's deepest. At one point its bottom plunges 4
column4: 708 feet
column5: more than 2
column6: 000 feet below sea level. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column7: National Geographic

column1: Eventually
column2: after innumerable delays
column3: we reached Kigoma
column4: a small European settlement overlooking Lake Tanganyika. There I hired the government launch to take us on the last stage of the journey—the 16 miles up the lake to the Gombe chimpanzee reserve.

column1: Game Ranger David Anstey had arranged one of his semi-annual visits to the reserve to coincide with our arrival. As we traveled up the crystal-clear lake
column2: I studied the terrain where I was to work. The mountains rise steeply from the narrow beach and are broken by innumerable valleys and gorges. The valleys are thickly forested
column3: but the upper slopes become open woodland and many of the peaks and ridges are treeless. Most of the wild chimpanzees in Africa inhabit the dense rain forests of the Congo and west coast. The more open country of the Gombe Stream reserve is ideal for field study
column4: though behavior of apes living there might not be the same as that of apes in the dense forests.

column1: View Images William munches termites on a bit of vine. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column2: National Geographic

column1: Our talk as we sailed the lake was about chimpanzees
column2: and one of Ranger Anstey’s stories persuaded me that they can be dangerous when cornered.

column1: He told me of an African who decided to climb an oil-palm tree to cut down some nuts for cooking oil. A chimpanzee was high in the tree
column2: feeding on the nuts
column3: but the African failed to notice the animal until he had climbed well up the trunk. The ape
column4: intent on feeding
column5: only then saw the African
column6: started rapidly down
column7: and as he passed the man
column9: slashing away half his cheek and one eye as he did so.

column1: At about 2 o’clock on the afternoon of July 14
column3: we arrived at Kasekela
column4: a campsite midway along the 10-mile coastline of the reserve. The motor launch went back to Kigoma
column5: with orders to return for David a few days later. We found ourselves on the beach
column6: surrounded by untidy-looking crates and bundles
column7: together with the small boat and its outboard motor which would be our only link with civilization. Our permanent party numbered four: myself; my mother; Dominic
column8: our African cook; and Dominic’s wife. (Watch Jane Goodall reflect on her legacy and imagine what lies ahead.)

column1: Despair marks first field studies
As we set up camp that first day
column2: we found the heat almost intolerable
column3: but the big tent was soon pitched and everything bundled inside. I shall always remember David’s expression when he found that our only tableware consisted of a couple tin plates
column4: a cup without a handle
column5: and a thermos top! Indeed we were equipped with only the barest essentials
column6: and I think even Dominic was secretly shocked.

column1: During the first two months of my field studies
column2: I often despaired. Each dawn I set out alone
column3: following the little streams as I explored the valleys one by one
column4: forcing my way through the dense undergrowth or scrambling up the steep slopes. Sometimes I saw a group of chimpanzees feeding in a tree
column5: but seldom managed to get close before the shy apes moved away. Frequently I heard their noisy calling
column6: but usually they had moved off before I could catch up with them. Disheartened
column7: I trudged wearily back to camp each dusk.

column1: View Images Alone in ape country
column2: the author scans a hill for chimpanzees. Perched 1
column3: 500 feet above a precipitous valley
column4: 29-year-old Miss Goodall sights chimpanzees afar
column5: then moves in among them. Equipped with blanket
column6: flashlight
column7: tinned beans
column9: she often stays out alone all night to observe primate sleeping habits. She took her own picture by using a delayed exposure. Photograph by Jane Goodall

column1: But those early days
column2: however frustrating
column3: initiated me into the ways of mountain life. The forests no longer seemed hostile after I learned to creep along pig trails instead of forcing my way through the undergrowth. The slopes were no longer a nightmare when I had discovered the baboon trails where I could pull myself up the steepest parts by roots worn smooth by constant use. I became acquainted with other animals: troops of vervet and redtail monkeys; the beautiful red colobus monkey; the shy bushbuck; the fat ginger bush pig.

column1: One morning
column2: while walking along the lake shore
column3: I was approached by an excited fisherman who showed me a tree into which a bull buffalo had chased him the night before. “Huyu kali sana
column4: ” the man said. “He’s a bad one
column5: this fellow.”

column1: Indeed
column2: the tree was scored by innumerable gashes from the buffalo’s horns. Mostly
column3: however
column4: the small herds are wary and hard to approach.

column1: Once I did have to climb a tree
column2: when I met two crotchety old bulls along a narrow track. My climb to safety was speeded by memory of Dr. Leakey’s opinion of them.

column1: “I’d rather meet a rhinoceros or a lion any day. I am more frightened of the buffalo than of any other creature in Africa.”
Often I saw tracks of leopard
column2: or recognized its powerful feline smell
column3: and sometimes I heard the soft rasping of its hunting call. Many months later I saw one. He passed only a few yards away in the long grass
column4: and I felt slightly apprehensive. But when he winded me he turned silently away.

column1: One-girl camp set up near chimps
I never attempted to hide
column2: and gradually the animals became used to the strange pale-skinned primate that had invaded their territory. After about six months
column3: most of the chimpanzees would sit and look at me calmly at distances of 100 yards. At first they fled if they saw me within 500 yards.

column1: Three-quarters of an hour’s climb from camp
column2: I discovered a peak overlooking two valleys and many open grassy ridges and slopes—an ideal place for long-distance observation. From the peak I could locate a group and then try to get closer. I had a tin trunk carried up there
column3: with blanket
column4: electric torch
column5: a couple of tins of baked beans
column6: coffee
column7: and a kettle. When the chimps slept close by
column8: I stayed up in the mountains near them.

column1: So
column2: gradually
column3: I began to learn the basic behavior patterns of the chimpanzees
column4: and after six months I was able to pick out and name some individuals. When I saw Mike lazing in the sun
column5: for example
column6: or Count Dracula ambling past
column7: it was like meeting a friend.

column1: People often ask me how I choose such names for individual chimpanzees. My answer is that some names—such as Mrs. Maggs
column2: Spray
column3: and Mr. McGregor—simply come to mind. Strange as it may sound
column4: some chimpanzees remind me of friends or acquaintances in some gesture or manner and are named accordingly. (See the Gombe chimpanzee family album.)

column1: One chimpanzee had a pale
column2: flesh-colored face instead of the dark color common in adults. It gave me a slightly eerie feeling when I first saw him close to
column3: and ever after that he was “Count Dracula.”

column1: Study extended by society grant
When the three preliminary months came to an end
column2: the National Geographic Society took over sponsorship of my research and financed a further 20 months. My mother had to return to England
column3: but by then I was accepted by the authorities and so was allowed to stay on at the reserve. (Hear our editor's first impressions of Jane Goodall.)

column1: At this time I was joined by Hassan
column2: of the Kakamega tribe
column3: an African who had worked for Dr. Leakey for 15 years—a most responsible and reliable helper. He took over the little boat and the monthly trip to Kigoma for stores and mail. The trial period was over
column4: and I could settle down to building a closer contact with the apes.

column1: Chimpanzees are nomadic within their territory
column2: and they follow no fixed circuit. They have no regular sleeping trees. Most chimpanzees in the reserve—probably between 60 and 80 individuals—range
column3: at various times of the year
column4: over the whole 60 square miles
column5: and sometimes beyond the boundaries. The distance and direction of their wanderings—they may travel as much as eight or ten miles in a day—depend on the seasonal availability of the fruits
column6: leaves
column7: and blossoms that form the bulk of their diet.

column1: View Images Rainy weather routine: To escape the cold
column2: damp ground
column3: two mature males rest among branches in freshly built day nests
column4: but they make no effort to take shelter from the rain. In the dry season
column5: usually from May through September
column6: the animals prefer to nap in the shade of trees. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column7: National Geographic

column1: The chimpanzees during much of the year move about in small groups of three to six animals. Such a group
column2: I discovered from observation
column3: may consist of adult males and females
column4: of females and juveniles
column5: of males only
column6: or a mixture of sexes and ages.

column1: During the day two or three small groups may join and move about together for a few hours or a few days. In certain seasons
column2: mainly when some kind of favorite fruit is plentiful
column3: I have often seen as many as 25 chimpanzees together.

column1: What makes the social pattern so complicated is that the small groups are not stable. When two groups which have joined temporarily separate again
column2: there has frequently been an exchange of individuals. Males often leave the group they are with to move about alone
column3: subsequently joining another group or another lone male.

column1: This casual
column2: free-and-easy grouping makes it harder to recognize individuals
column3: yet it is essential to do so before one can even begin to understand the social pattern.

column1: View Images Suffering with a cold
column2: William turns in early. Apes often snack at bedtime. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column3: National Geographic

column1: From my mountaintop perch
column2: I observed how chimpanzees go to bed. Every night each one makes its own sleeping platform
column3: or nest—except for the small infants
column4: which sleep with their mothers until they are about three years old. (See how scientists are still using Jane Goodall's original research.)

column1: Treetops provide springy mattresses
The construction of a nest
column2: I found
column3: is simple and takes only a couple of minutes. After choosing a suitable foundation
column4: such as a horizontal fork with several branches growing out
column5: the chimpanzee stands on this and bends down a number of branches from each side so that the leafy ends rest across the foundation. He holds them in place with his feet.

column1: Finally he bends in all the little leafy twigs that project around the nest
column2: and the bed is ready. But the chimpanzee likes his comfort
column3: and often
column4: after lying down for a moment
column5: he sits up and reaches out for a handful of leafy twigs which he pops under his head or some other part of his body. Then he settles down again with obvious satisfaction.

column1: View Images Curled like a dog
column2: an ape dozes. He will vary sleeping positions
column3: but prefers the side. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column4: National Geographic

column1: One evening I sat quietly below a group of five chimpanzees that were feeding in a tree. There was Mrs. Maggs with her two offspring: little Jo
column2: about two years old; and Spray
column3: then about five. There was another mature female
column4: Matilda
column5: and a young male
column6: Hugh.

column1: Just before sunset there was excited calling as another male joined the group. Spray climbed down from the tree and ran up the slope to greet him. As they climbed the tree together
column2: I saw that the newcomer was Mr. McGregor
column3: an old male who had lost the hair from his sholders and was almost completely bald-headed—a rarity in chimpanzees.

column1: The group fed quietly until the sun had almost vanished behind the mountains across the lake
column2: and then Mrs. Maggs began looking for a place to make her nest. She tested the branches exactly the way a person tests the springs of a hotel bed. One by one
column3: the other apes began to make their nests.

column1: Drowsy mother cuddles little one
When the sun finally sank out of sight
column2: Mrs. Maggs was lying on her back in her completed nest. As the chill of night crept into the air
column3: little Jo ran to her mother
column4: who put out her arm and drew the young one close to the warmth of her body.

column1: View Images In a wilderness boudoir Miss Goodall lathers her blond hair with water pure enough to drink. Sedge crowds the rocky bed of Kakombe Stream
column2: a camp-side bath. Shallow rivulets course nearly all the cool
column3: humid valleys that cut through the reserve. The author reports that chimpanzees appear to ignore lake waters
column4: preferring to drink from streams. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column5: National Geographic

column1: Darkness fell swiftly and I climbed to my mountaintop lookout post
column2: opened a tin of beans
column3: and boiled my kettle over a little fire. The moon was nearly full
column4: and the mountains were beautiful and rather ghostly when I returned to the chimpanzees. I disturbed them as I settled down with my blanket about 50 yards away
column5: and they began to call out loudly
column6: alerting a troop of baboons sleeping in the valley below. The chimpanzees soon quieted down
column7: but the baboons went on barking for a long time.

column1: The chimpanzees slept soundly for the rest of the night
column2: but I was perched halfway down a steep slope with only a small tree to keep me from slithering into the ravine below. I was glad for the first glimmering of dawn.

column1: As it grew lighter I gradually made out the dark shape of Mrs. Maggs
column2: with Jo curled up beside her. Soon Jo sat up
column3: yawned
column4: and gazed about. Mrs. Maggs rolled over onto her back
column5: flung out an arm
column6: and also yawned. Jo jumped onto her chest
column7: leaned forward
column8: and pressed her face against her mother’s
column9: flinging her arms around her neck.

column1: Chimps awake in mood for fun
The other apes began to move. I could see Matilda sitting up in her nest and Spray feeding in a tree close by.
View Images Balky outboard plagues the author on 420-mile-long Lake Tanganyika
column2: her only route back to civilization. Storms sometimes send boats scurrying for shore. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column3: National Geographic

column1: Jo became restless. She climbed to a branch above the nest and hung down
column2: kicking and twisting from side to side. Her mother reached up and patted her
column3: pushing her to and fro
column4: until Jo
column5: delighted
column6: tumbled down on top of her. Mrs. Maggs
column7: her legs in the air
column8: bounced Jo up and down with her feet and then suddenly bent her knees so that Jo collapsed in a heap of waving arms and legs.

column1: The game went on for about ten minutes; then Mrs. Maggs suddenly sat up and peered through the branches. Matilda had left her nest
column2: and sounds below indicated that the others were moving away. Mrs. Maggs touched Jo
column3: who jumped to her at once
column4: clinging under her belly as the mother swung down from the tree.

column1: When a chimpanzee is born
column2: it is almost as helpless as a human baby
column3: save that it rapidly develops great strength in hands and feed
column4: enabling it to cling to its mother’s long hair as she travels from place to place.

column1: For the first four months the infant never leaves its mother
column2: but after this it begins to venture first a few feet and then a few yards away. It is still very unsure of itself
column3: and the mother is always ready to reach out should it lose its balance.

column1: Babies play like human children
By the time the infant is about a year old
column2: it has more confidence and spends hours playing gently
column3: hanging from a branch and patting at its toes
column4: or doing careful gymnastics on a branch. If two infants play together
column5: they pat out at each other or have a tug-of-war with a twig. Always the games are slow and gentle.

column1: By the time they are about two years old
column2: the little apes are very active and their playing far more adventurous. Whether they are swinging and leaping around in a tree or rolling over and over on the ground
column3: they never seem to be still for a minute.

column1: Their elders
column2: particularly the adolescents and the younger males
column3: are amazingly good-natured with them. I once watched little Fifi tormenting an adolescent male
column4: Figan. He was resting peacefully when Fifi hurled herself onto him
column5: pulling his hair
column6: pushing her fingers into his face
column7: biting his ears. She swung above him
column9: while he indulgently pushed her to and fro with one hand. Finally
column11: she flung herself down beside him.

column1: View Images With bored tolerance
column2: David endures grooming by the author. Discarded banana peels evidence his growing sophistication. When first offered the fruit
column3: he devoured skins and all. Now he drops peelings—but often guards them jealously. Photograph by Vanne Goodall
column4: National Geographic

column1: From the ages of about three years the young chimpanzee becomes more and more independent. Often it still moves around with its mother until it is five or six
column2: but it no longer rides on her back or sleeps in the nest with her at night. Games become rougher and wilder
column3: wrestling and chasing being the favorite sports.

column1: Occasionally a small infant tries to join in
column2: and then the older ones treat it with great consideration. I saw one youngster swinging an infant gently by one arm and then
column3: after peering down
column4: she dropped the little one to a leafy platform a few feet below. When the infant had difficulty in climbing up again
column5: she gave a helping hand.

column1: At about eight years
column2: the chimpanzee child attains puberty
column3: and during the next three or four years of adolescence it gradually takes its place in society. How long it might live
column4: no one can say pending further study
column5: but a good guess for average life span in the wild would be 40 to 50 years.

column1: Chimps express feelings in action
In this society
column2: relationships among the adult apes are more harmonious than had been assumed from observations of chimpanzees in captivity. Of course
column3: if you judged from sound alone
column4: you would imagine that wild chimpanzees were always fighting and quarreling. When two groups meet there is sometimes a fantastic cacophony as the males call loudly
column5: drum on tree trunks
column6: and shake branches
column7: while the females and youngsters scream and rush out of the way. But this is merely excitement and pleasure; with his highly emotional extrovert temperament
column8: the chimpanzee likes to express his feelings in action.

column1: When squabbles do arise
column2: often over the merest triviality
column3: they are usually settled by gestures and loud protest. Once I was watching a youngster feeding peacefully beside an adult male. By chance
column4: they both reached for the same fruit. The youngster immediately withdrew its hand
column5: but screamed loudly and “flapped out” at the male. The male screamed and flapped at the youngster. This went on for a few moments and then the quarrel ended
column6: neither ape having touched the other.

column1: View Images Cooperative endeavor to chew up a cardboard box belies a common notion that a dominant male always drives away lesser competitors. Meeting in the wild
column2: large groups call loudly
column3: screaming with excitement and drumming on trees
column4: but mingle without fighting. Here Goliath stands while William (left) munches and David ponders a bite. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column5: National Geographic

column1: Relationships between mature and adolescent males are particularly harmonious—they do not even fight over females! I once saw seven males in succession mate with a single female
column2: with no sign of jealousy or antagonism.

column1: As to mating in general
column2: chimpanzees in captivity breed all year round
column3: and it seems likely that this is the case in the wild
column4: because females appear receptive toward males during all months of the year. In addition
column5: I saw small infants in April
column6: June
column7: September

column1: During September and October
column2: however
column3: when the chimpanzees are frequently seen moving about in large aggregations
column4: excitement
column5: caused by this social stimulation
column6: does appear to have a very marked effect upon reproductive behavior. I saw the animals mating almost daily during these two months—spring in Tanganyika. Thus
column7: although it would appear that a certain amount of mating must take place throughout the year

column1: Mutual grooming plays an important role in the social life of chimpanzees
column2: and two friends
column3: or even a small group
column4: will sit quietly for hours searching through each other’s long black hair for specks of dirt
column5: grass seeds
column6: or ticks.

column1: Some students of animal behavior see in this grooming activity the first beginnings of true social and altruistic behavior in the whole animal kingdom.
Calls and gestures serve as language
I am often asked
column2: “Do chimpanzees have a language?” They do not
column3: of course
column4: have a language that can be compared with our own
column5: but they do have a tremendous variety of calls
column6: each one induced by a different emotion.

column1: The calls range from the rather low-pitched “hoo” of greeting
column2: and the series of low grunts that is heard when a chimpanzee begins to feed on some desirable food
column3: to the loud
column4: excited calls and screams which occur when two groups meet.

column1: View Images Balancing in a tree
column2: apes groom each other. Remarkably free of fleas
column3: these chimps pick out seeds
column4: dirt
column5: burrs
column6: and ticks. Among adults
column7: mutual grooming takes as much as two hours of leisure time daily. Photograph by Jane Goodall

column1: One call
column2: given in defiance of a possible predator
column3: or when a chimpanzee
column4: for some reason
column5: is angry at the approach of another
column6: can be described as a loud “wraaaah.” This is a single syllable
column7: several times repeated
column8: and is one of the most savage and spine-chilling sounds of the African forest.

column1: Another characteristic call is a series of hoots
column2: the breath drawn in audibly after each hoot
column3: and ending with three or four roars. This is the cry of a male chimpanzee as he crosses a ridge. It seems to be an announcement to any other chimpanzees that may be in the valley below: “Here I come.”

column1: These calls
column2: while they are not a language in our sense of the word
column3: are understood by other chimpanzees and certainly form a means of communication.

column1: In addition
column2: chimpanzees communicate by touch or gesture. A mother touches her young one when she is about to move away
column3: or taps on the trunk when she wants it to come down from a tree. When a chimpanzee is anxious for a share of some delicacy
column4: he begs
column5: holding out his hand palm up
column6: exactly as we do. He may pat the branch beside him if he wants a companion to join him there. When two animals are grooming each other and one feels that it is his turn to be groomed
column7: he often reaches out and gives his companion a poke.

column1: Once
column2: when three males were all grooming one another
column3: I saw a female going round poking at each of them in turn. But she was completely ignored—and so sat down sadly and groomed herself!

column1: There are also many gestures of greeting and friendship. Sometimes when two friends meet after a separation
column2: they fling their arms around each other in a delighted embrace.

column1: View Images Prey clamped in teeth
column2: a meat-eating ape hurries to cross an exposed ridge. Chimpanzees in the Gombe region kill game for food
column3: Miss Goodall found
column4: thus upsetting a widely held belief that wild chimps eat no meat. This one
column5: uneasy in open ground
column6: flees with the remains of a colobus monkey. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column7: National Geographic

column1: Despite this fairly well-developed system of communication
column2: a chimpanzee suddenly confronted with danger gives no alarm call to warn his companions
column3: but simply runs off silently.

column1: Defiant glares greet visitor
This was the way the apes initially reacted to my presence
column2: but after a few months fear replaced curiousity. Curiosity
column3: in turn
column4: changed to defiance. Then
column5: instead of running away or peering suspiciously at me
column6: some of the chimpanzees would climb into the trees and rock the branches
column7: glaring at me in silence.

column1: Those silent “displays
column2: ” as modern scientific zoologists call them
column3: were still tinged by fear
column4: and it was many months before the chimpanzees were sufficiently unafraid to react with real aggression. It happened for the first time when I was following a group in thick forest. The chimpanzees had stopped calling when they heard my approach
column5: and I paused to listen
column6: unsure of their whereabouts.

column1: A branch snapped in the undergrowth right beside me
column2: and then I saw a juvenile sitting siliently in a tree almost overhead
column3: with two females nearby. I was right in among the apes. I sat down. Then I heard a low “huh” from a tangle of lianas to my right
column4: but I could see nothing. Then came another “huh” behind me
column5: and another in front.

column1: Curiosity prompts an attack
For about 10 minutes these uneasy calls continued. Occasionally I made out a dark shape in the undergrowth
column2: or saw a black hand clutching a liana
column3: or a pair of eyes glaring from beneath black
column4: beetling brows.

column1: The calls grew louder
column2: and all at once a tremendous bedlam broke out—loud
column3: savage yells that raised the hair on the back of my neck. I saw six large males
column4: and they became more and more excited
column5: shaking branches and snapping off twigs. One climbed a small sapling right beside me and
column6: all his hair standing on end
column7: swayed the tree backward and forward until it seemed he must land on top of me. Then
column9: the display was over and the males began to feed quietly beside the females and youngsters.

column1: On one occasion I was actually hit by a chimpanzee in the wild
column2: but this was prompted by curiosity rather than aggression.

column1: View Images Disturbing sight—the crouching author—sends a big male scurrying. When startled
column2: chimpanzees clamber from trees and race off across the ground. A more courageous ape
column3: investigating Miss Goodall
column4: struck her. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column5: National Geographic

column1: I was waiting near a ripe fruit tree when I heard footsteps in the leaves behind me. Not wanting to startle the apes
column2: I lay down
column3: hoping that they would reach the fruit tree without seeing me. But the footsteps stopped
column4: and I heard small
column5: high-pitched sounds behind me: “Hoo! Hoo!” The inflection told me the chimpanzees were surprised or uneasy.

column1: I did not move
column2: and suddenly a mature male climbed into the tree above me and sat
column3: scarcely 10 feet over my head
column4: peering down at the strange object below. I think he was puzzled by my immobility and by the sheet of polyethylene protecting me from the rain.

column1: He worked himself into a rage
column2: hitting the trunk and shaking the branches. His small hoots became louder until
column3: with mouth wide open to show yellow canines
column4: he was uttering high-pitched
column5: choking screams of anger.

column1: Still I did not move. Through the corner of my eye I could see three others watching.
All at once the male disappeared
column2: and I heard him moving in the leaves behind me. There was silence and then
column3: with a loud scream
column4: he rushed forward and I felt the slam of his hand on the back of my head.

column1: The experiment had gone far enough—the fate of the African who had lost and eye and half his cheek in an encounter with an angry chimpanzee came to mind. Slowly I sat up
column2: and at last the ape realized exactly what I was. He moved away with his companions
column3: still brave from his passion
column4: calling out and drumming on the trees.

column1: Later I talked with Dr. Leakey about the incident—and was thankful I had made no sudden moves or cries that would have further enraged the chimpanzee.
“If you had waved your arms
column2: shouted
column3: or shown anger in any way
column4: ” he said
column5: “you might have been killed. He was merely testing to find out if you were an enemy or not.”

column1: Gradually
column2: during the months of my study
column3: the apes became less aggressive
column4: until finally I was greeted almost as another chimpanzee—sometimes by a show of excitement with hooting and shaking of branches
column5: and sometimes by a complete lack of interest.

column1: On the whole the chimpanzees merely tolerated me
column2: but one
column3: a mature male in the prime of life
column4: went a stage further
column5: and tolerance became friendship. David Greybeard—he deserves an article to himself.

column1: View Images Confirmed banana raider makes a getaway
column2: unmolested by lunching Africans. Enjoying the run of camp
column3: chimpanzees carry away blankets and clothing as well. David Greybeard
column4: boldest and friendliest of the apes that visit the author
column5: often enters tents
column6: peers under beds
column7: pulls out clothing
column8: and pokes through boxes to find hidden fruit. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick

column1: It was during the eighth month of my research
column2: when the fruit was ripe on one of the oil palms outside my tent
column3: that David paid his first visit to camp. Dominic told me about it when I got down from the mountains that April evening.

column1: The following day I learned he had called again
column2: and so I determined to wait in camp to try to see him. I recognized him at once from having seen him in the forest; he had always been particularly unafraid of me there.

column1: He visited camp almost every day for about a week
column2: and then the nuts were finished and he stopped coming.

column1: David provides a wonderful moment
When more palm nuts ripened
column2: however
column3: David again visited us. Even in those early days he sat feeding calmly while I walked about under the trees. I discovered that he liked bananas too and left a few out for him.

column1: Gradually he became tamer and tamer
column2: but it was not until the last five months that David showed complete confidence in his human friend. Two of the palms in camp were ripe
column3: so I got in a great supply of bananas and devoted myself to David for a whole week.

column1: After three days he actually took a banana from my hand. It was a wonderful moment. He was apprehensive when I held it out. He stood up and hit the trunk of a tree
column2: rocking slightly from foot to foot. But when he took the fruit there was no snatching—he was amazingly gentle from the first.

column1: Friends in the forest
column2: too

column1: After that I began carrying a couple of bananas with me up in the mountains
column2: and when I met David he would come up and take them
column3: sitting close beside me
column4: to the astonishment of his companions who gazed wide-eyed at the behavior of their fellow ape! Even when I had no bananas David would come to sit beside me for a moment
column5: with a soft “hoo!” of greeting.

column1: View Images Lower lip stuffed
column2: David Greybeard interrupts his dinner in camp to listen to the call of chimpanzees nearby. He sits in a relaxed position
column3: forearm on knee
column4: elongated hand dangling. Tough
column5: thickened skin on the knuckles attests the four-legged gain preferred by the apes. Divergent big toe
column6: useful for gripping
column7: helps him climb trees. White whiskers are no indicator of age; they often sprout on youngsters. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick

column1: Soon David began popping into camp any old day
column2: whether there was palm with fruit or not. Dominic and Hassan were both delighted and would describe David’s visits in detail when I returned from the mountains in the evenings. (Follow our photographer's journey with Goodall throughout Africa.)

column1: Best of all
column2: David began to bring two friends along
column3: Goliath and William. At first they were shy and watched from the safety of the trees
column4: but eventually the sight of David sitting and stuffing himself was too much for them
column5: and they rushed out to grab a share of bananas. Ultimately they became as tame as David
column6: and I was able to treat the three in a way few people would care to treat a mature chimpanzee in captivity.

column1: Clothing and blankets disappear
In addition to their love for bananas
column2: David and his friends had a passion for sucking material—old clothes and greasy cloths from the kitchen were the most sought after. David went off with a good many blankets
column3: as well as shirts and other garments
column4: and Goliath took many tea towels
column5: but it was William who was the real thief.

column1: William looked for things to steal
column2: and Dominic
column3: as soon as he saw him approach
column4: would rush off to protect the washing and watch over the tents.

column1: View Images Indulging a passion for chewing on cloth
column2: David absconds with the cook's blanket. To win the apes' friendship
column3: the author instructs her assistants to let them take whatever they want
column4: never to chase them—so they won't feel angry or frustrated. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column5: National Geographic

column1: But there were many days when William’s arrival went unnoticed
column2: and finally my wardrobe was reduced to one pair of shorts and two shirts. All my blankets had
column3: at some time or another
column4: been rescued from the trees where William had abandoned them.

column1: Chimpanzees show as much individuality as man himself
column2: and David
column3: Goliath
column4: and William have very different characters. David has an exceptionally calm disposition and an air of natural dignity. He takes life as it comes
column5: moving leisurely from place to place
column6: and is always trying to calm the excitable Goliath.

column1: Goliath
column2: with his massive shoulders and bull neck
column3: could easily be taken for a gorilla at first glance. He is wild
column4: impetuous
column5: and inclined to violence; all his movements are vigorous
column6: whether his is swinging down from a tree or charging off to meet a friend.

column1: His large size and uncertain temper make him well respected by other chimpanzees. When he leaps into a tree to join a group
column2: there are wild screams as the hitherto peaceful chimpanzees scatter in all directions. He is the only male I have seen actually attacking a female
column3: and on one occasion he even drove a young ape from its nest
column4: which he then appropriated
column5: bending in a few more branches and settling down with great satisfaction.

column1: Angry goliath brandishes ax
When I refused to give Goliath more bananas
column2: he became tremendously excited and rushed about slapping the ground or tearing off branches and waving them in the air. Once when I withheld the fruit
column3: he charged after Dominic’s wife
column4: seizing an ax that was lying nearby and brandishing it over his head. He probably had no intention of using it as a weapon. It was simply a means of expressing his frustration; he calmed down at once when I went up to him with a banana.

column1: View Images Shoulders hunched and lower lip drooping
column2: timid William emerges from five-foot-high sword grass. Dense growth
column3: soaked by an average of 40 inches of rain
column4: springs to 12 feet or more during the months-long wet season. In pursuit of ape troops
column5: Miss Goodall must push her way through such knife-edged stands
column6: sometimes taking to trees as do the animals she tracks. ""I'm becoming more and more arboreal
column7: she says. Photograph by Jane Goodall

column1: William—well
column2: William is just William. With his long
column3: scarred upper lip and his long
column4: drooping lower lip he is the clown of Chimpland. Yet he is a rather pathetic individual under his clownishness. In the early days when he sat watching David eat bananas and dared not approach
column5: he would rock himself quietly from side to side
column6: occasionally saying sadly
column7: “Hoo! Hoo!” Once or twice he was a little more active
column9: but he never gave a display like Goliath’s.

column1: Even in health William is a sad figure
column2: with his bony hips
column3: his broken finger
column4: his curled-up
column5: slightly deformed feet
column6: and his scars. Such scars and deformities are rare to my knowledge
column7: though I have seen other broken fingers.

column1: Once when William had a dreadful cold
column2: he slept in the same nest for three nights
column3: a most unusual procedure. Each night it poured rain
column4: and when he climbed down in the morning he was shivering violently
column5: and coughing and wheezing so that I longed to give him a hot toddy instead of a cold banana.

column1: Chimpanzees often call out if it rains during the night. They sit up in their nests
column2: hunched forward over their knees with heads bent down
column3: and wait until the rain stops. I never observed them attempting to make a shelter or take advantage of any natural one. (Hear Jane Goodall's concerns about the future of the Serengeti.)

column1: View Images Nesting chimpanzee seeks solace by chewing on a towel he stole from the author. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column2: National Geographic

column1: Rains make grass 12 feet tall
Rainfall in the Kigoma area is heavy
column2: and the rainy season
column3: which starts with the “short rains” in October
column4: carries on without a break into the “long rains
column5: ” which last until May.

column1: At the start of the short rains
column2: the mountains are at their most beautiful
column3: with green grass pushing up through the black volcanic soil
column4: and flowers
column5: many of them exquisitely lovely
column6: appearing overnight.

column1: Gradually
column2: however
column3: it becomes hard to move through the mountains. The grass
column4: razor sharp and always drenched by rain or dew
column5: shoots up to 12 feet or more all over the reserve
column6: and traveling along the overgrown tracks is no joke. Once I came within 10 yards of a bull buffalo who was lying down dozing. Luckily I was downwind and he never knew I was there.

column1: Keeping equipment dry is a never-ending battle. Water condenses in binoculars
column2: camera lenses mist over
column3: and everything is permanently thick with mildew.

column1: In addition
column2: when I am moving about through grass taller than my head
column3: it is difficult to see anything. In order to continue my observations
column4: I have to climb trees. Thus
column5: as the rainy season progresses
column6: my own habits become increasingly arboreal!

column1: December brings the departure of the last of the fishermen permitted in the reserve
column2: and my evening clinics
column3: which consist mainly of handing out aspirin
column4: Epsom salts
column5: antimalaria pills
column6: or adhesive tape to the inevitable visitors to camp
column7: are considerably reduced. These clinics
column8: started by my mother when we first arrived at the reserve
column9: were a tremendous help in establishing and maintaining friendly relations with the Africans.

column1: View Images Sick call at camp finds the author's mother
column2: Mrs. Vanne Morris-Goodall
column3: dispensing aspirin. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column4: National Geographic

column1: My most faithful patient was eight-year-old Jamanne. He always managed to think up some complaint
column2: and was happiest when he could produce a minute scratch and demand a strip of adhesive tape. But his chief delight lay in helping me
column3: handing out the medicine and explaining to the fishermen in the most superior manner how they should take it.

column1: During the rains the chimpanzees tend to go to bed earlier and get up later
column2: and when they rest during the day they often make themselves a day nest in a tree rather than lie on the cold
column3: damp ground.

column1: At these times infants still sleeping with their mothers at night make little nests as a sort of game
column2: and very instructive play it is. An infant of eighteen months finds it difficult to bend in even a couple of twigs; each time it reaches out for a second one
column3: the first springs up again. But by the time the young one is ready to sleep alone
column4: it has mastered the nest-making technique.

column1: Rain incited a violent ritual
Generally speaking
column2: chimpanzees become more active during the rains and often
column3: for no apparent reason
column4: a male will break into a run
column5: slapping the ground or hitting out at a low branch as he passes. This behavior
column6: when large groups are present
column7: may develop into a fascinating display which I have called the “rain dance.”

column1: View Images Leaping from trees and brandishing boughs
column2: apes charge downhill in a wild rain dance. Illustration by Walter A. Weber
column3: National Geographic

column1: I saw it on four occasions
column2: always about midday and always in similar terrain. In every instance it followed the same pattern
column3: but the duration varied from 15 to 30 minutes. It did not always take place in the rain
column4: but rain was falling hard the first time I saw it.

column1: I was watching a large group of chimpanzees
column2: 16 in all
column3: feeding and playing in a tree halfway up the opposite slope of a narrow ravine. Rain had been threatening all morning and finally it came down
column4: gently at first
column5: becoming gradually heavier.

column1: When the rain started
column2: the chimpanzees climbed down from the tree one by one and sat for a while on the ground before starting off up the grassy slope.

column1: They had divided into two groups
column2: with four large males in one group and three in the other. As they neared the ridge at the top
column3: one of the males suddenly turned and charged diagonally downward
column4: slapping the ground
column5: calling loudly
column6: and hitting at a tree as he passed. At once a male from the other group turned and began to run down the slope. Standing upright
column7: he tore a low branch from a tree
column9: and then dragged it behind him as he ran.

column1: Meanwhile the females and juveniles were climbing trees near the skyline to watch.
At the top of the slope another male stood upright
column2: rocking slightly from foot to foot
column3: his arms swinging
column4: working up momentum. Then he took away
column5: charging downward
column6: breaking off a great bough as he went. Two more set off
column7: calling wildly. One after the other they sprang up into a tree and
column9: hurled themselves some 25 feet to the ground
column10: tearing off branches as they fell and dragging them on their downward run.

column1: At the bottom
column2: each chimpanzee swung up into a tree to break his headlong rush. There he sat for a moment before climbing down to plod up to the top of the slope once more. Then
column3: with loud cries
column4: he was off again.

column1: Thunder roars above apes’ wild calls
All the time the rain pelted down
column2: harder and harder
column3: while lightning streaked across the leaden sky and crashing thunder almost drowned the wild calling of the apes. Against the new green grass they looked very black and huge—primitive
column4: hairy men displaying their strength.

column1: For about half an hour I watched; and then
column2: as suddenly as it had started
column3: the display was over. The spectators climbed down from their trees
column4: and one by one the chimpanzees wandered up to the ridge and disappeared over the top. The last male paused on the skyline
column5: looking back toward me with one hand on a tree trunk—the actor taking his final curtain. Then he
column6: too
column7: was gone.

column1: Rain seems to have more effect on some chimpanzees than others. Goliath in particular often gets very excited at the start of a rainstorm
column2: and once he did a fantastic dance all by himself
column3: swaying rhythmically from foot to foot
column4: tearing down huge branches
column5: and gradually becoming wilder and wilder. William
column6: who was sitting close beside him at the start
column7: paid absolutely no attention.

column1: View Images In friendly persuasion
column2: David nudges a restraining arm
column3: hoping to get at bananas in a hinged box
column4: the camp's only chimp-proof storage. Wild chimpanzees are normally gentle; this contrasts with the dangerously bad tempers many males develop in captivity. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column5: National Geographic

column1: David Greybeard is inclined to become truculent in the rain. Once during a thunderstorm
column2: when I was sitting on the banana box trying to prevent his taking all the fruit
column3: he came up and stood upright in front of me
column4: hooting loudly
column5: with one arm raised above his head. He then danced about
column6: hitting a tree
column7: the box

column1: Chimps and baboons sometimes clash
Occasionally a group of baboons gathers round David while he is eating bananas. Sometimes he ignores them
column2: but often
column3: and particularly when it is raining
column4: he chases them off
column5: swinging his arms and hooting.

column1: View Images Foil-wrapped baubles adorn a tropical Christmas tree. Balloons festoon the tent; baboon skull
column2: found and studied by the author
column3: tops the pole. Goliath
column4: who nested the night before almost overhead
column5: chooses a banana but disdains oranges. Palm-nut trees beyond the tent provides a chimpanzee staple. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column6: National Geographic

column1: The relationship between the chimpanzee and the baboon is complex and interesting. The ape is the larger and more powerful animal
column2: but the baboon is far more numerous and represents the chimpanzee’s only serious competitor for food.

column1: For the most part the two species tolerate each other
column2: and it is common to see baboon and chimpanzee feeding in the same tree. On the other hand
column3: I have seen a group of chimpanzees leap out of a tree at the approach of a baboon troop. On one occasion a fairly young male baboon climbed up into a palm where David and William were feeding and began to taunt William
column4: going up to him
column5: barking and hitting out at him. William hit back and the two fought for a moment. Then both chimpanzees climbed from the tree
column6: leaving the baboon in possession.

column1: Sometimes young male baboons chase after female and juvenile chimpanzees
column2: which rush away screaming. Often one or two male chimpanzees then join in
column3: chasing after the baboons
column4: which flee in turn. These mock battles seem to be a strange mixture of play and aggression. (See vintage photos of Jane's time in Gombe.)

column1: I once watched a troop of baboons teasing four adult chimpanzees—two males and two females. The male baboons insolently moved closer and closer to the apes—until
column2: all at once
column3: the latter seemed to lose their tempers.

column1: The males stood upright and charged at their tormentors
column2: swinging their arms over their heads. The females leaped to the low branches of a tree and
column3: leaning down
column4: screamed piercingly at the baboons below. I thought a real fight would take place
column5: but after a few moments the male chimpanzees returned from the chase
column6: and both apes and baboons walked peacefully on.

column1: It would seem that the chimpanzee and the baboon tolerate each other because each
column2: to some extent
column3: has respect for the other. But these happy relations do not exist between the chimpanzee and some of this smaller neighbors.

column1: Gombe chimpanzees eat meat

It will be a surprise to many to learn that the chimpanzee in the wild has definite carnivorous tendencies. It has always been suspected by scientists that wild chimpanzees might eat an occasional lizard or small rodent
column2: but no one thought these apes might kill fairly large animals.

column1: View Images Dining at a forest buffet
column2: David peels away the outer layer of reed and munches its juicy core. Plumed plant bears the local name mtele. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column3: National Geographic

column1: As far as I can determine
column2: the fact that they do so came to light for the first time during my research. This behavior may not be common to all races of chimpanzees in Africa
column3: but it is certainly true of those of the Gombe Stream Reserve.

column1: Monkeys seem to be a favorite item on the menu. I saw them eaten on four occasions
column2: and twice I found bits of bone in the chimpanzee droppings. In addition
column3: I once saw a young bushbuck eaten
column4: and another time a young bush pig. Four times the prey was unidentifiable.

column1: I saw chimpanzees eating meat several times before I actually saw them attack and kill. On that occasion the prey was a red colobus monkey. I was watching four of these monkeys resting in a tall
column2: leafless tree when suddenly a young chimpanzee climbed into a neighboring tree. He sat close enough to one of the monkeys to attract its attention
column3: yet not close enough to scare it away. Meanwhile another young chimpanzee bounded up the tree in which the monkey was sitting
column4: ran with incredible speed along the branch
column5: leaped at the colobus
column6: caught it with its hands
column7: and presumably broke its neck.

column1: Five other chimpanzees then climbed up
column2: including a mature male. But because an adolescent had made the kill
column3: the carcass was torn up and shared among the whole group
column4: with no fighting or quarreling.

column1: At other times
column2: however
column3: when the prey is in the possession of a mature male
column4: there is no such sharing. The others in the group show respect. They sit as close to the male as they can
column5: watching the meat with longing eyes
column6: holding out their hands palm uppermost in a begging gesture.

column1: William pays price for grabbing
The reaction of the male to his suppliants varies. Let me describe the time when Huxley was eating a young bushbuck. He was clasping the carcass with one arm
column2: and it was
column3: incidentally
column4: almost as big as himself! Presumably he had broken its neck
column5: just as other chimps had killed monkeys. In his free hand Huxley held a bunch of twigs and after each mouthful of meat he ate a few leaves—for all the world like a man with a lump of cheese and a stick of celery.

column1: Gathered close round Huxley
column2: and all begging
column3: were three other large males—J. B.
column4: Hollis
column5: and William. Several times Huxley tore off a piece of meat and put it into the outstretched hand of J. B. Once Hollis begged from J. B. and was rewarded with a small bloody splinter. When a youngster of about four years held out its hand
column6: Huxley
column7: after a moment
column8: very gently cuffed it on the head
column9: but a female with a tiny infant was allowed to feed from the carcass unmolested.

column1: View Images Camp raider proves a scientific point. Walking erect
column2: banana-loaded David dispels the belief that chimpanzees travel on all fours except when running. Even with arms empty
column3: the animals sometimes assumes an upright stance
column4: the better to see over surrounding vegetation. The author observed chimpanzees loading their arms with choice wild fruit
column5: then walking erect for several yards to a spot of shade before sitting down to eat. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column6: National Geographic

column1: The sight of this female tucking it in proved too much for poor old William
column2: who had been begging and begging in vain. He ventured to help himself to a bite. Evidently it was one thing for the mother to share in the spoil
column3: but quite another when William tried to join in. Huxley at once grabbed William and bit him
column4: at which J. B. came racing down and chased the screaming William from the tree.

column1: There was a good deal of yelling and crashing around in the undergrowth
column2: and then the two climbed back into the tree. They sat near Huxley
column3: who at once hit William four or five times
column4: after which J. B. did the same.

column1: Poor William tried neither to escape nor to retaliate. He simply sat there screaming and took his medicine. And then he reached out to touch the lips of his punishers in the gesture of appeasement
column2: and all was peaceful again. William was not forgiven
column3: however
column4: to the extent of a handout.

column1: Raw meat
column2: though obviously a great delicacy
column3: is only an occasional supplement to the chimpanzee’s diet. Whether the apes deliberately set out to hunt for meat
column4: or merely make kills because of opportunity
column5: remains undetermined. I suspect the latter.

column1: The bulk of the diet is
column2: of course
column3: vegetarian. I have collected 81 different types of vegetable foods eaten by chimpanzees
column4: of which half consist of fruits
column5: a quarter of leaves
column6: and the remainder of seeds
column7: blossoms
column9: and bark. (Follow one chimpanzee as he leaves a medical testing system.)

column1: Epic discovery reveals a tool-maker
In addition
column2: however
column3: the chimpanzees sometimes feed on insects—at certain times of the year fairly extensively. I have seen them eating termites
column4: two species of ant
column5: and two types of gall
column6: a tumorlike growth on a leaf in which the young gallfly lives. And it is this method adopted by the chimpanzees for feeding on ants and termites that probably represents the most important discovery in my two years of research.

column1: View Images Delicatessen item for the apes bulges from the underside of leaves. Larvae of the gallfly cause formation of the candylike growth. Holes remain after apes pick off the galls. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column2: National Geographic

column1: For a long time there has been heated discussion in scientific circles as to whether any primates in the wild ever modify natural objects to make tools. My chimpanzees have settled the argument for once and for all: The answer is that at least some chimpanzees do.
Termites form a major part of the chimpanzee diet for a two-month period. The termite season starts at the beginning of the rains
column2: when the fertile insects grow wings and are ready to leave the nest. At this time the passages are extended to the surface of the termite heap and then sealed lightly over while the insect awaits good flying weather. The chimpanzee is not alone in his state for termites—the baboon in particular has a fondness for the juicy insects
column3: but he must wait until they fly and then take his turn
column4: together with the birds
column5: at grabbing the termites as they leave the nest.

column1: The chimpanzee forestalls them all. He comes along
column2: peers at the surface of the termite heap and
column3: where he spies one of the sealed-entrances
column4: scrapes away the thin layer of soil. Then he picks a straw or dried stem of grass and pokes this carefully down the hole. The termites
column5: like miniature bulldogs
column6: bite the straw and hang on grimly as it is gently withdrawn.

column1: I have watched chimpanzees fish this way for two hours at a time
column2: picking dainty morsels from the straw and munching them with delight. When they don’t have much luck with one hole
column3: they open another and try again.

column1: As the straw becomes bent at the end
column2: the chimpanzee breaks off the bent pieces until the tool is too short for further use. Then it is discarded and a new one picked. Sometimes a leafy twig is selected
column3: and before this can be used the chimpanzee has to strop off the leaves.

column1: In doing so—in modifying a natural object to make it suitable for a specific purpose—the chimpanzee has reached the first crude beginnings of tool making.
Chimps carry tools on termite search
In this respect
column2: the chimpanzees do not always await the discovery of a termite nest before seeking a tool. I have seen them break off a twig and carry it for as far as half a mile
column3: going from one termite hill to another
column4: though none at the time was suitable for feeding.

column1: View Images With humanlike concentration
column2: a chimpanzee carefully feeds a length of vine into an opening it has made. The chimpanzee's short thumb prevents his bringing it and forefinger together in the precision grip so useful to man. As a substitute
column3: this ape clamps the stem between his thumb and side of the index finger. Photograph by Baron Hugo van Lawick
column4: National Geographic

column1: It is unlikely that this practice of fishing for termites is an inborn behavior pattern. Among higher primates
column2: behavior is found to depend more and more on learned techniques and les and less on “instincts.” It seems almost certain that this method of eating termites is a social tradition
column3: passed from ape to ape by watching and imitation. As such
column4: it must be regarded as a crude and primitive culture.

column1: We do not know yet if similar traditions have developed among other chimpanzee populations in Africa. The answer may throw interesting light on the spread and development of culture in early man.
Meat in diet poses questions
It is equally important to find out whether capture and eating of prey is common to all chimpanzees or peculiar to those of the Gombe Stream Reserve. Perhaps this is simply a local tradition
column2: in which case there is always the possibility that it might develop and eventually involve more elaborate hunting techniques.

column1: View Images Apes fishing for termites use stems as tools
column2: modifying them on the spot. The author established that wild chimpanzees share with humans the ability to modify natural objects and turn them to useful ends—a talent long believed to set mankind apart from all other creatures. Photograph by Jane Goodall
column3: National Geographic

column1: AT present these chimpanzees appear merely to take advantage of any good opportunity that presents itself for the killing of prey —as was perhaps the case with early man. It seems important that in the future recurring observations should be made of the meat-eating and hunting behavior of this chimpanzee population.
In the chimpanzee
column2: there is reason to speculate that over-specialization has not led to an evolutionary dead end
column3: as may be the case with the other great apes. Of course
column4: if the forests of Africa were cleared for agriculture
column5: the chimpanzee would not survive in competition with man. But if the forests gradually disappeared due to changing climate or similar causes
column6: I think it is interesting to conjecture that the chimpanzee
column7: with his primitive hunting and tool-using
column8: might have a chance of survival
column9: a chance of adapting himself to the new conditions. (Discover what happened to Jane Goodall after leaving Gombe.)

column1: There is still much to learn about the behavior of the free-ranging chimpanzee. I am returning to the Gombe Stream Reserve for a further six months
column2: and again with the generous support of the National Geographic Society. After that I hope to make behavior studies in other parts of Africa
column3: because
column4: until we have sufficient comparative data
column5: we cannot tell if the behavior of the Gombe Stream chimpanzees differs from those in other regions. Only after we have such data can we draw far-reaching conclusions about the way of life of the chimpanzee

There are a lot of things one can learn from animals - whether it’s their sense of brotherhood
column2: being empathetic or just sharing. Take for example this chimp and tortoise that can teach everyone a lesson on sharing. A video of the two beings from completely different species of the animal kingdom will give you a sense of calm in an otherwise complex environment.

column1: The clip shows a chimpanzee eating an apple. However
column2: after a few moments it feeds the apple to the tortoise near him. The heartwarming scene between the two is melting netizens’ hearts.

column1: “Give
column2: even if you only have a little
column3: ” reads the caption.

column2: even if you only have a little.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"
A HUMILIATED chimpanzee has been filmed riding around the world's most hated zoo on a bike while spraying anti-coronavirus sanitiser.
The animal was recorded at the controversial Samutprakarn Crocodile Farm and Zoo near Bangkok
column2: Thailand
column3: where bosses used the chimp to promote the work they are doing during the pandemic.

column1: ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news & updates
This poor chimpanzee was paraded around the zoo spraying anti-viral disinfectant Credit: Viral Press
The chimp spends most of his time chained to a wall or in a small cage according to investigators Credit: Viral Press
Shocking footage shows the intelligent animal wearing a surgical face mask
column2: denim shorts and an orange Hawaiian shirt while pedalling a children's bicycle with a tank strapped to the back spraying disinfectant.

column1: Animal rights investigators have previously documented more serious accounts of abuse at the zoo last year including animals being beaten with bamboo sticks.
The Samutprakarn Crocodile Farm and Zoo sparked outrage last December when footage emerged of a painfully thin elephant being forced to perform tricks for crowds.
This Thai zookeeper was filmed jabbing an emaciated elephant with a large spike Credit: AsiaWire
Tourists take pictures with heavily sedated wild cats Credit: Caters News Agency
Campaigners say that other ""attractions"" at the zoo include emaciated elephants being abused
column2: bears rocking nervously back-and-forth while stuck in filthy pools and malnourished crocodiles.

column1: Regarding the chimpanzee disinfecting the zoo
column2: farm director Uthen Yangpraphakorn said they had to keep the place clean to be ready to re-open as soon as the government eases Covid-19 coronavirus restrictions.

column1: Uthen said: ""We have been closed since the government orders about the virus
column2: so in the meantime
column3: we do not have much to do.

column1: Chai Yai
column2: the world's largest captive crocodile
column3: is ridden by the Managing Director of Sumatprakarn crocodile farm Charoon Yangprapakorn Credit: Reuters

column1: We clean the place two or three times a week in case the government will allow us to re-open
column2: so we are ready to start accepting visitors again.

column1: The chimp was also trained in the farm so we just brought him out to let him stretch his limbs during this inactive period.""
Thailand has so far declared 2
column2: 643 Covid-19 coronavirus cases and 43 deaths.

column1: The country has enforced strict measures to combat the pandemic including closing zoos and other businesses
column2: banning passenger flights
column3: imposing curfews
column4: sweeping travel bans and alcohol prohibition.

column1: The ape was led around the zoo on a bike in a Hawaiian shirt Credit: Viral Press
Animals weren't removed from their enclosures as they were sprayed down with potentially toxic chemicals Credit: Viral Press
The keeper can be seen dragging the chimp along with a tether attached to its waist Credit: Viral Press
Since the zoo came to light over the past few years
column2: campaigners have been trying their best to stop degrading practices like this in the zoo that has a history of animal abuse and have it closed down.

column1: Responding to the video of the chimp
column2: animal rights group PETA said the treatment was ''heartbreaking'' and described the zoo as a ''hell hole''.

column1: Spokesman Nirali Shah said: ''Places like Samutprakarn Crocodile Farm and Zoo are hellholes where animals like this chimpanzee endure miserable lives in captivity every single day.
''They are routinely mistreated and know little more than chains. When they're not used for human 'entertainment'
column2: they are held in cramped cages.''

column1: Despite multiple attempts by PETA to contact Samutprakarn
column2: the zoo's management has never responded.

column1: PETA submitted the investigative findings to the Thai police and lodged an official complaint with authorities
column2: urging them to inspect the zoo.

column1: More World News FORCED TO STRIP Air stewardesses turn to STRIPPING after being grounded by virus lockdown ‘I WAS SCREAMING’ Dad drops dead in front of wife after ‘drinking expired soft drinks’ JOB’S A GOOD UN Kim congratulates China for ‘success in preventing coronavirus spread’ HOME FREE Starving elephants in closed Thai tourist camps released back to natural homes ‘I WAS TERRIFIED’ Brit mum & baby quarantined for 7wks after jet diverted when labour began DOWNFALL Final days of Nazi Germany revealed in shocking pics as world remembers on VE Day
Animal rights groups have also pressured tour companies to stop taking holidaymakers to the enclosure just south of Bangkok.
Chinese firm Ctrip - Asia's biggest online booking agency that handles millions of holidaymakers a year - ditched the zoo in August 2019 and stopped selling tickets to the facility.
Yet despite mounting pressure the zoo continues to operate and animals are still held in appalling conditions.
The chimp was allegedly being taken around for 'exercise' Credit: Viral Press
The chimp was dressed in PPE including a mask that is known to restrict airflow Credit: Viral Press
The chimp was forced into a Hawaiian shirt Credit: Viral Press
The surgical mask placed over the animals face was part of the joke Credit: Viral Press

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"It’s a girl!
The Maryland Zoo in Baltimore welcomed a female baby chimpanzee last December.
Raven
column2: a 24-year old chimp
column3: became a first-time mom on Dec. 29. Zookeepers said the baby is her spitting image
column4: with fluffy black hair that covers most of the body.

column1: The baby spends most of her time cradled in Raven’s arms.
“The baby is gripping well and is very vocal
column2: ” Erin Cantwell
column3: the zoo’s mammal collection and conservation manager
column4: said in a statement.

column1: Baby chimps’ developmental milestones are similar to human babies
column2: and the baby’s keepers will monitor her successes
column3: including ability to hold her head up on her own
column4: using her fingers and toes to grasp things
column5: learning vocalizations and facial expressions
column6: and teething
column7: the zoo said in a news release.

column1: Raven is the second chimpanzee to give birth at the zoo recently. In July
column2: Bunny gave birth to Lola.

column1: Chimpanzee gestation is about eight months long
column2: and the zoo conducts prenatal care for the animals once there is a positive pregnancy test.

column1: Chimpanzees are classified as endangered on the International Union for the Conservation of Nature’s Red list. Wild chimpanzees face loss of their African forest habitat from commercial logging
column2: agriculture and fires
column3: as well as poaching and disease.

column1: There are 14 chimpanzees in the Maryland Zoo
column2: including the newborn. They can be seen daily
column3: but Raven and her baby will remain behind the scenes for a while to allow them to bond.

column1: In the mean time
column2: see pictures of the new baby below.";Chimp off the old block: Female chimpanzee born at Maryland Zoo;https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEFpAbgFHwwmO5qvRI61HZLkqGQgEKhAIACoHCAowjaWHCzCr3IUDMPzknAY?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://wtop.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/RavenBabyChimp1.jpg;01/08/2020;[{'sent': 'The Maryland Zoo in Baltimore welcomed a female baby chimpanzee last December.\n\n'
