column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"MONKEY World has welcomed its latest arrival – Kalu the chimpanzee.
The 37-year-old primate had lived at Broadlands Stud
column2: the South African estate of the renowned racehorse trainer Pat Cavendish O'Neill.

column1: Pat
column2: who died last year
column3: built up a menagerie of wild animals at Broadlands. Kalu was kept at the stud farm in Somerset West
column4: Cape Town
column5: for more than 30 years following her capture from the wild in the Democratic Republic of Congo
column6: formerly Zaire.

column1: Kalu also featured predominantly in O'Neill's written memoirs
column2: 'A Chimpanzee in the Wine Cellar'.

column1: PICTURES: Monkey World through the years
Monkey World director Dr Alison Cronin said “Despite not having contact with her own kind since she was stolen from the wild as a baby
column2: Kalu is reacting calmly and happily to the attentions of the new group.

column1: It shows how much chimpanzees want and need to be with other of their own kind regardless of how long they have lived alone.
This is the story of so many of our rescued chimps at the park.”
Since O'Neill's death Kalu had been looked after by South Africa's Monkey Town Primate Centre
column2: who contacted Monkey World to see if she could finally find a family of her own kind at the Dorset primate rescue centre.

column1: However
column2: her trip to the UK was not without drama. Monkey World says the chimpanzee was held for ransom over a financial dispute with the O'Neill estate.

column1: A Monkey World spokesman said: ""Kalu’s rescue was jeopardised when the Monkey World team were prevented from entering the Broadlands Farm on the day they were due to move her.
Negotiations between the landowner and the O’Neill Trust and estate got the team to Kalu but not before they missed their flight out of Cape Town.
Monkey World director Dr Alison Cronin
column2: animal director Jeremy Keeling
column3: and specialist wildlife veterinarian Dr John Lewis made the epic trip back to the UK
column4: with the chimpanzee on board the same flight
column5: 24 hours later.""

column1: On arrival in the UK
column2: Dr Cronin and the team quickly settled Kalu into life at the park
column3: living alongside her new family
column4: a community of five other chimpanzees including three others which have also been smuggled from the wild and used in circuses and as photographer’s props in Cyprus
column5: Mexico
column6: and Thailand.";Meet Kalu the chimpanzee

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Freud
column2: Wilkie and the other chimpanzees peacefully fed and rested in the sun-dappled Tanzanian forest. Mzee Hilali stood next to me
column3: writing notes on the chimpanzees’ behavior
column4: as he had been doing for over 30 years as a field assistant for Jane Goodall’s long-term study at Gombe National Park.

column1: Suddenly
column2: a strange
column3: high-pitched call sounded from where some other chimpanzees were feeding
column4: about a hundred meters from us. Hilali turned to me
column5: and with a little laugh
column6: said
column7: “Nyoka.” This was the Swahili word for “snake.”

column1: Freud climbed down from his tree and walked quickly toward where the call had sounded
column2: with Hilali following close behind. As I slowly made my way through the undergrowth to catch up with them
column3: Hilali called to me: “Chatu!” “Python!”

column1: When I caught up with Hilali
column2: he was pointing to a tangled mass of leaves and vines on the forest floor. I looked closely – most of the snake lay hidden from view
column3: but the one visible stretch of black and tan scaly hide was too big to be anything but a python.

column1: From years of experience
column2: Mzee Hilali knew instantly that this particular chimp call meant they’d found a snake. Does this mean that chimpanzees have a “word” for snake? Do chimpanzees have a language of their own? I’ve been working with a team of students and Tanzanian field assistants to record and analyze chimpanzee vocalizations in an effort to answer questions like this. Ultimately we hope to learn more about how human language first evolved.

column1: Clues to the origins of language
Chimpanzees are among human beings’ closest living relatives
column2: and they share with us many unusual traits. Like humans
column3: chimps make and use tools; join together in groups to hunt animals like monkeys; defend group territories; and sometimes gang up on and kill their enemies.

column1: One trait that seems to set humans apart from every other species
column2: however
column3: is a fully developed language. Other animals communicate
column4: but only humans appear able to talk about an unlimited variety of topics. Language enables us to make plans
column5: negotiate with and teach one another.

column1: How and why language evolved remains a mystery. Much of the evidence of human evolution comes from fossils
column2: but fossil bones don’t tell us much about soft tissues or the sounds early human ancestors made. Studying the communication patterns of our living relatives can help solve the mystery.

column1: If some features of chimpanzee communication resemble language
column2: we can study chimpanzees further to find clues for why those features evolved. If chimpanzee communication doesn’t share much in common with human language
column3: then the key steps in language evolution must have occurred after our lineages separated (around 7.9 million years ago) for reasons unique to our human lineage.

column1: Recording in the forest
To investigate chimp communication
column2: my colleagues and I follow chimpanzees through the forest as they go about their lives. We carry a hand-held “shotgun” microphone and a digital recorder
column3: waiting for them to call.

column1: Usually we pick a particular chimp to follow each day
column2: trying to get equal numbers of calls per individual. In addition to recording new calls
column3: we’ve been working to build an archive of recordings from other researchers
column4: going back to the 1970s. The archive currently contains over 71 hours of recordings.

column1: Snake alarm calls are intriguing
column2: but because chimps don’t encounter large snakes very often
column3: it is hard to do a systematic study of them. (Cathy Crockford and colleagues have done some interesting experiments
column4: though
column5: playing back recordings of these calls to see how chimpanzees respond and presenting them with model snakes). One thing chimpanzees do every single day
column6: though
column7: is eat. Chimpanzees spend most of their time looking for food and eating it. And when they find food
column8: they often give a particular kind of call: the rough-grunt.

column1: A chimpanzee rough-grunt.
Biologist Lisa O'Bryan studied rough-grunt calls for her dissertation research with me. They vary from low
column2: noisy grunts to higher-pitched calls. Some researchers have proposed an intriguing possibility: Maybe chimpanzees make distinct kinds of rough-grunt calls in response to particular foods
column3: rather like words that name certain food items.

column1: But Lisa has found that when eating any one kind of food
column2: chimpanzees can produce a range of different rough-grunts. Rough-grunts thus tell other chimps that the caller is eating
column3: but they don’t say what’s for dinner.

column1: Just as a particular alarm call informs others that a snake has been found
column2: the thin
column3: wavering tones of a copulation scream announce that a mating has just taken place.

column1: Author provided 14.6 KB (download) A chimpanzee copulation scream.

Why female chimpanzees sometimes give such a scream just as they finish mating remains unknown. Because the data collected by Mzee Hilali and other field assistants since the 1970s have been entered into a computer database
column2: we can readily examine thousands of different mating events.

column1: My student Tony Massaro has been analyzing these data to try to tease out what factors make females more likely to produce these calls. Such calls aren’t particularly word-like
column2: but they do play an important role in communication. Like many wordless sounds that people make – think laughter
column3: screams and crying – listeners hearing the sounds can infer quite a bit about the caller’s situation.

column1: When Jane Goodall gives public talks
column2: she often begins by giving a pant-hoot: a loud call that begins with an introduction
column3: followed by a build-up
column4: a climax and a let-down. Pant-hoots are loud and enable chimpanzees to communicate over long distances through the forest.

column1: Previous studies have found differences in the pant-hoots calls from different regions. For example
column2: the pant-hoots from Gombe sound a bit different from those made by chimpanzees in Mahale
column3: 160 km away. When I played recordings of a single Mahale pant-hoot call to chimpanzees in Kibale Forest
column4: Uganda
column5: the Kibale chimpanzees acted as if they had just heard an intruder. If they were in a group with three or more males
column6: they gave a loud vocal response and rapidly moved towards the speaker.

column1: If they were in a group with only one or two males present
column2: though
column3: they stayed quiet
column4: and if they approached
column5: did so slowly and cautiously.

column1: For chimpanzees
column2: correctly telling friend from foe is a matter of life or death
column3: so it would make sense for chimpanzees in neighboring groups to have distinctive pant-hoot calls.

column1: Cathy Crockford and colleagues found that pant-hoots from different communities within Taï Forest
column2: Côte d'Ivoire
column3: also sound distinct. If such group-level differences result from vocal learning
column4: they would be rather like dialects in human languages.

column1: My student Nisarg Desai has been testing whether this is also the case at Gombe. We’ve been working with a team of Tanzanian field assistants
column2: Hashimu Issa Salala and Nasibu Zuberi Madumbi
column3: to record calls from the Mitumba and Kasekela chimpanzees
column4: and are starting to test for differences between groups.

column1: We are in the early stages of this analysis.
From calls to language isn’t a clear path
Chimpanzees might be capable of some degree of vocal learning
column2: but I’m struck by how subtle the differences in pant-hoot calls are from place to place. Chimpanzees make lots of different calls – pant-hoots
column3: pant-barks
column4: waa-barks
column5: pant-grunts
column6: rough-grunts
column7: and so on – but across Africa
column8: all chimpanzees produce a pretty similar set of calls in similar circumstances. In this respect
column9: chimpanzee calls resemble human sounds like laughter and crying more than they resemble human words
column10: which can vary drastically from place to place.

column1: Chimpanzees communicate effectively with their various sounds
column2: but in ways quite similar to those of other nonhuman primates. This suggests that our common ancestor with chimpanzees also had a fairly typical repertoire of vocal communication for a nonhuman primate. The really big changes in human language – such as a lifelong ability to learn to make entirely new sounds and a rich symbolic meaning of such sounds – likely evolved later
column3: for reasons that we still don’t understand.";Studying chimpanzee calls for clues about the origins of human language;https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEJ4Wg5MITN8rZXWvntumorYqGQgEKhAIACoHCAowzLvzCjDzxNMCMNuspgU?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://images.theconversation.com/files/218089/original/file-20180508-34006-g309sg.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0&rect=0%2C31%2C998%2C498&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop;05/08/2018;"[{'sent': 'Freud

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"A still from 'The Last Chimpanzee' showing Eli on the set of 'Zero.' As the chimp reached adolescence and had more outbursts
column2: he worked on a greenscreen away from human actors.

column1: As CGI replaces live animals
column2: Eli the chimpanzee — whose résumé includes a TBS show and a One Direction video — retired last year but has yet to find a long-term facility. An upcoming documentary will tell his story.

column1: From Ronald Reagan co-star Bonzo to the Today show's J. Fred Muggs and Bear in B.J. and the Bear
column2: chimpanzees have been appearing in movies and on TV for more than eight decades. That all but came to an end in 2018
column3: the year that Eli
column4: the last chimpanzee professionally trained to act in Hollywood
column5: appeared in his final movie
column6: the Bollywood film Zero. Eli — whose key trick was taking someone's glasses and putting them on — is now awaiting placement in a forever home.

column1: Having been let go by Working Wildlife (which specializes in providing exotic species for entertainment productions)
column2: he was dropped off in March at a financially struggling nonprofit sanctuary near Angeles National Forest
column3: just outside of Los Angeles. The facility shut down in August
column4: and Eli and more than 40 other chimps
column5: many of whom arrived from research labs
column6: have since been under the on-site care of the California Department of Fish and Wildlife. ""We are currently in discussion with a high-quality facility that may provide a permanent home for Eli
column7: says Kirsten Macintyre
column8: a spokeswoman for the state agency.

column1: The 9-year-old chimpanzee's transition out of the business
column2: as typically occurs when the species reaches adolescence
column3: is part of a larger trend away from using real wild creatures to ""act"" onscreen. (While chimps
column4: orangutans and elephants are being phased out
column5: it's still mostly business as usual for species like big cats and bears.)

column1: A mix of factors accounts for the shift
column2: including the adoption of believable CGI (Planet of the Apes
column3: The Lion King) as well as high-profile credibility issues involving the industry's on-set animal watchdog
column4: the American Humane Association. Arguably the strongest influence has been a relentless pressure campaign by animal-rights activists. ""They made it happen
column5: observes Barbara Casey
column6: the head of another industry regulator
column7: Movie Animals Protected.

column1: Eli — who appeared in commercials (Microsoft)
column2: music videos (One Direction) and the occasional TV show (TBS' Angie Tribeca) — saw his own output curbed by the effort
column3: with a Geico ad pulled and scenes from a season of MasterChef Junior cut. PETA primate expert Debbie Metzler is proud of the result. ""A decade ago
column4: there were at least a dozen chimpanzees working
column5: she says. ""Now there are zero.""

column1: At least
column2: there are zero with Hollywood training. Productions willing to risk the ire of activists can still secure chimps from several private companies around the country that teach them circus-style tricks. These include Chance
column3: who appeared opposite Leonardo DiCaprio in 2013's The Wolf of Wall Street.

column1: To conceptual artist Alex Israel
column2: whose practice often probes the mechanics of the entertainment business
column3: including its props and sets
column4: Eli represents the end of an era. For one project
column5: Israel photographed Eli in a Malibu mansion
column6: interacting with other artists' works — including Damien Hirst's pickled
column7: vitrine-based piece Black Sheep. ""He definitely connected with it
column8: looking up close through the glass
column9: interested in what it was and why it was there
column11: at the Gagosian Gallery in London
column12: Israel will unveil a portrait of himself with Eli that references the Jeff Koons sculpture Michael Jackson and Bubbles. Israel calls Eli ""really such a star
column14: adding that the chimpanzee loved candy. ""I think they fed him M&Ms or Skittles or gumdrops. He would be given candy as a reward for holding still for a photo or doing a trick.""

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The government of Nigeria’s Ekiti state has issued an executive order establishing a conservation area within the Ise Forest Reserve
column2: where about 20 Nigeria-Cameroon chimpanzees are believed to survive.

column1: With perhaps as few as 3
column2: 500 left in the wild
column3: the Nigeria-Cameroon chimpanzee faces threats including hunting
column4: logging and forest clearing for agriculture across its range.

column1: Upgrading the reserve to a conservation area will put stricter forest-protection measures in place.
Before doing so
column2: conservationists say they will work to gain the consent and support of forest-dependent communities in the area.

column1: Nigeria’s Ekiti state government has moved to establish a conservation area within the Ise Forest Reserve
column2: an important step toward protecting the habitat of the Nigeria-Cameroon chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes ellioti).

column1: The 46-square-kilometer (18-square-mile) forest reserve is deemed an important priority site for the subspecies
column2: the most threatened type of chimpanzee. Its total population
column3: which occurs in the forested border areas of Nigeria and Cameroon
column4: is projected to number between 3
column5: 500 and 9
column6: 000 in the wild. Fewer than 20 individuals are believed to survive in Ise
column7: distributed across an area of 32 km2 (12 mi2).

column1: While already established as a reserve
column2: the Ise Forest is surrounded by farmland and human settlements
column3: and is grappling with heavy logging and land clearing for farms and illegal marijuana cultivation. Nigeria’s National Drug Law Enforcement Agency said it destroyed 400 acres
column4: about 160 hectares
column5: of marijuana plantations in Ise Forest in late 2014; a year later
column6: it discovered 2
column7: 000 cannabis farms in Ise and Ogotun

column1: Encroachment is a problem in forest reserves throughout Nigeria’s chimpanzee habitats. These reserves
column2: which are controlled by state governments
column3: are established to promote the controlled use of resources rather than as strictly protected areas. They often are poorly monitored
column4: leaving them vulnerable to logging
column5: hunting for bushmeat and for traditional ritual medicines
column6: and clearing for farming and human settlements. Underfunded and understaffed forestry departments struggle to tackle these problems.

column1: Rachel Ashegbofe Ikemeh
column2: project director of The South-West/Niger Delta Forest Project (SWNDF)
column3: which pushed for the establishment of a conservation area in Ise
column4: says she hopes the forest’s upgraded status will protect the forest from these dangers. This will not just aid chimpanzees
column5: she says
column6: but also improve the outcome for other plant and animal species in this highly biodiverse ecosystem.

column1: “The results we are hoping to see in the next few years are simple — good quality habitat
column2: thriving wildlife populations — basically an improved version of what is obtainable in the forest reserve today
column3: all things being equal
column4: ” Ikemeh tells Mongabay.

column1: The exact size and location of the conservation area has yet to be determined. Since March 11
column2: when the state government issued an executive order establishing the conservation zone and indicating that it was willing to ultimately transfer authority to SWNDF
column3: the group has conducted a preliminary assessment. It is also working to attract partner organizations with the expertise and resources to effectively manage the areas
column4: and to work with local communities to gain their support.

column1: In her 2013 survey of chimpanzees in Ise Forest and the Idandre forest cluster
column2: a 2

column1: Chimpanzees are “heavily threatened
column2: ” she says
column3: warning that without immediate action the “populations may never stand the chance of recovery.”

column1: Key to protection efforts
column2: Ikemeh says
column3: is the recruitment and training of “committed individuals as eco-guards/rangers then instituting a patrol and enforcement regime.”

column1: “However
column2: prior to this
column3: is to ensure that a free
column4: prior and informed consent is duly conducted … to ensure we carry the border communities along every step to guarantee a significant level of cooperation
column5: ” she says.

column1: Implementing strict conservation measures can come as a blow to forest-dependent communities. Ikemeh and her team are working to assess the needs of communities living adjacent to the reserve
column2: and to hold discussions with them to explore alternative livelihood projects.

column1: “However
column2: we also expect that there’s no amount of support we are going to provide that will completely deter everyone from attempting to exploit the forests within the conservation area
column3: ” she says. “That’s why there will also be attention paid to effective law enforcement.”

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"It’s been three weeks of lockdown in Paris. The street outside my window seems smaller and emptier every day
column2: as if people are more and more afraid to venture out. The French government recently announced even stricter measures: only one outing allowed per day
column3: one hour per outing
column4: within a 1-kilometer radius of home. The world outside my window is
column5: in fact
column6: getting smaller.

column1: I feel as if I’m almost exclusively a father now
column2: and no longer a writer. Writing matters less than making sure my 3-year-old son sees this new reality as some kind of adventure.

column1: We go outside once a day
column2: for a short walk or a ride on his scooter. At home
column3: we make up games — snapping off the shoots of spinach leaves
column4: learning to pick up scraps of paper with tweezers
column5: creating complex designs on the floor with his collection of used metro tickets.

column1: As I see it now
column2: my primary occupation is keeping everything that’s going on as far away from him as possible — the lockdown
column3: the virus
column4: the uncertainty
column5: the overall sense of panic
column6: the soaring number of sick and dead. And for the most part I’d succeeded. Or so I thought.

column1: Advertisement
Some days ago
column2: I showed my son a short video with a scene of a chimpanzee clinging to Jane Goodall in what appears to be a grateful embrace. I explained that the chimpanzee’s name was Wounda
column3: and that Goodall and her team were releasing Wounda back into the jungle of the Congo after it had been rehabilitated.

column1: As soon as the video ended
column2: my son started to sob inconsolably. At first I was almost proud of his tears
column3: which I interpreted as empathy or emotional intelligence. And maybe they were. But then I couldn’t help but wonder how much built-up frustration he also was releasing in those tears
column4: how much sadness he’d been storing up all week
column5: and hiding from his father.

column1: A few days have passed since he saw the video
column2: but he still talks constantly about Dr. Goodall — he calls her Jane — and about Wounda. This afternoon
column3: while we were trying to nap
column4: he again told me Wounda’s story in his own way
column5: in his own words.

column1: Advertisement
And as I listened to him
column2: I thought of a woman and her team healing a chimpanzee
column3: and a chimpanzee healing a son
column4: and a son healing a father.

column1: Eduardo Halfon has written 14 books of fiction in Spanish and is originally from Guatemala.

@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;LONDON — When trying to get to the bottom of what being human means
column2: we often recruit animals. From scheming
column3: fatally flawed beasts that populate folktales
column4: to the anthropomorphizing of pets by their owners
column5: to the digitized emoticons and avatars in our phones
column6: animals become our unwitting doppelgängers.

column1: In the post-atomic era
column2: apes emerged as our preferred understudy. In the sci-fi masterpiece Planet of the Apes (1968) orangutans
column3: gorillas
column4: and monkeys stand in for humans and cast a complicated light on our hierarchical
column5: technocratic
column6: and dystopian culture. The Naked Ape (1967)
column7: another global best-seller from this era
column8: was zoologist Desmond Morris’s speculative anthropological study in which apes’ body language and mating rituals highlight corresponding behaviors in humans. While Morris’s text has long since been eclipsed by the more rigorous scholarship about simians by fellow Brit Jane Goodall
column9: Morris pioneered multiple studies on the art-making impulse in animals
column10: especially paintings and drawings created by a prolific chimpanzee from The London Zoo named Congo. Morris has put these works up for public sale and they’re on display in The Mayor Gallery’s current exhibition Congo the Chimpanzee: The Birth of Art.

column1: This is not Congo’s artistic debut. Many “Congos” were originally exhibited at London’s Institute of Contemporary Arts in 1957
column2: which led to the monkey’s art being snatched up by admiring peers such as Pablo Picasso and Joan Miró. But Congo
column3: like many an Abstract Expressionist in his time
column4: quickly faded from the annals of postwar art. This neglect is rectified by The Mayor Gallery’s generous gathering of some 55 Congo works
column5: including oil and pastel paintings and drawings.

column1: From 1955 to 1959
column2: chaperoned and occasionally recorded on live television by Morris
column3: Congo sat at a small desk for painting “sessions” that ran for about 15 minutes each. During this artistic zenith he created over 400 artworks
column4: independently choosing colors
column5: patterns
column6: and themes
column7: and deciding when the picture was finished by refusing to continue until Morris provided him with a new

column1: Like artworks made by very young children and those experiencing psychoses
column2: Congo’s work makes us believe in the much maligned concept of originality in art. Functioning beyond cultural influence
column3: Congo was a proto-Modernist. He never fretted about his work’s debt to Surrealism or Cubism
column4: nor was he anxiously gazing over his hairy shoulder at his most obvious stylistic peers
column5: for instance
column6: Joan Mitchell or Cy Twombly. And judging from the range of pictures at The Mayor Gallery
column7: there are signs of artistic development

column1: In his first sessions
column2: he made spare
column3: stray marks that did not qualify as complete pictures. But Morris reports that without coercion or direction
column4: Congo became ever more focused. That willfulness and concentration has been documented in studio photographs of the chimp manipulating paintbrushes
column5: sometimes wielding two at a time
column6: to execute balanced and cohesive compositions
column7: which he held up and scrutinized at various stages of completion.

column1: As represented by the works at The Mayor Gallery
column2: his palette preferences tend toward primary and secondary colors — various reds
column3: yellows
column4: and greens. Yet the chimp seems mindful about complementary tones and hues. In some paintings
column5: yellows are juxtaposed with greens; in others
column6: bold blues are softened by adjoining or overlapping squibs of white or black and
column7: in even more bold flourishes
column8: by deep pinks and lush purples. And like homo sapien peers during this period
column9: Congo occasionally painted only in black and white
column10: testing the inherent plasticity produced through gestural painting.

column1: Thematically speaking
column2: Congo’s abstractions fall roughly into three species: impassioned vortexes
column3: exquisite fan patterns
column4: and calligraphic arrangements. Some pictures look like twisted trees while others suggest a jungle’s entangled undergrowth. In one series
column5: repeated pale green brushstrokes resemble palm fronds
column6: very nearly representing them. But such readings could be facile biographical interpretations which Congo-the-pure-abstractionist might rebut with outraged howls and whoops.

column1: Still
column2: it is tempting to translate Congo’s abstractions into realistic terms. Especially in his drawings
column3: scissoring and elongated flourishes seem to verge on a kind of script. What
column4: we might ask
column5: is he communicating to us
column6: or to himself? In one very spare drawing reproduced in Mayor’s Congo catalogue raisonné
column7: the artist seems to make an attempt at drawing a human face.

column1: Though short-lived
column2: Congo’s art career ended
column3: ironically
column4: with a postmodern bang. According to Morris’s catalogue essay
column5: Congo soon recoiled against the bourgeois orderliness of these painting sessions and
column6: like an auto-destructive artist ahead of his time
column7: the chimp began “to obliterate the sheets of paper with large masses of paint.”

column1: All this monkey business at The Mayor Gallery takes us from wild aesthetic conjectures to sobering ethical dilemmas around animal agency
column2: art ownership
column3: and basic rights of living creatures. We might wonder
column4: is Congo more a circus elephant or a simian Vincent van Gogh? Take the recent case around a selfie snapped by a macaque ape in Indonesia
column5: which raised the thorny question about who owns the copyright to an artwork created by an animal
column6: even when the means or conditions for creating that artwork are furnished by a human being? In response to many such incidents
column7: animal rights advocates have argued for recognizing personhood for simians.

column1: Such quandaries — and a good many more — underpin Alfred Fidjestøl’s absorbing new study
column2: Almost Human: The Story of Julius
column3: the Chimpanzee Caught Between Two Worlds (Greystone Books
column5: a timely book in light of Congo’s artistic resurgence.

column1: Born in 1979 in The Kristiansand Zoo in southern Norway
column2: Julius
column3: who turns 40 in the next few weeks
column4: was inexplicably rejected by his birth mother and
column5: immediately afterward
column6: beaten nearly to death by another chimp. Young Julius was ferried to safety in the homes and families of various zookeepers who nursed him back to health for almost a full year. Monitored by the news media
column7: Julius became an overnight sensation in Norway and remained a celebrity there throughout the 1980s. While living in human company
column8: Julius adopted their rhythms and habits
column9: sleeping in a bed made from a cardboard box and waking early to play with his human “sisters
column11: moving his food bowl on the floor as if it were a toy car.

column1: This impulse toward interactive play emerges as a recurring human-chimpanzee link in Almost Human. While being tickled
column2: Julius would feign intolerance while enjoying it; when beginning a race with his human siblings
column3: he suspiciously monitored his competitors’ positions to ensure no one took off before the starting bell. And
column4: as Fidjestøl makes clear
column5: Julius’s mirroring behavior parallels that of an equally famous chimp named Lucy who lived with an Oklahoma couple in the 1970s and who also began to adopt human culture as her own — using silverware
column6: learning sign language
column7: selecting clothing to wear
column8: drinking a boozy cocktail now and then

column1: But like Lucy
column2: who was returned to a chimp community in Gambia where she remained an alienated
column3: depressed outsider unable to bond with peers
column4: so too Julius’s youthful immersion in human culture had a detrimental effect on the animal’s adulthood.

column1: By painstakingly narrating Julius’s troubled reintegration with fellow chimps at the zoo
column2: Fidjestøl debunks any naiveté readers might harbor about chimpanzees who
column3: we learn
column4: have sharp teeth capable of easily biting off a finger and arm strength 15 times stronger than that of an athletic adult human male. And unlike the far less aggressive and much more sexually open-minded bonobo species of apes
column5: chimpanzees are patriarchal and tribal
column6: and
column7: at times
column9: even as they demonstrate acute proficiencies like photographic memory

column1: As its reflective title suggests
column2: Almost Human develops its drama around regrets and anxieties about Julius’s welfare that bedevil his human caretakers
column3: inside the zoo and beyond it
column4: as they become both antagonists and protagonists in the chimp’s rocky development. Moreover
column5: Julius’s plight reflects subtly on universal human predicaments
column6: such as choosing domesticity over spontaneity
column7: togetherness over individuality

column1: Though Fidjestøl goes easy on homo sapiens
column2: a subtext is how lousy a species we are. We continue to destroy chimps through hunting and poaching while laying waste to their natural habitats through our greed. In 1979
column3: when Julius was born
column4: there were one million chimpanzees in the wild. Today
column5: according to Fidjestøl
column6: there may be less than 200

column1: And Julius is conscripted into the zoo’s image makeover. The Kristiansand Zoo expands into an amusement park and upgrades its grounds to accommodate the growing push for animal rights. Having painted sporadically alongside his human counterparts when small
column2: in the late 1990s
column3: the adult Julius is given a paintbrush again at the behest of his handlers and creates images that are sold to raise funds for the zoo. Though the incident has an unpleasant commercial stench to it
column4: Julius’s artwork indicates that the chimp had the potential to be as interesting
column5: though somewhat more conservative an artist
column6: as his more prolific predecessor
column7: Congo.

column1: Fidjestøl closes Almost Human with meditations on Julius’s receptivity and openness
column2: relating notes by his early caretaker
column3: Billy Glad
column4: who studies the young chimp’s gaze
column5: noting
column6: “You [Julius] have such a serious face
column7: little man — like an old man. You look so wise
column8: so quizzical. And yet your gaze is clear and open.” At its best
column9: the passage sums up what humans seek out in animals and in art
column10: as well as in animal-made art — a disquieting and empathetic encounter with the nonhuman
column11: of which we are also a part. Such encounters temporarily free us from civilization’s sedative effects
column12: and startle our consciousness about the improbable
column13: fundamental fact that we too are animals and we exist.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"This video of a fist-bumping chimpanzee has made the rounds all over Twitter. While some viewers may think it’s “cute
column2: ” PETA thinks everyone would feel different if they knew this primate’s story.

column1: The chimpanzee is believed to be a male named Sugriva. That name may ring a bell. Earlier this year
column2: we let readers know how the notorious roadside zoo Myrtle Beach Safari exploits him on a regular basis for social media clout.

column1: If you’re unfamiliar with Sugriva’s story
column2: he was torn away from his mother as an infant—like most primates used for entertainment and encounters with humans. In his early years
column3: trainers likely kept him under the constant threat of physical punishment in order to ensure that he “performed” whenever humans wanted him to.

column1: Throughout his entire life
column2: he’s been paraded around as though he were nothing more than a prop for publicity stunts.

column1: Myrtle Beach Safari treats its animals like inanimate party equipment. Handlers have used Sugriva as a photo prop for tourists at a mall
column2: passing him along from stranger to stranger. His brother
column3: Vali
column4: has even been forced to “play football” with an NFL athlete in one Instagram video.

column1: Experiences like these are unnatural and likely confusing and frightening for a young chimpanzee who should be living in the forest with his family. At Myrtle Beach Safari
column2: these animals have no choices or free will. Their lives are valued only relative to how much money they bring in for the roadside zoo.

column1: For decades
column2: PETA has worked to shut down the sleazy Myrtle Beach Safari. We want the numerous exotic animals held there to be moved to reputable sanctuaries.

column1: Operator and owner Bhagavan “Doc” Antle has a long history of violating the federal Animal Welfare Act
column2: including by endangering the public and by failing to provide animals with needed veterinary care
column3: sufficient cage space
column4: and clean water. He’s also been cited for keeping animals in dangerous
column5: dilapidated enclosures. In 2014
column6: he came under fire from PETA for a shameless—and dangerous—stunt in which he took two chimpanzees to a screening of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Update: April 23
Officials ordered Samutprakan Crocodile Farm and Zoo—a shady Thai facility—to shape up after it forced a masked
column2: leashed chimpanzee to ride around on a bike and spray disinfectant in an apparent attempt to capitalize on the coronavirus crisis.

column1: Zoo ordered to stop using its chimpanzee to spray disinfectant #โควิด19 #COVIDー19 https://t.co/CjZpbq5iBK — Coconuts Bangkok (@CoconutsBangkok) April 21
While we’re thankful that authorities put the kibosh on the cruel stunt
column2: it’s not nearly good enough. As a PETA video exposé revealed last year
column3: animals kept at Samutprakan Zoo are abused for entertainment in other ways
column4: too. Eyewitnesses observed crocodiles being struck with poles
column5: tigers harassed into performing and being in photos with tourists
column6: and primates whose basic needs were neglected.

column1: Please
column2: never support animal shows or exhibits.

column1: Keep reading to learn how else you can help exploited animals like the chimpanzee.
Originally posted on April 21

Folks online didn’t fall for a shoddy Thai zoo’s cheap attempt to capitalize on a chimpanzee’s suffering and the coronavirus crisis—not even when the facility lamely alleged that it was just letting the great ape “stretch his limbs.” The footage below shows what actually happened: A chimpanzee—on a leash and wearing a mask and human clothing—was forced to ride around on a bike spraying “coronavirus sanitizer
column2: ” all while staff videoed.

column1: The heartbreaking stunt took place at Samutprakan Crocodile Farm and Zoo
column2: a seedy operation in Thailand that PETA Asia sounded the alarm on previously. As pointed out by the Daily Mail
column3: though
column4: the exploit garnered quite a backlash.

column1: Thailand zoo sparks fury after making chimpanzee in a face mask ride a bicycle while spraying coronavirus sanitizer https://t.co/jMK9hqjdc9 — Daily Mail Online (@MailOnline) April 15
Chimpanzees are a lot like us humans. They love slapstick humor
column2: falling about if one of their chimpanzee pals falls off a rock (as long as they don’t seem hurt). What they surely don’t find funny
column3: though
column4: is being exploited for entertainment—and the criticism that the video received proves that many members of the public don’t think such a horrible stunt is amusing
column5: either. “Who ARE those tourists who don’t seem to give a s**t about animal welfare?!” one Twitter user asked—an apt question
column6: considering that if everyone refused to patronize Samutprakan Zoo and other animal-exploiting operations like it
column7: it would be near impossible for such businesses to stay afloat.

column1: Learn More About Avoiding Attractions That Use Animals

column2: a PETA Asia video exposé of Samutprakan Zoo showed that elephants at the facility are stabbed in order to make them perform tricks
column3: crocodiles are struck with bamboo poles
column4: and tigers are harassed for performances and photos with tourists. Eyewitnesses found that other animals
column5: including a young orangutan and a young chimpanzee (who could be this same one forced to ride a bike and spray disinfectant)
column6: appeared frustrated and listless.

column1: Thanks to thousands of kind people who took action
column2: Trip.com and Ctrip (Asia’s biggest travel agency) have made the compassionate decision to stop selling tickets to Samutprakan Zoo. But this chimpanzee and the other animals being held and exploited at the hellhole tourist trap need your continued support. Please
column3: never support animal shows or exhibits. Instead
column4: use a compassionate travel agency as you plan your next vacation when it’s safe to travel:

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The United Nations famously protects cultural heritage sites
column2: but for the first time it has recognized the unique culture of animals.

column1: At the 13th Conference of Parties (CoP) to the United Nations Environment Program's (UNEP) Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS)
column2: which took place recently in India
column3: the conference attendees agreed to protect the ability of West African chimpanzees to crack nuts
column4: according to Down to Earth magazine. The CMS recognized the unique learned ability of chimpanzees to use stone hammers and bits of wood to crack nuts
column5: making this the first time
column6: it seems
column7: that one species has formally recognized the value of another's learned customs
column8: according to The Times of London.

column1: The proposal recognized that there are 39 cultural variations that are recognized in chimpanzees across various regions of Africa
column2: but it said
column3: ""[a]mong these
column4: the clearest instance was nut-cracking
column5: common in the West
column6: yet absent elsewhere despite the availability of the necessary raw materials."" The CMS is looking to create something similar to a cultural heritage site
column7: where chimpanzee nut-cracking is protected. The CMS said it highlights the chimpanzees' ""unique technological culture
column8: as CNN reported. The ability to use stone and wood as a hammer and anvil is only observed in chimpanzees in West Africa. The CMS said that chimps in Guinea
column10: Liberia and the Ivory Coast have the ability
column11: but those in other parts of Africa do not

column1: In different parts of western Africa
column2: scientists noted that chimpanzees interacted with each other and used tools
column3: so their behaviors are different from other animals. It becomes apparent when you watch them for a while
column4: said Ian Redmond
column5: a CMS tropical field biologist and conservationist
column6: to Down to Earth. ""You can tell where a chimpanzee is from by looking at its behavior in a way similar to when you recognize which tribe a human comes from through her clothes
column7: dancing and mannerisms."" The need to protect chimpanzees is particularly pronounced now that their habitat is rapidly changing due to the climate crisis and industrial nut farming. ""[We] must expect [nut cracking culture] to suffer a high degree of threat
column8: a situation that is reminiscent of cultural extinctions among humans
column9: such as of relatively rare local languages and other customs
column10: the CMS wrote in its proposal. ""Alternatively
column11: such behavioral plasticity could enhance survival prospects of chimpanzees in marginal habitat or subject to climate-induced changes to vegetation.""";The UN Looks to Protect Chimpanzee Culture;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiPmh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmVjb3dhdGNoLmNvbS91bi1jaGltcGFuemVlLWN1bHR1cmUtMjY0NTQ0OTg0My5odG1s0gE9aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZWNvd2F0Y2guY29tL2FtcC91bi1jaGltcGFuemVlLWN1bHR1cmUtMjY0NTQ0OTg0Mw?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://assets.rebelmouse.io/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJpbWFnZSI6Imh0dHBzOi8vYXNzZXRzLnJibC5tcy8yMjg3MDkzMi9vcmlnaW4uanBnIiwiZXhwaXJlc19hdCI6MTU5MTk3OTc0Mn0.j7-XCcSGj6NkKItUSyi9AY1iJobnvTXlDBBeMhwdo-I/img.jpg?width=1200&coordinates=0%2C37%2C0%2C38&height=600;03/11/2020;"[{'sent': 'The United Nations famously protects cultural heritage sites

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Some of NIH’s chimpanzees will not retire to a sanctuary as planned
The U.S. National Institutes of Health (NIH) will not be retiring all of its chimpanzees to a sanctuary
column2: as it originally pledged to do
column3: agency head Francis Collins announced today. Nearly four dozen chimps at a biomedical primate facility in New Mexico will remain there because they are too old and sick to move
column4: he said
column5: although scientific studies of them have ended. Some federally owned or supported chimpanzees at other biomedical primate facilities may also not be retired to sanctuaries.

column1: “Some of these animals are quite old and very frail. It was just going to be too unsafe to move all of them
column2: ” says NIH Deputy Director James Anderson
column3: whose division oversees the NIH Chimpanzee Management Program. “We’re not going to take the risk.”

column1: Chimp Haven in Keithville
column2: Louisiana
column3: the national chimpanzee sanctuary where the animals were supposed to be retired
column4: laments the decision. “We’re disappointed
column5: ” says Stephen Ross
column6: the sanctuary’s board chair. “We believe that every chimpanzee should have the opportunity to live out the rest of their life in a sanctuary
column7: and we’re concerned this decision will set a precedent for other chimps still waiting to be retired.”

column1: Biomedical research on chimpanzees effectively ended in 2015
column2: when NIH announced it would no longer fund such studies. The agency also pledged to retire all of the approximately 300 chimps it owned or supported to Chimp Haven. Experts expected that the 340 or so other chimpanzees privately owned for research would follow suit. But retirement proceeded slowly. In the 2 years after NIH’s decision
column3: only 51 government-owned or -supported chimps and 22 privately owned chimps had entered sanctuaries.

column2: NIH announced a formal retirement plan
column3: with Anderson predicting most of its animals would enter a sanctuary within 10 years. And by the following year
column4: retirement had picked up
column5: with more chimps in sanctuaries than in biomedical facilities for the first time. Today
column6: only 178 government-owned or -supported chimpanzees live in biomedical primate facilities: the Alamogordo Primate Facility in New Mexico; the MD Anderson Cancer Center in Bastrop
column7: Texas; and the Texas Biomedical Research Institute in San Antonio. About 190 chimpanzees remain at two private facilities: the New Iberia Research Center in Louisiana
column8: and Yerkes National Primate Research Center in Atlanta.

column1: Many of these remaining chimps have lived at their facilities for decades
column2: which means they’re nearing the end of their lives
column3: and have diabetes
column4: heart conditions
column5: and other infirmities. Some in the biomedical community have argued that these animals are too sick and frail to survive the stresses of a long trip and a new living facility
column6: with new humans and chimps to get used to. They point to nine older chimps that died within 2 years of being transferred from the MD Anderson Cancer Center to Chimp Haven about 5 years ago.

column2: NIH created a working group to help the agency figure out which chimpanzees were fit to move to a sanctuary. A panel of NIH veterinarians not involved with the agency’s Chimpanzee Management Program reviewed the health records of chimps at the Alamogordo facility and consulted the vets there. In a report completed in September
column3: the vets recommended that all 44 remaining chimpanzees at Alamogordo remain there for the rest of their lives. “Many of the animals had varying degrees of cardiovascular disease
column4: [and] these conditions could cause the animals to die in transport
column5: ” according to the report.

column1: “The NIH’s decision is in the best interest of these elderly and frail animals
column2: ” writes Matthew Bailey
column3: president of the Washington
column4: D.C.–based National Association for Biomedical Research
column5: in a statement released today. “The chimpanzees will live out their days in Alamogordo
column6: where … they have forged close bonds with their social groups and their caretakers.”

column1: But the Washington
column2: D.C.–based Humane Society of the United States says NIH’s evaluation process was flawed. “The NIH panel didn’t include vets with sanctuary experience
column3: and it just rubber stamped what the labs wanted
column4: ” says Kathleen Conlee
column5: the organization’s vice president of animal research issues. She contends that the Alamogordo facility wants to keep the animals because they get NIH funding to care for them. (A spokesperson for the company that manages the facility directed all press queries to NIH.) “We are extremely disappointed that NIH has broken its promise to these chimpanzees
column6: ” Conlee says.

column1: Ross says NIH shouldn’t just look at the potential drawbacks of moving the animals
column2: but also at the upside. “There are tremendous benefits of getting them in the large
column3: dynamic social groups we have at Chimp Haven
column4: ” he says
column5: in which chimps “meet new friends and in most cases keep old friends
column6: too.” He also says many (though not all) of the animals at Chimp Haven are free to climb trees and roam large
column7: open-topped
column8: grassy enclosures—something they can’t do at Alamogordo. “The benefits of sending these animals to a sanctuary far outweigh the risks.”

column1: Anderson says NIH’s vets had the best interests of the animals in mind. And he contends that the chimps that will remain at Alamogordo will still live good lives
column2: in their existing social groups and with access to the outdoors (see video above).

column1: NIH will next turn its attention to the chimps at the MD Anderson Center. Fifty-nine animals of the animals there have already gone to Chimp Haven this year
column2: Anderson says
column3: but he’s not sure how many of the remaining 63 will make it. “It’s possible some will retire where they are.”

column1: *Correction
column2: 25 October

column2: the Little Rock Zoo's newest chimpanzee
column3: arrived on March 3 from Albuquerque
column4: N.M.
column5: officials said Thursday. (Special to the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette/Catherine Tidwell)

column1: The Little Rock Zoo welcomed a new chimpanzee last month
column2: officials announced Thursday.

column1: Kianga is a 13-year-old female chimp who came to Little Rock from the Albuquerque Biological Park on a breeding recommendation from the Association of Zoos and Aquariums’ Chimpanzee Species Survival Plan. She arrived March 3.
According to her keepers
column2: Kianga is petite but savvy and has already made friends with the other chimps
column3: the zoo said in a news release.

column1: Since Kianga’s arrival
column2: the zoo has closed due to the covid-19 pandemic
column3: but anyone interested in learning about her and the zoo’s other chimpanzees can watch a video posted on the zoo’s Facebook page on Sunday.

column1: The zoo is also hosting daily virtual tours on Facebook. See the zoo's website for details.
Thirteen is considered adult age for female chimpanzees
column2: a Little Rock Zoo employee said in the video
column3: while males reach adult age around 15 or 16.

column1: @TRAFFIC_WLTrade;@TRAFFIC_WLTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"BALTIMORE (WJZ) — The Maryland Zoo has a new family member!
29-year-old chimpanzee Bunny gave birth to a female chimpanzee on July 5.
Credit: Maryland Zoo
The Zoo’s animal staff said she had an uncomplicated labor and delivery
column2: and Bunny and the baby have spent their first 10 days together bonding in a quiet
column3: off-exhibit area.

column1: “Bunny is very attentive and protective of her baby. She likes to hold the baby up and watch her move and often nuzzles her face
column2: ” said Erin Cantwell
column3: mammal collection and conservation manager. “Bunny is also doing a great job of helping us by showing us the baby when her care team ask
column4: which has allowed us to be able to observe her closely and make sure she looks good. The baby is nursing regularly and getting stronger every day.”

column1: The Chimpanzee Forest team has been monitoring the pair closely to make sure all behaviors are normal between the infant and the mother because Bunny is mostly deaf- with slight hearing in one year.
Keepers said she is able to hear and feel the baby when it cries loudly.
“We want to be as hands-off as possible to allow mom and baby plenty of time to develop their relationship. Just like with human moms
column2: there is a steep learning curve for both the baby and the mother in the first few days as they both adjust to this new way of life
column3: ” said Cantwell.

column1: The little chimpanzee has little fluffy black hair covering most of her body and spends nearly all of her time cradled in Bunny’s arms or clinging closely to her back. Chimp babies usually weigh 2-3 pounds at birth.
“We are so excited to see Bunny flourish as a mom
column2: ” said Cantwell. “It’s great to watch an animal we care so much about experience this next step in her life. And
column3: chimp babies are really quite adorable. We can’t wait to watch the baby grow up and achieve her own life milestones!”

column1: Bunny is with a smaller group of chimps so she can focus on her baby and not have to worry about the social dynamics of chimp society
column2: the Zoo said.

column1: There are 13 chimpanzees in the Maryland Zoo’s troop including the newborn. The Zoo said for now
column2: Bunny and her baby will stay behind the scenes so they can strengthen their bond and then later will be introduced to the troop.";It’s A Girl! Chimpanzee Born At The Maryland Zoo;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiWWh0dHBzOi8vYmFsdGltb3JlLmNic2xvY2FsLmNvbS8yMDE5LzA3LzE1L2l0cy1hLWdpcmwtY2hpbXBhbnplZS1ib3JuLWF0LXRoZS1tYXJ5bGFuZC16b28v0gFdaHR0cHM6Ly9iYWx0aW1vcmUuY2JzbG9jYWwuY29tLzIwMTkvMDcvMTUvaXRzLWEtZ2lybC1jaGltcGFuemVlLWJvcm4tYXQtdGhlLW1hcnlsYW5kLXpvby9hbXAv?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/15910056/2019/07/dsc_4949-3.jpg?w=1500;07/15/2019;[{'sent': 'The Maryland Zoo has a new family member!\n\n'

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Common chimpanzee behaviours
column2: like stripping the leaves from a twig and using it to fish for termites
column3: are becoming more rare according to new research that suggests that human activity is wearing down chimpanzee culture.

column1: Culture
column2: in the animal sense
column3: being the diversity of behaviour and the sharing of knowledge between individuals.

column1: A study published on Thursday in the journal Science revealed an 88 percent decline on average in the number of behaviours a chimpanzee will show when they’re living near areas with lots of people
column2: or roads
column3: or without forest cover.

column1: Chimpanzees might be more cautious about cracking nuts loudly using stones
column2: for example
column3: for fear of attracting the attention of poachers. Similarly
column4: declining chimpanzee numbers mean there are fewer individuals to show others how to
column5: say
column6: get water using moss.

column1: “We weren’t surprised that the human impact was having a negative effect but we were surprised by the degree
column2: ” primate researcher Ammie Kalan told Motherboard over the phone.

column1: Read More: Elite Canadian Wolves Airdropped Into Michigan to Kill Moose and Have Babies

The findings are frighteningly robust. Researchers catalogued 31 different behaviours (such as making cushions out of leaves or cooling down in a nearby cave) in 144 social groups. The study spanned the entire geographic range of wild chimpanzees
column2: from Guinea in Western Africa to Southern Sudan in the east and Angola in the south.

column1: No matter how the scientists grouped the behaviours in their statistical analysis
column2: the results were the same: human impact isn’t just linked with population declines
column3: it’s also affecting how chimpanzees behave.

column1: “It wasn’t just based on a single glance at the dataset
column2: but it was a really strong pattern
column3: ” Kalan said.

column1: Chimpanzee numbers have declined by more than 80 percent in the past quarter century partly because of the fragmentation of their forest habitat through agriculture and climate change. This means there are fewer of them to pass on behaviours.
Behavioural diversity could also be decreasing
column2: the authors note
column3: because climate change is limiting the availability of foods or plants they smash up or use to hunt for ants.

column1: The researchers aren’t sure whether chimps spontaneously developing new behaviours can make up for the loss in behavioural diversity. They fear some yet-unobserved behaviours may be gone before any human ever gets to witness them.

Chimpanzees aren’t the only animals that could suffer from culture loss thanks to anthropogenic activity and climate change. Kalan said that any animal that’s socially intelligent and spreads ideas between generations could be at risk: orangutans
column2: whales
column3: dolphins
column4: elephants
column5: even song birds with special dialects.

column1: The latest United Nations Environment Programme report recognizes the importance of behavioural diversity and says data collection on social groups should be included in conservation efforts
column2: along with keeping animal numbers and genetic variability up
column3: going forward.

column1: Kalan and the other study authors suggest creating “cultural heritage sites” to try and preserve chimpanzee behaviours. These would be specific locations that are particularly important to chimpanzees for tool use or communication—a cave or group of stones
column2: for example.

column1: “If those places didn’t exist then those behaviours most likely would not continue. It really becomes part of the cultural heritage of that chimpanzee community
column2: ” Kalan explained.

The Rock of Gibraltar is one of the Pillars of Hercules
column2: the peninsulas that flank the entrance to the Strait of Gibraltar
column3: a narrow strait that connects the Atlantic Ocean to the Mediterranean Sea and separates Gibraltar from Morocco in Africa. At the narrowest point
column4: Europe and Africa are only separated by 7.7 nautical miles of ocean.

column1: The common chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes) can be found in north-west and central Africa and is a species of great ape. This primate lives in groups that range in size from 15 to 150 individuals
column2: although they split into much smaller groups to travel and forage during the day. The species lives in a male-dominated and strict hierarchy
column3: which means that disputes can generally be settled without the need for violence.

column1: Believed to be one of the closest living relatives of humans
column2: nearly all chimpanzee populations have been recorded using tools
column3: modifying sticks
column4: rocks
column5: grass and leaves and using them for acquiring honey
column6: termites
column7: ants

column1: The biggest threats to the common Chimpanzee are habitat destruction
column2: poaching and disease. The species is listed on the International Union of Conservation of Nature Red List as an endangered species and are therefore legally protected in most of their range.

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"When and where did humans split from the apes to become a separate branch of bipeds? Are we an ape or not? If so
column2: which of the living Great Apes is the closest to humans?

column1: European philosophers and scientists have debated questions like these for more than three centuries.
From the pre-evolutionary musings of sixteenth century Dutch anatomists like Nicolaes Tulp and eighteenth century naturalists such as Carl Linnaeus
column2: to the father of evolutionary biology
column3: Charles Darwin
column4: and his successors
column5: Western scholars have long pondered where among the living primates humans belong.

column1: The careful and detailed dissections of Great Apes and humans done by ‘Darwin’s bulldog’
column2: T.H. Huxley
column3: in the late nineteenth century seemed to reveal that gorillas and chimpanzees were physically more alike than either species was to humans.

column1: This also squared with the view that humans were very distinct from the other African Apes
column2: having evolved for longer
column3: and perhaps at a faster rate
column4: to obtain highly distinctive features like our upright posture
column5: bipedal locomotion and big brains.

column1: Still
column2: Huxley’s work made it starkly clear that humans were a Great Ape
column3: closer to our African kin than our East Asian ape cousins
column4: the orangutan.

column1: It was unclear
column2: however
column3: which of the hundreds of extinct ape species found during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries in Africa
column4: Europe and Asia
column5: dating from the period 10 million to 35 million years old
column6: gave rise to the human lineage.

column1: By the mid-1960s this seemed to be solved. David Pilbeam of Harvard University argued that Ramapithecus
column2: a 14 million year old ape from the Siwalik Mountains of Pakistan
column3: but also found in East Africa
column4: was the earliest member of the human line.

column1: It was even suggested that humans had split from a common ancestor with the African apes by about 30 million years ago
column2: making our evolution a very long process indeed.

column1: Coincidentally
column2: at the time Ramapithecus was being touted as the first human ancestor
column3: pioneers of the nascent field of molecular biology were beginning to compare blood proteins among different mammals
column4: including humans and apes
column5: to study their evolution.

column1: Their findings were poised to cause a major upset among anthropologists
column2: and would come to set the framework for understanding the origins of the human branch until today.

column1: Emile Zuckerkandl and twice Nobel Prize winner Linus Pauling were among the many workers studying haemoglobin
column2: and were interested in differences between humans and the gorilla.

column1: They found that the differences between the two species were mostly the result of ‘neutral’ mutations
column2: or genetic changes with little or no consequence for the functioning of blood proteins themselves.

column1: The neutrality of these mutations meant they could be used as a yardstick of evolutionary distance - the more mutations accumulated
column2: the longer the time since the species split.

column1: Neutral mutations were also found to occur with enough regularity to provide a kind of ‘molecular clock’; which is today used across the entire tree of life to give evolution a time frame.
Although the molecular clock is now a well established tool in evolutionary biology
column2: it is not without its controversies or detractors.

column1: It isn’t as accurate as the geological clocks used routinely to date rocks and fossils by geologists
column2: although
column3: they also have their uncertainties of course.

column1: And
column2: rather cleverly
column3: modern molecular clocks use dated geological events as a kind of reference or standard against which to calibrate evolutionary time
column4: especially the ‘tick rate’ (or mutation rate) of the clock itself.

column1: With the advent of ancient DNA sequencing
column2: we can even study clocks in extinct species and get a handle on whether its ticking rate has changed over time.

column1: These first molecular clocks suggested humans and gorillas had separated only around 11 million years ago
column2: not 30 million as suggested by fossils like Ramapithecus.

column1: Surprisingly
column2: this date is remarkably similar to even the most recent molecular clock estimates as well as the latest fossil discoveries
column3: as we shall see later
column4: indicating gorillas diverged between 8.5 and 12 million years ago.

column1: Incidentally
column2: once the bony face of Ramapithecus was unearthed from the fosil record of Pakistan in the early 1980s
column3: the human status of this ape was quickly reassessed.

column1: When it comes to studying Great Ape evolution
column2: especially chimpanzees
column3: we have so little to go on from the fossil record that we have no choice but reply heavily on genomic evidence.

column1: As it turns out
column2: everything we know about chimp evolution has been garnered from their genomes: the common chimpanzee (species: Pan troglodytes) had its genome sequenced in 2005
column3: while the bonobo (species: Pan paniscus) only had its genetic code fully read in 2012.

column1: So far
column2: we’ve found just three fossil teeth for the entirety of chimpanzee evolution
column3: and they’re a mere 500
column4: 000 years old.

column1: As I noted earlier
column2: Huxley’s dissections in the late 1800s established the closeness of humans to chimpanzees and gorillas.

column1: But
column2: for a good portion of the twentieth century
column3: the precise branching arrangements of the African ape tree - whether humans were closest to either of the apes or sat out on our own - were contested.

column1: It wasn’t until the year 2000 when this was finally resolved by molecular biologists: humans and chimpanzees were shown to share an ancestor after gorillas had gone their separate evolutionary way.
Following the sequencing of the complete human and chimpanzee genomes by 2005
column2: geneticists showed that we share around 99 percent of our DNA
column3: firming up our closeness.

column2: along came Orrorin tugenensis and Sahelanthropus tchadensis
column3: fossils that appeared to belong to the human line
column4: and dated between 6 and 7 million years old.

column1: Most molecular clocks at the time
column2: and many since
column3: put the split between humans and chimpanzees at only around 5-6 million years ago.

column1: But now the fossil record had pushed the date back
column2: and so the molecular clocks would need to be rethought.

column1: Some geneticists and anthropologists argued against Orrorin
column2: Sahelanthropus and another group
column3: Ardipithecus
column4: being in the human branch on the grounds that they were too old and their similarities to humans explainable in ways other than shared ancestry.

column1: While most anthropologists currently welcome them as pre-humans
column2: there continue to be high profile sceptics
column3: and opinions can change quickly with new evidence.

column1: Still
column2: truth is we have so few fossils in the window of 4 million to 12 million years ago that we’re a long way from having a clear sense of when and how gorillas
column3: chimpanzees and humans split from each other
column4: and the emergence of the human lineage itself.

column1: The human fossil record gets a lot denser from about 4 million years onwards.
Enter Chororapithecus abyssinicus: found by anthropologists excavating in Ethiopia during 2006 and 2007.
This species seems to belong to the gorilla line
column2: and new research published in the journal Nature by Shigehiro Katoh and a large international team has confirmed the age of the species to be 8 million years old.

column1: Another fossil probably belonging to the gorilla branch is Nakalipithecus from Kenya
column2: found also in 2007
column3: but dated to about 10 million years old.

column1: These fossils together constrain the age of the gorilla versus chimpanzee-human split to between 8 and 10 million years ago
column2: well within the range of estimates from molecular clocks.

column1: Big tick for the molecular clock.
What might this mean for Sahelanthropus
column2: Orrorin and Ardipithecus regarding our understanding of the human lineage?

column1: Well
column2: if these groups are indeed early humans
column3: then the human-chimp ancestor must have formed very quickly
column4: and just as quickly split to begin the human line; all within 1 or 2 million years.

column1: Alternatively
column2: if the detractors are correct
column3: and Sahelanthropus
column4: Orrorin and Ardipithecus turn out not be human
column5: then there’s a huge chunk of time
column6: 4-6 million to be precise
column7: for these events to occur
column8: and an even bigger gap in knowledge of our past.

column1: Perhaps the more remarkable thing about of all about this is just how similar the dates for Chororapithecus and Nakalipithecus are to the pioneering estimates of Zuckerkandl and Pauling
column2: published way back in 1962 using their crude protein clock.

column1: That’s a remarkable achievement in itself and testimony to the enduring role molecular clocks have played in evolutionary biology
column2: as well as hinting at a few lessons we might just wish to take on board from history.";When humans split from the apes;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiQWh0dHBzOi8vdGhlY29udmVyc2F0aW9uLmNvbS93aGVuLWh1bWFucy1zcGxpdC1mcm9tLXRoZS1hcGVzLTU1MTA00gEA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://images.theconversation.com/files/112265/original/image-20160222-25898-cixhdy.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop;02/22/2016;"[{'sent': 'If so
column3: which of the living Great Apes is the closest to humans?\n\n'
column4: 'ents': {'ORG': ['Great Apes']}}

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"MYRTLE BEACH
column2: SC — The internet is still swooning over a video of a chimpanzee using a cellphone and scrolling through Instagram. The video of the chimpanzee at a Myrtle Beach safari company illustrates similarities between humans and chimpanzees
column3: but some primatologists who study the behavior of our closest living relative and work to save them from extinction aren't loving it — at all.

column1: Myrtle Beach Safari founder Bhagavan Antle posted the video of the juvenile chimpanzee Kody on his Facebook page and it's since been picked up on Twitter
column2: Instagram and Reddit. Antle did not return Patch's attempts for comment
column3: both through the website and by Facebook Messenger.

column1: Chimpanzees are among the planet's most amazing animals
column2: sharing 98 percent of genetic DNA with humans. They're a lot like us in many other ways
column3: too.

column1: Published research has shown chimpanzees lead rich
column2: emotional lives and are capable of feeling emotions such as happiness and empathy. They use vocalizations to warn other chimpanzees in their troupes of approaching danger
column3: and have a repertoire of 58 gestures to communicate with each other. One study found chimpanzees and human toddlers 12 to 24 months of age share behaviors such as jumping
column4: hugging
column5: stomping and throwing objects.

column1: Given all that research has shown about chimpanzee behavior
column2: it's not a stretch to suggest that the Myrtle Beach chimpanzee was making choices about the Instagram photos
column3: primatologist Benjamin Beck
column4: who has written several books about great ape behavior
column5: told Patch.

column1: There is no scientific proof in the video but I would not be surprised if the chimp recognizes pictures and selects those he wants to look at
column2: Beck said
column3: emphasizing his comments were not intended as an endorsement of Myrtle Beach Safari or its operators.

column1: We know that chimpanzees do that with books
column2: magazines
column3: and tablets. They can recognize pictures of people
column4: other animals
column5: themselves
column6: places
column7: and foods
column8: and they choose to watch some pictures more often and for longer durations

column1: Noting that swiping — that is
column2: a finger motion to move from one image to another on a social platform such as Instagram — ""is not a common chimpanzee movement
column3: Beck said he was impressed by the chimpanzee's thumb mobility.

column1: And while ""there is evidence that seeing video of chimpanzees doing 'human-like things' leads human viewers to think they might make good pets
column2: Beck isn't too worried the video will spur widespread interest among U.S. citizens in obtaining a great ape as a pet. It's illegal to purchase chimpanzees and other great apes across state lines in the United States

column1: We should not rush to conclusions because we don't like the back story of pet chimpanzees and the commercial exploitation of apes in entertainment
column2: Beck said.

column1: But some primatologists
column2: including the legendary Jane Goodall
column3: cite the illegal pet trade as a key reason for their opposition to Antle's video and others like it on his Facebook page. Goodall called the video an ""awful portrayal"" of a chimpanzee in captivity and said it perpetuates both the illegal pet trade of great apes and the idea that they make ""cute pets.""

column1: The danger of keeping a chimpanzee as a pet was glaringly demonstrated in 2009 when Charla Nash
column2: a Connecticut woman
column3: was viciously attacked by Travis
column4: her friend's 200-pound pet chimpanzee. Nash received a face transplant after the chimp mangled her face
column5: leaving her without a nose
column6: eyes or lips. An infection spread by the ape left her permanently blind;

column1: In her statement
column2: Goodall said the interactions depicted in Antle's video are ""highly dangerous
column3: as well as harmful to the well-being of the chimpanzee.""

column1: As responsible and compassionate individuals
column2: I hope anyone who sees the video will not like
column3: share or comment on it and all responsible media outlets change the coverage of the video to highlight stories of chimpanzees in the wild or responsible captive care
column4: Goodall said in the statement. ""And I hope and urge the people who have chimpanzees in their care will cease use of him in this way and join those of us who are working to end the cruel treatment of chimpanzees in entertainment.""

column1: Primatologist Ashley Edes
column2: a postdoctoral fellow at the National Zoo
column3: wrote in a tweet that ""research has shown that sharing images [and] videos like this fuels the exotic pet trade
column4: which we never want to encourage.""

column1: About 3
column2: 000 great apes are stolen every year to supply the illegal pet trade
column3: but that number ""is only a fraction of the total number of apes captured for the live trade
column4: as apes are prone to high mortality rates during the trafficking process
column5: Orif Drori
column6: founder of the Last Great Ape Organization
column7: wrote for a report by the United Nations' Great Ape Survival Project.

column1: The international criminal network supplies a range of markets
column2: including the entertainment industry
column3: disreputable zoos and wealthy people who want exotic pets as status symbols
column4: the report said.

column1: In her tweet
column2: Edes wrote that ""animals in the pet trade experience horrific conditions [and] struggle when they're eventually surrendered.""

column1: Perhaps no organization knows that better than the Center for Great Apes in Florida
column2: where most of the chimpanzee and orangutan residents were rescued from either the entertainment industry or inappropriate living conditions such as basements
column3: garages
column4: tiny indoor cages and backyard cages.

column1: Exotic pet rescue situations are among our saddest 'before' stories because of the unnatural living conditions the apes endure
column2: Center for Great Apes explained on its website
column3: citing as examples Kiki and Linus
column4: two orangutans that lived for years without exposure to sunlight were barely able to walk when they arrived at the center
column5: let alone move from tree to tree
column6: as they would in the wild.

column1: Many of the chimpanzees and orangutans arrive with profound psychological damage and it takes years to properly rehabilitate them
column2: according to the Center for Great Apes.

column1: Beck said the Myrtle Beach Safari video may well ""raise appreciation for the sentience of apes

column1: Bonobos are also endangered
