column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"The question of where we humans come from is one many people ask
column2: and the answer is getting more complicated as new evidence is emerging all the time.

column1: For most of recorded history humankind has been placed on a metaphorical
column2: and sometimes literal
column3: pedestal. Sure
column4: modern humans were flesh and blood like other animals.

column1: But they were regarded as being so special that in the Linnaean taxonomy that prevailed well into the second half of the 20th century they were given their own family
column2: the Hominidae.

column1: Read more: Ancient DNA sheds light on the origin of Europeans
This distinguished them from the Pongidae
column2: the separate family used for the three African great apes – the common chimpanzee
column3: bonobo and gorilla – plus the orangutan from Southeast Asia.

column1: We now realise that modern humans are just one of the African great apes.
So when and how did this radically changed perception come about?
Early observations

In the 19th century the only evidence available for determining the closeness of the relationship between any two living animals was how similar they were in terms of what the naked eye could tell from their bones
column2: teeth
column3: muscles and organs.

column1: The first person to undertake a systematic comparative review of these differences between modern humans and the apes was English biologist Thomas Henry Huxley.
In the central section of a small book he published in 1863
column2: called Evidence as to Man’s Place in Nature
column3: Huxley concluded that the differences between modern humans and African apes were less than those between African apes and orangutans.

column1: This was the evidence the English naturalist Charles Darwin referred to in The Descent of Man in 1871.
He speculated that because African apes were morphologically closer to modern humans than the apes from Asia
column2: then the ancestors of modern humans were more likely to be found in Africa than elsewhere.

column1: A closer inspection

Developments in biochemistry and immunology during the first half of the 20th century enabled the search for evidence of the relationships between modern humans and the apes to shift from macroscopic morphology to the morphology of molecules.

The results of applying a new generation of analytical methods to proteins were reported by the Austrian-born French biologist Emile Zuckerkandl and American biologist Morris Goodman in the early 1960s.
Zuckerkandl used enzymes to break up the protein component of haemoglobin into its peptide components. He showed that the patterns of the peptides from modern humans
column2: gorilla and chimpanzee were indistinguishable.

column1: Goodman used a different method
column2: immunodiffusion
column3: to study albumin
column4: a serum protein. He showed that the patterns produced by the albumins of modern humans and the chimpanzee were identical. He concluded that this was because the albumin molecules were
column5: to all intents and purposes
column6: identical.

column1: Apes and humans: related
Proteins are made up of a string of amino acids and in many instances one amino acid can be substituted for another without changing the function of the protein.
In the late 1960s
column2: the American anthropologist Vince Sarich and New Zealand biologist Allan Wilson exploited these minor differences in protein structure and concluded that modern humans and the African apes were very closely related.

column1: They also provided the first molecular clock estimate of modern human-African ape divergence
column2: dating the split to only around five million years ago. This date was less than half of contemporary estimates based on fossil evidence.

column1: In 1975 the American human geneticist Mary-Claire King and Allan Wilson showed that 99% of the amino-acid sequences of chimpanzee and modern human blood proteins were identical.
Enter DNA
The discovery by James Watson and Francis Crick
column2: with unwitting help from Rosalind Franklin
column3: of the basic structure of DNA
column4: and the subsequent discovery by Crick and others of the nature of the genetic code
column5: meant that the relationships among organisms could be pursued at the level of the genome.

column1: Nowadays technological advances mean that whole genomes can be sequenced. Over the past decade researchers have published good draft sequences of the nuclear genomes of the chimpanzee
column2: orangutan
column3: gorilla and the bonobo.

column1: Shutterstock/Sergey Uryadnikov/Petr Masek/Sergey Uryadnikov/Eric Gevaert
More and better data are steadily being accumulated
column2: and in 2013 a review of ape DNA based on the genomes of 79 great apes was published.

column1: These new ape genome sequences support the results of earlier analyses of both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA that suggested modern humans and chimpanzees are more closely related to each other than either is to the gorilla.
When DNA differences among modern humans and the great apes are calibrated using the best palaeontological evidence for the split between the apes and the old world monkeys
column2: those differences predict that the hypothetical common ancestor of modern humans
column3: chimpanzees and bonobos lived about 8 million years ago.

column1: The rise of the hominins
Most researchers now recognise the modern human as hominins.
Still
column2: the question “where do we come from” can from a scientific perspective be difficult for someone outside of the discipline to come to grips with. In part this is because the fossil record for human evolution seems to grow exponentially
column3: with the author of each new discovery often claiming that the textbooks need to be rewritten.

column1: The interdisciplinary nature of palaeoanthropology also means that new evidence that helps us make sense of our ancestry does not always come in the form of new fossils.
It comes from advances in a range of disciplines that include archaeology
column2: comparative anatomy
column3: earth sciences
column4: evolutionary biology
column5: genomics and primatology.

column1: A further complicating factor is that the human fossil record does not just consist of the fossil evidence of our direct ancestors.
Many of the fossils belong to lineages that do not make it to the surface of the Tree of Life. They belong to extinct close relatives
column2: and the task of sorting close relatives from ancestors is one with which we are only just now beginning to grapple.

column1: There is a lineage that leads to today’s Homo sapiens
column2: but there are also a host of side experiments that are equally important to understand. They represent some of the most interesting chapters in human evolution.

column1: Origins of the genus Homo
Understanding the origins of our own genus Homo means establishing what fossils we recognise as being the first early humans.
Sometime before 4 million years ago we see the first evidence of the genus Australopithecus. These fossils sample the kind of creature that was most likely the ancestor to the genus Homo.
Around 2.5 million years ago we see the first fossil evidence of species in Africa that many argue belong to our own lineage. One of these
column2: Homo habilis
column3: almost certainly made stone tools
column4: had a slightly larger brain than Australopithecus
column5: stood upright and regularly walked on two legs.

column1: Some recognise a second species
column2: Homo rudolfensis
column3: about which we know even less.

column1: These possible human ancestors lived alongside close relatives that were almost certainly not our ancestors. These species are called Paranthropus or robust australopiths – they had small brains
column2: big jaw bones
column3: large flat faces
column4: and huge chewing teeth.

column1: They lasted for at least a million years
column2: so whatever they were eating (which is still a mystery) they were successful in the sense that they lasted as long in the fossil record as the average mammal.

column1: But some researchers think that Homo habilis and Homo rudolfensis are not different enough from the australopiths that preceded them to justify being included in the genus Homo.

They claim that the size and shape of their body and the size of their teeth and jaws was little different from that of the australopiths. This means that their locomotion and diet had not shifted far enough in the direction of pre-modern Homo species such as Homo erectus to justify inclusion in Homo.
Tool making is not enough
Also
column2: because it is becoming evident that australopiths may have been making tools earlier than Homo habilis it means that tool-making can no longer be seen as the sole prerogative of Homo.

column1: There is a developing consensus that the relaxation of the criteria more than 50 years ago that saw the inclusion of Homo habilis into the genus Homo needs to be reconsidered.
Species that emerge slightly later from Africa
column2: such as Homo ergaster
column3: fit much more clearly within what we understand by the genus Homo. That species probably left Africa around 2 million years ago and migrated ultimately as far east as China and Indonesia where it evolved
column4: eventually
column5: into Homo erectus.

column1: A number of further migrations out of Africa probably occurred after the initial Homo ergaster migration
column2: one of which
column3: Homo heidelbergensis
column4: is considered by many palaeoanthropologists to be the ancestor of both Neanderthals (Homo neanderthalensis) and modern humans (Homo sapiens).

column1: As far as we know
column2: Neanderthals evolved outside of Africa
column3: perhaps in response to the ice ages of Europe. Our ancestors remained in Africa where perhaps as early as 300
column4: 000 years ago
column5: as revealed from recent redating of the Moroccan site of Jebel Irhoud
column6: were well along in the process of evolving into modern humans.

column1: So the origins of ‘us’
Once we get to the origins of our own species Homo sapiens we have the added advantage that we are able to now use next generation sequencing methods to recover ancient DNA (aDNA).
As geneticists recover ancient genomes from different extinct hominin species
column2: they are generating insights that are not possible from comparing the anatomy of the fossils alone.

column1: There is now fossil evidence from teeth to suggest that Homo sapiens may have been in China by 120
column2: 000 years ago and in South East Asia by 67
column3: 000 years.

column1: The discovery of some distinctive modern human DNA within the DNA recovered from a Neanderthal fossil suggests that modest interbreeding was occurring between Neanderthals and modern humans in Central Asia by 100
column2: 000 years ago.

column1: Modern humans have not shared the planet with another hominin species for several tens of thousands of years. But before that
column2: in the past 300
column3: 000 years or so
column4: there is fossil and DNA evidence of several hominin species
column5: including the recently reported archaic hominin Homo naledi

column1: First and foremost there was Homo neanderthalensis
column2: whose range overlapped with modern humans in the Near East. Neanderthals most likely became extinct as a result of direct competition with the more technologically sophisticated Homo sapiens.

column1: The evidence from DNA shows that there was interbreeding between our species and pre-modern humans
column2: including the Neanderthals and the other enigmatic hominin referred to as the Denisovans.

column1: We do not yet know how and when Homo erectus became extinct. It would appear that another unexpected side experiment in hominin evolution
column2: known from the island of Flores and called Homo floresiensis most likely became extinct sometime after 60
column3: 000 years ago.

column1: Indeed this hominin may represent something far more significant than simply an interesting side experiment
column2: with many leading palaeoanthropologists arguing that the Hobbit may represent a pre-ergaster migration out of Africa.

column1: Read more: A 700
column2: 000-year-old fossil find shows the Hobbits’ ancestors were even smaller

column1: What next?
Even though thousands of hominin fossils have now been recovered and described there is still much work to be done.
Was there a hominin that successfully migrated out of Africa prior to Homo ergaster? Did most of human evolution occur in Africa? Did some important transitions occur outside of Africa?
When did Homo erectus become extinct
column2: and was there genetic exchange between erectus
column3: sapiens and perhaps other hominin species?

column1: As is often the case in science
column2: with the recovery of additional data
column3: in this case fossils and DNA extracted from fossils
column4: we generate more questions than answers.

column1: But ultimately all of this new evidence will result in a far more sophisticated appreciation of not only our evolution
column2: but also the evolution of our extinct fossil cousins.";The origin of ‘us’: what we know so far about where we humans come from;https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://images.theconversation.com/files/199881/original/file-20171219-27557-sri3mm.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop;01/07/2018;[{'sent': 'The question of where we humans come from is one many people ask
column3: and the answer is getting more complicated as new evidence is emerging all the time.\n\n'

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Her hunger growing
column2: she broke a short branch from a tree
column3: ripped off the side-shoots and leaves
column4: stripped down the bark
column5: and sharpened the end with her teeth. Jabbing this self-made spear into a tree hollow
column6: she struck lucky first time and dragged a screeching bushbaby from its sleeping space. With a few swift blows this chimpanzee had achieved her aim: dinner.

column1: It’s nearly 15 years since scientists first observed western chimpanzees – a critically endangered subspecies of the common chimpanzee – hunting with spears at a site in south-eastern Senegal. Native to western Africa
column2: western chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes verus) are the only chimps known to use spears. They also differentiate themselves by living in caves
column3: sharing food and travelling and foraging at night.

column1: Despite this chimp subspecies being well studied
column2: the data tend to be specific to particular localities. With no central database of findings
column3: it was hard for scientists to compare studies
column4: observe population trends or map out the density distribution of the animals. And these are the kinds of data that conservationists need to make evidence-based decisions on how best to protect the ape and where to prioritize conservation activities.

column1: To remedy this issue
column2: in 2005 scientists established the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Species Survival Commission Ape Populations
column3: Environments and Surveys database
column4: or APES
column5: to bring together survey data for all 14 taxa of great apes. Fourteen years later
column6: they are able to show the benefits achieved by sharing data this way
column7: and to demonstrate that similar databases would bring huge conservation benefits to other endangered species.

column1: For western chimpanzees
column2: APES collated 52 datasets collected during separate studies between 2001 and 2015 across nine different countries in West Africa.

column1: “For the first time we were able to model the distribution of western chimpanzee densities across their entire range
column2: ” says Stefanie Heinicke from the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology
column3: Germany.

column1: By comparing the chimp data with information on forest loss
column2: the researchers could see that western chimpanzees are highly sensitive to forest loss
column3: and that if a forest shrinks by more than 10% the chimps tend to disappear.

column1: The database has already had an impact
column2: demonstrating that western chimp numbers have declined by 80% since 1990 and providing the necessary evidence for the species to be updated to “critically endangered” on the IUCN’s Red List.

column1: In their most recent publication
column2: in Environmental Research Letters (ERL)
column3: Heinicke and colleagues reveal that only 17% of western chimps live in national parks
column4: and 10% of western chimps live within 25 km of four multinational “development corridors” currently planned for West Africa.

column1: “The results from our study can be used to estimate how many chimpanzees would likely be affected by such developments and advise on the locations where population connectivity might already be low and should therefore be avoided by new developments
column2: ” says Heinicke.

column1: As well as improving our understanding of western chimps
column2: this database has allowed researchers to get a handle on the distribution of bonobos
column3: central chimpanzees and the western lowland gorilla
column4: providing valuable input to the conservation action plans for these species.

column1: A handful of similar taxon-specific databases are in existence for other taxa
column2: but the researchers argue that rolling out these collaborative databases more widely would have huge conservation value.

column1: “These databases help to fill the gaps in biodiversity data and they provide the level of detail needed for conservation planning
column2: ” says Heinicke.

column1: Right now
column2: funding to create such databases is thin on the ground
column3: but Heinicke and her colleagues hope that the value of the information emerging from the APES database will encourage funders to adopt similar programmes for other taxa too.";One-tenth of western chimps live close to planned development corridors – Physics World;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiY2h0dHBzOi8vcGh5c2ljc3dvcmxkLmNvbS9hL29uZS10ZW50aC1vZi13ZXN0ZXJuLWNoaW1wcy1saXZlLWNsb3NlLXRvLXBsYW5uZWQtZGV2ZWxvcG1lbnQtY29ycmlkb3JzL9IBAA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://physicsworld.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/western-chimpanzee-1434024623-Shutterstock_Charlotte-Bleijenberg-.jpg;09/02/2019;[{'sent': 'Native to western Africa
column4: western chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes verus) are the only chimps known to use spears.'

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Scientists have learned that chimpanzees will ‘talk’ to each other using hand gestures with similar language rules to humans.
The primates will use language that
column2: ahem
column3: apes the way humans communicate with each other have learned.

column1: Experts made this discovery after studying videos of wild chimps living in Uganda’s Budongo Forest Reserve. Like other great apes
column2: chimpanzees lack the ability to speak but they use meaningful gestures
column3: much like deaf people signing to each other.

column1: Chimpanzee making a begging gesture (Getty Images)
The study found that chimp gestures are underpinned by mathematical patterns
column2: or linguistic laws
column3: similar to those seen in human language.

column1: The team from the University of Roehampton focused on two particular rules known to apply across the board of human languages.
One was Zipf’s law of abbreviation
column2: which predicts that more commonly used words tend to be shorter.

column1: The other was Menzerath’s law
column2: which predicts that larger linguistic structures are made up of shorter parts.

column1: Three chimps sitting on a rock in Gombe Stream National Park in Western Tanzania (Getty Images)
In the case of spoken language
column2: this translates to longer words consisting of shorter syllables.

column1: Advertisement
Advertisement
The scientists analysed more than 2
column2: 000 of around 58 different types of ‘play’ gesture employed by the Budongo Forest chimps.

column1: They found that
column2: as predicted by the two linguistic laws
column3: more frequently used gestures were shorter in duration
column4: and longer signing sequences were made up of shorter gesture ‘syllables’.

column1: Lead researcher Raphaela Heesen said: ‘Primate gestural communication is
column2: of course
column3: very different to human language
column4: but our results show that these two systems are underpinned by the same mathematical principles.’

column1: Monkey business (iStockphoto)
‘We hope that our work will pave the way for similar studies
column2: to see quite how widespread these laws might be across the animal kingdom.’

column1: As well as using hand and foot gestures
column2: chimps communicate with noises
column3: body postures and facial expressions.

column1: Research published in September last year showed that chimps and human toddlers employ similar stamping
column2: pointing
column3: and clapping tactics to get attention.

column1: The latest findings appear in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B.";Chimps communicate using the same language rules as humans;https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEL988hYtgPZPhztXy9wz51IqGQgEKhAIACoHCAowzc-JCzDQ5psDML6GogY?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://i0.wp.com/metro.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/sei_52066944-86e9_1550055744.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&w=1200&h=630&crop=1&zoom=1&ssl=1;02/13/2019;[{'sent': 'Experts made this discovery after studying videos of wild chimps living in Uganda’s Budongo Forest Reserve.'

column1: @IlWildTrade;@IlWildTrade;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Memories of 11 lions that were poisoned in Hamukungu village
column2: bordering Queen Elizabeth National Park are still fresh in Derrick Ajuna's mind. One afternoon
column3: in April 2018
column4: he was drawn to a scene with carcasses scattered about. Ajuna
column5: head guide of Kasoga Community Experience in the same area
column6: believes that many people within the community
column7: have not appreciated the value of wildlife.

column1: Even after the incident
column2: animals continue to destroy crops and feed on domestic animals. The community argues that if they benefitted from wild animals
column3: there would not be any problem
column4: he reveals.

column1: Expectations
With the new Uganda Wildlife Act 2019
column2: tourism stakeholders and conservationists are elated that stringent laws have been considered to protect wildlife and increase sustainability. President Museveni assented to The Wildlife Act on July 1

column1: The new law replaces the old Uganda Wildlife Act 1996
column2: which conservationists say
column3: was not deterrent enough. ""The previous law was weak. That is why we worked on a tougher one. From seven years to life imprisonment. We have the toughest wildlife conservation law in the wild
column4: declares Dr Barirega Akankwasa
column5: commissioner of Wildlife Conservation at the Ministry of Tourism
column6: Wildlife and Antiquities.

column1: Stringent penalties
The highest penalty in the new Act is a maximum fine of Shs20 billion or life imprisonment
column2: or both for an offence related to a wildlife species classified as extinct in the wild
column3: critically endangered. These include the roan antelope
column4: lion
column5: hunting dog
column6: spotted and stripped hyena
column7: greater and lesser kudu
column12: and endangered species such as impala
column15: mountain gorilla and the common chimpanzee.

column1: A person who
column2: without a permit takes
column3: hunts
column4: molests or reduces into possession protected specimen or is found with
column5: sells
column6: buys
column7: transfers or accepts transfer of protected specimen
column8: commits an offence and shall on conviction
column9: be liable to a maximum fine of Shs200 million or to a jail term or both.

column1: The Act also gives court powers to fine a first-time offender
column2: Shs7 million or to a term of imprisonment
column3: not exceeding 10 years
column4: or both. Second time or subsequent offenders are required to pay a fine of Shs10 million or serve a maximum jail term of 20 years
column5: or both.

column1: The punishment for use of weapons
column2: traps
column3: explosives is Shs100 million fine or 10 years imprisonment
column4: or both. This also applies to persons who unlawfully prepare land for cultivation
column5: mining or those who take
column6: destroy
column7: damage or deface any object of geomorphological

column1: Human-wildlife conflicts
UWA reports from 2009 to 2017
column2: reveal more than 13
column3: 000 human wildlife conflicts
column4: involving livestock predation by lions and leopards
column5: elephant crop damage as well as hippo
column6: buffalo and chimpanzee attacks. Between 1996 and 2009
column7: 300 crocodile attacks were recorded. Among these
column8: 247 deaths and 63 survival cases were recorded. Stray animals have turned areas around Queen Elizabeth
column9: Murchison Falls Conservation Area and Kidepo Valley National Park into conflict hotspots. Since 2009
column10: the number of human-wildlife conflict has risen by more than 22 per cent.

column1: Compensation

The new law provides for compensation for loss occasioned by animals escaping from wildlife protected areas. Communities near protected areas have for long cast blame on Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA) for delayed response when animals cross to community farmlands and feed on both their crops and domestic animals.
According to the Act
column2: compensation will be given to a person who suffers body injury or is killed or suffers damage of his or her property by wild animals. This will be effected when the person's legal representative submits a claim to the wildlife compensation verification committee. The committee shall verify a claim and submit it to the board together with its recommendation. The board will then review the claim and if approved
column3: compensate victims according to the market rates.

column1: Highlighted concerns
However
column2: some stakeholders have expressed concern about compensatable animal list . ""I am concerned about the implementation. It is going to be difficult to value the damage. Even with the presence of the verification committee
column3: I do not know how transparent the process is going to be. Many species of animals were left out of this arrangement. For example
column4: among the primates
column5: they considered baboons
column6: mountain gorillas
column7: and chimpanzees. Vervet monkeys which raid our crops are left out. Some communities have been reported to grow crops along gazetted conservation areas with the intention of getting compensated
column8: when animals raid their gardens. All those issues need to be addressed
column10: founder of Kibale Association for Rural and Environmental Development (KAFRED) based in Kamwenge District.

column1: Compensatable wildlife
According to the Act
column2: section 84(1)(b)
column3: the compensatable wildlife species that cause damage to property are elephant
column4: buffalo
column5: lion
column6: leopard
column7: hippo
column10: chimpanzee and bushpig. The compensatable wildlife species that cause death and injury are elephant

column1: Wildlife funds
The new law has reforms on the revenue sharing programme. The board shall authorise the executive director of UWA to pay 20 per cent of the park entry fees
column2: collected from a wildlife protected area
column3: to the local government of the area surrounding the wildlife protected zone from which the fees were collected
column4: as a conditional grant.

column1: Akankwasa
column2: a member of the UWA board of trustees
column3: says there is no longer room for diversion of funds. ""Previously
column4: money was sent to local government
column5: as their revenue and they could use it for allowances or spend it any way
column6: they deemed fit. Now funds will go as conditional grants for specific community projects
column7: such as building a classroom block""

column1: Dr Caroline Asiimwe
column2: a veterinarian and conservation coordinator at Budongo Conservation Field Station (BCFS) wishes the fund was availed to communities near forest reserves. ""Much as 20 per cent is given to communities around protected areas which are national parks
column3: consideration should be made for those living around forest reserves
column4: where there is also wildlife and the communities are suffering the damages from animals such as baboons
column5: she says.

column1: Commercial agreement
The new law favours commercialisation of wildlife on private land through sustainable utilisation. The executive director of UWA may
column2: with the approval of the board
column3: enter into any suitable commercial or collaborative arrangement with any person for: the management of a conservation area or a portion
column4: provision of services and infrastructure in a conservation area or the management of a species or a class of species of animals or plants.

column1: Makerere University don and wildlife researcher Dr Amos Ochieng argues that collaborative commercial arrangements to manage conservation areas is a well thought out idea
column2: adding that
column3: ""Wildlife management should be treated as a land use activity to offer opportunities for economic and social benefits. Wildlife is found on both protected and private land. Collaboration with private land owners to manage conservation areas will offer more chances of wildlife survival outside protected areas.""

column1: Reactions
The new Wildlife Act 2019 has generated mixed reactions among tourism and conservation stakeholders. Gillian Josephine
column2: a tour operator based in northern Uganda
column3: applauds the idea of giving 20 per cent to communities as conditional grants.

column1: That is good for conservation initiatives in the communities
column2: since those community projects will have direct tangible effects to them. They will 'own conservation' as opposed to the 'I do not care' about wildlife attitude. The act will also lead to reduction in the wildlife-human conflicts because there is now compensation for problems which animals cause to communities. My people of Nwoya and those around Karenga
column3: Orom can now take up conservation programmes seriously
column4: she says.

column1: Honest and fair committee
Tinka
column2: whose association manages Bigodi Sanctuary
column3: is concerned about the composition of the Community Wildlife Committee (CWC). He hopes the CWC will be fair and honest because it is composed of many government officials and only a handful of community members.

column1: For the case of Kibaale
column2: we have someone from Kamwenge District Local Government
column3: Kyenjojo
column4: Kabarole
column5: Bunyangabu
column6: Kasese
column7: one from a non-governmental organisation (NGO) and Community Development Officer (CDO). But from the wildlife interpretation
column8: a community means people who come from parishes that make the park's boundary. I am hoping that they will invite representatives from these parishes to form part of the committee

column1: Composition of the committee
Every wildlife conservation area will have a community wildlife committee which will act as a link between UWA and the local community. The composition of the CWC is a representative of UWA
column2: who shall be the secretary of the committee
column3: a representative of each of the district local government surrounding the conservation area
column4: a wildlife conservation NGO operating around the conservation area and a representative of a community wildlife association
column5: operating within the wildlife conservation area. The members of the CWC shall be appointed by the minister of Tourism
column6: Wildlife and Antiquities
column7: in consultation with the UWA board. By definition in the Act
column8: a community is an assemblage of human beings
column9: living in a defined geographical area and identified by a common history
column10: a common culture or a common residence in that area.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Freud
column2: Wilkie and the other chimpanzees peacefully fed and rested in the sun-dappled Tanzanian forest. Mzee Hilali stood next to me
column3: writing notes on the chimpanzees’ behavior
column4: as he had been doing for over 30 years as a field assistant for Jane Goodall’s long-term study at Gombe National Park.

column1: Suddenly
column2: a strange
column3: high-pitched call sounded from where some other chimpanzees were feeding
column4: about a hundred meters from us. Hilali turned to me
column5: and with a little laugh
column6: said
column7: “Nyoka.” This was the Swahili word for “snake.”

column1: Freud climbed down from his tree and walked quickly toward where the call had sounded
column2: with Hilali following close behind. As I slowly made my way through the undergrowth to catch up with them
column3: Hilali called to me: “Chatu!” “Python!”

column1: When I caught up with Hilali
column2: he was pointing to a tangled mass of leaves and vines on the forest floor. I looked closely – most of the snake lay hidden from view
column3: but the one visible stretch of black and tan scaly hide was too big to be anything but a python.

column1: From years of experience
column2: Mzee Hilali knew instantly that this particular chimp call meant they’d found a snake. Does this mean that chimpanzees have a “word” for snake? Do chimpanzees have a language of their own? I’ve been working with a team of students and Tanzanian field assistants to record and analyze chimpanzee vocalizations in an effort to answer questions like this. Ultimately we hope to learn more about how human language first evolved.

column1: Clues to the origins of language
Chimpanzees are among human beings’ closest living relatives
column2: and they share with us many unusual traits. Like humans
column3: chimps make and use tools; join together in groups to hunt animals like monkeys; defend group territories; and sometimes gang up on and kill their enemies.

column1: One trait that seems to set humans apart from every other species
column2: however
column3: is a fully developed language. Other animals communicate
column4: but only humans appear able to talk about an unlimited variety of topics. Language enables us to make plans
column5: negotiate with and teach one another.

column1: How and why language evolved remains a mystery. Much of the evidence of human evolution comes from fossils
column2: but fossil bones don’t tell us much about soft tissues or the sounds early human ancestors made. Studying the communication patterns of our living relatives can help solve the mystery.

column1: If some features of chimpanzee communication resemble language
column2: we can study chimpanzees further to find clues for why those features evolved. If chimpanzee communication doesn’t share much in common with human language
column3: then the key steps in language evolution must have occurred after our lineages separated (around 7.9 million years ago) for reasons unique to our human lineage.

column1: Recording in the forest
To investigate chimp communication
column2: my colleagues and I follow chimpanzees through the forest as they go about their lives. We carry a hand-held “shotgun” microphone and a digital recorder
column3: waiting for them to call.

column1: Usually we pick a particular chimp to follow each day
column2: trying to get equal numbers of calls per individual. In addition to recording new calls
column3: we’ve been working to build an archive of recordings from other researchers
column4: going back to the 1970s. The archive currently contains over 71 hours of recordings.

column1: Snake alarm calls are intriguing
column2: but because chimps don’t encounter large snakes very often
column3: it is hard to do a systematic study of them. (Cathy Crockford and colleagues have done some interesting experiments
column4: though
column5: playing back recordings of these calls to see how chimpanzees respond and presenting them with model snakes). One thing chimpanzees do every single day
column6: though
column7: is eat. Chimpanzees spend most of their time looking for food and eating it. And when they find food
column8: they often give a particular kind of call: the rough-grunt.

column1: A chimpanzee rough-grunt.
Biologist Lisa O'Bryan studied rough-grunt calls for her dissertation research with me. They vary from low
column2: noisy grunts to higher-pitched calls. Some researchers have proposed an intriguing possibility: Maybe chimpanzees make distinct kinds of rough-grunt calls in response to particular foods
column3: rather like words that name certain food items.

column1: But Lisa has found that when eating any one kind of food
column2: chimpanzees can produce a range of different rough-grunts. Rough-grunts thus tell other chimps that the caller is eating
column3: but they don’t say what’s for dinner.

column1: Just as a particular alarm call informs others that a snake has been found
column2: the thin
column3: wavering tones of a copulation scream announce that a mating has just taken place.

column1: Author provided 14.6 KB (download) A chimpanzee copulation scream.

Why female chimpanzees sometimes give such a scream just as they finish mating remains unknown. Because the data collected by Mzee Hilali and other field assistants since the 1970s have been entered into a computer database
column2: we can readily examine thousands of different mating events.

column1: My student Tony Massaro has been analyzing these data to try to tease out what factors make females more likely to produce these calls. Such calls aren’t particularly word-like
column2: but they do play an important role in communication. Like many wordless sounds that people make – think laughter
column3: screams and crying – listeners hearing the sounds can infer quite a bit about the caller’s situation.

column1: When Jane Goodall gives public talks
column2: she often begins by giving a pant-hoot: a loud call that begins with an introduction
column3: followed by a build-up
column4: a climax and a let-down. Pant-hoots are loud and enable chimpanzees to communicate over long distances through the forest.

column1: Previous studies have found differences in the pant-hoots calls from different regions. For example
column2: the pant-hoots from Gombe sound a bit different from those made by chimpanzees in Mahale
column3: 160 km away. When I played recordings of a single Mahale pant-hoot call to chimpanzees in Kibale Forest
column4: Uganda
column5: the Kibale chimpanzees acted as if they had just heard an intruder. If they were in a group with three or more males
column6: they gave a loud vocal response and rapidly moved towards the speaker.

column1: If they were in a group with only one or two males present
column2: though
column3: they stayed quiet
column4: and if they approached
column5: did so slowly and cautiously.

column1: For chimpanzees
column2: correctly telling friend from foe is a matter of life or death
column3: so it would make sense for chimpanzees in neighboring groups to have distinctive pant-hoot calls.

column1: Cathy Crockford and colleagues found that pant-hoots from different communities within Taï Forest
column2: Côte d'Ivoire
column3: also sound distinct. If such group-level differences result from vocal learning
column4: they would be rather like dialects in human languages.

column1: My student Nisarg Desai has been testing whether this is also the case at Gombe. We’ve been working with a team of Tanzanian field assistants
column2: Hashimu Issa Salala and Nasibu Zuberi Madumbi
column3: to record calls from the Mitumba and Kasekela chimpanzees
column4: and are starting to test for differences between groups.

column1: We are in the early stages of this analysis.
From calls to language isn’t a clear path
Chimpanzees might be capable of some degree of vocal learning
column2: but I’m struck by how subtle the differences in pant-hoot calls are from place to place. Chimpanzees make lots of different calls – pant-hoots
column3: pant-barks
column4: waa-barks
column5: pant-grunts
column6: rough-grunts
column7: and so on – but across Africa
column8: all chimpanzees produce a pretty similar set of calls in similar circumstances. In this respect
column9: chimpanzee calls resemble human sounds like laughter and crying more than they resemble human words
column10: which can vary drastically from place to place.

column1: Chimpanzees communicate effectively with their various sounds
column2: but in ways quite similar to those of other nonhuman primates. This suggests that our common ancestor with chimpanzees also had a fairly typical repertoire of vocal communication for a nonhuman primate. The really big changes in human language – such as a lifelong ability to learn to make entirely new sounds and a rich symbolic meaning of such sounds – likely evolved later
column3: for reasons that we still don’t understand.";Studying chimpanzee calls for clues about the origins of human language;https://news.google.?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://images.theconversation.com/files/218089/original/file-20180508-34006-g309sg.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0&rect=0%2C31%2C998%2C498&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop;05/08/2018;"[{'sent': 'Freud
column4: Wilkie and the other chimpanzees peacefully fed and rested in the sun-dappled Tanzanian forest.'

column2: Mo. – The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri has just granted PETA’s motion for summary judgment against Andrew Sawyer
column3: who boarded a chimpanzee named Joey in solitary confinement at the Missouri Primate Foundation from 2013 to 2016
column4: when PETA sent a required notice of intent to sue under the Endangered Species Act (ESA)—and Sawyer absconded with Joey to an undisclosed location.

column1: The district court has now ruled that Sawyer violated the ESA by failing to meet Joey’s fundamental social
column2: physical
column3: and psychological needs; terminated his ownership of the chimpanzee; and ordered counsel for PETA and Sawyer to agree on an acceptable accredited sanctuary where Joey can live for the rest of his life.

column1: “After years of isolation in substandard conditions at the Missouri Primate Foundation
column2: Joey finally has a future
column3: ” says PETA Foundation Deputy General Counsel for Animal Law Jared Goodman. “At a proper sanctuary
column4: he’ll have space to roam
column5: expert care
column6: and the opportunity to interact with other members of his highly social species.”

column1: PETA—whose motto reads
column2: in part
column3: that “animals are not ours to use for entertainment or abuse in any other way”—opposes speciesism
column4: which is a human-supremacist worldview. More information about the Missouri Primate Foundation is available here.";Update: Court Orders Chimpanzee’s Move to Sanctuary;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiW2h0dHBzOi8vd3d3LnBldGEub3JnL21lZGlhL25ld3MtcmVsZWFzZXMvdXBkYXRlLWNvdXJ0LW9yZGVycy1jaGltcGFuemVlcy1tb3ZlLXRvLXNhbmN0dWFyeS_SAQA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://www.peta.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/peta-facebook-placeholder-new.jpg;11/21/2019;"[{'sent': 'For Immediate Release:\n\n'

A captive chimpanzee has reunited with her carer who raised it as an infant 40 years ago.
Jessie
column2: a 41-year-old female chimpanzee
column3: recognised the elderly woman when she showed up in front of her enclosure at Wellington Zoo in the capital city of the same name in New Zealand.

column1: Heartwarming footage captured Jessie and her carer's first encounter four decades later.
The carer
column2: whose name has not been revealed
column3: is seen trying to get Jessie’s attention.

column1: Jessie
column2: the matriarch of the zoo's population
column3: appears to recognise the woman and the chimpanzee outstretches her hand for her to ""touch"" through the glass separating them.

column1: (Image: Newsflash/Wellington Zoo)
Meanwhile
column2: a woman in the background is heard saying “aww” as the pair reconnect.

column1: The zoo posted the clip on its Facebook page and accompanies with a message that read: ""Watch this touching moment between Jessie
column2: our 41-year-old female Chimpanzee and a volunteer that knew her when she was a baby.

column1: We're not crying
column2: you're crying!""

column1: A spokesperson for Wellington Zoo said: ""Jessie came over pretty quickly and it seemed like she knew her.""
According to reports
column2: Jessie
column3: who turns 42 in July
column4: is Wellington Zoo’s oldest chimpanzee.

column1: Chimpanzees are around six times stronger than humans and are highly intelligent animals
column2: the zoo introduced.

column1: They are able to learn sign language
column2: recognise themselves in the mirror
column3: and can make and use tools.

column2: a drunk man in Poland has jumped into a bear enclosure in a sickening attempt to drown the animal in the water while a farmer dubbed a two-headed
column3:

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"West Africa’s chimpanzee population has dropped dramatically since the 1960s
column2: falling from an estimated 1 million to fewer than 300
column3: 000 today.

column1: Across West Africa
column2: a network of sanctuaries is working to provide shelter for chimpanzees rescued from traffickers.

column1: Members of the Pan African Sanctuary Alliance say their work goes beyond simply caring for individual apes
column2: extending to protecting wild chimpanzee populations and supporting the people who share their habitats.

column1: In the 1960s
column2: there were an estimated 1 million wild chimpanzees in West Africa. Today
column3: there are fewer than 300
column4: 000. With habitat loss
column5: hunting and wildlife trafficking taking their toll
column6: chimps have now disappeared completely from four countries in the region. That makes the western chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes verus) the only one of the four chimp subspecies to be declared critically endangered.

column1: At the forefront of the battle to save the western chimpanzee is a network of sanctuaries. These safe havens can have a dramatic effect on the countries where they are established
column2: caring for individual animals while also working to help stabilize populations
column3: tighten laws
column4: and stop the illegal trade in wildlife from flourishing.

column1: Twenty-three organizations operate as part of the Pan African Sanctuary Alliance (PASA)
column2: which was established in 2000 and now looks after 915 chimps in 13 countries. Many arrive as the result of habitat destruction
column3: as forests are cleared for agriculture
column4: logging and extractive industries
column5: as well as infrastructure developments
column6: decimating family groups and leaving young chimps abandoned.

column1: Others will have suffered at the hands of hunters
column2: victims of a lucrative trade that sees adults shot for bushmeat and juveniles sold on the black market to end up as pets or as entertainment in hotels
column3: circuses and zoos in Africa and beyond.

column1: Underpinning anti-trafficking efforts
While conservationists largely support the work of sanctuaries
column2: there have been criticisms that they use funds that could be better used to protect wild populations
column3: that their methods lack scientific rigor
column4: and that they focus too much on individual animals rather looking at the bigger conservation picture.

column1: What sanctuaries offer
column2: says PASA executive director Greg Tully
column3: is somewhere for the authorities to put confiscated chimps. Where they don’t exist
column4: trafficking is rife
column5: the authorities turn a blind eye
column6: and the country often becomes a hub for the illegal trade.

column1: “In countries that don’t have sanctuaries
column2: wildlife law enforcement is a lot weaker
column3: ” Tully says. “Police and other law enforcement agencies don’t want to arrest someone who has a live chimpanzee if there’s nowhere to put it — they don’t want to be taking care of a baby chimp for the next 50 years.”

column1: In recent years
column2: Côte d’Ivoire has become a center for animal trafficking
column3: as efforts to create a national chimp sanctuary have stalled.

column1: “The destruction of the environment is at a level that is unseen anywhere else in Africa
column2: ” says Estelle Raballand
column3: who has worked in West Africa for the last 25 years
column4: the last three spearheading the push to create the Akatia sanctuary near the Ivorian capital
column5: Abidjan.

column1: Around 80% of the country’s forests were lost between 1960 and 2010. The government “has refused to have a sanctuary for many
column2: many years and now they have lost almost all their forest and they’ve lost almost all their chimps
column3: ” Raballand says. “They have no management whatsoever of the wildlife trade.”

column1: The few chimps that are confiscated are sent to the local zoo
column2: which have neither the capacity not the skill to care for them
column3: she says.

column1: But Raballand says she remains hopeful. A new memorandum of understanding is on the table that could establish the Akatia sanctuary. The Côte d’Ivoire government did not respond to requests from Mongabay for confirmation about whether it was likely to succeed
column2: or to comment on the country’s management of the wildlife trade.

column1: David Greer
column2: who also worked in primate conservation for 25 years
column3: including a stint at the WWF and running a wildlife sanctuary
column4: says he agrees that sanctuaries play a pivotal role in chimp conservation. But he says he also fears that unless they adopt a more proactive approach to law enforcement
column5: they risk becoming dumping grounds where the rich can get rid of their chimp status symbols with impunity.

column1: “They essentially go and dump these animals on the sanctuary’s doorsteps
column2: with no repercussion whatsoever
column3: ” he says. When sanctuaries accept an animal
column4: he says
column5: part of the deal with the authorities must be that the poachers
column6: traders and those who illegally own chimpanzees are prosecuted and proper sentences are handed down.

column1: “Sanctuaries and big wildlife conservation organizations have to hold the government’s feet to the fire
column2: ” he says. “[They] need to enforce the law and establish deterrents.”

column1: “In many African countries
column2: the laws about wildlife are sadly outdated
column3: ” says PASA director Tully. “The penalties might be a couple of dollars … and maybe a night in jail
column4: which for someone making thousands of dollars smuggling endangered species
column5: is just part of doing business.”

column1: Although largely supportive of sanctuaries
column2: Greer says he believes there are other ways in which they could support the wider conservation movement
column3: too. “They provide a humane setting for these animals to live out the remainders of their lives but that also comes with some responsibilities
column4: ” he says. “A lot of the sanctuaries work in a bubble and aren’t necessarily as collaborative as they could be.”

column1: Most are reluctant to be audited
column2: he says
column3: or reveal details about the activities they are undertaking
column4: their performance and their conservation impact. As a result
column5: “It is difficult to measure whether these activities are having a positive impact on conservation objectives in the field.”

column1: Sanctuary managers are passionate
column2: Greer says
column3: but they’re rarely traditionally trained conservationists. “Some of them are just so busy trying to ensure the welfare of the animals they are maintaining in captivity that they don’t have much time to develop strategic planning or project impact monitoring
column4: ” he says.

column1: Many are also having to deal with a new threat
column2: in the form of COVID-19. “Great apes are very susceptible to human respiratory diseases
column3: as we share 98% of the same DNA
column4: ” Tully says. As a result
column5: sanctuaries are taking extra precautions to minimize the risk of coronavirus affecting the animals
column6: with many staff remaining on site 24/7 to reduce the risk of bringing the chimps into contact with the virus.

column1: Kay Farmer
column2: who helped establish the Limbe sanctuary in Cameroon
column3: and has since completed a Ph.D. in chimpanzee reintroduction
column4: describes sanctuaries as “a very visible example of failed conservation.” If conservation was working
column5: she says
column6: chimpanzees wouldn’t be coming into the sanctuaries.

column1: It’s also easy to miss the point about why sanctuaries exist in the first place
column2: she says. “Their raison d’être is rescuing these animals … which arrive in the most appalling conditions
column3: ” she says. “The majority are traumatized
column4: dehydrated
column5: they might have bullet wounds … They are experts at providing the triage … and getting those animals well again.”

column1: Running a sanctuary is often a hand-to-mouth existence
column2: Farmer says
column3: with a constant battle to find operational funding. “Sanctuaries quite simply haven’t got the time or the income to be carrying out audits and collect evidence and stats
column4: ” she says. “When you’ve got to feed your animals and pay your staff
column5: a strategic plan often isn’t at the top of your agenda.”

column1: A distinction has also been made between individual animal welfare
column2: as practiced by the sanctuaries
column3: and protection on a population level
column4: as championed by intentional conservation groups
column5: Farmer says. As a result
column6: many of the bigger funders simply won’t give to sanctuaries.

column1: “There’s just not enough funding and people view each other as competition
column2: ” she says.

column1: This theoretical competition for funds is another reason why sanctuaries have been criticized
column2: but it’s a point Tully is quick to refute. “The money for conservation and the money for animal welfare are largely two different pots of money
column3: ” he says
column4: with few donors giving to both.

column1: Beyond animal welfare
While chimp welfare may be their key purpose
column2: many sanctuaries fill a much wider role too. In 1999
column3: Raballand took the post of project manager at Chimpanzee Conservation Center (CCC) in Guinea’s Haut Niger National Park
column4: which now boasts the highest density of chimpanzees of any West African protected area.

column1: The sanctuary helps run the national park
column2: supplies rangers for anti-poaching and logging patrols
column3: and contributes significantly to the local economy
column4: buying more than 5 tons of food a month and employing 30 permanent staff.

column1: The center also works with local villages. By integrating communities into conservation initiatives
column2: Raballand says
column3: people become “drivers of change” and develop a much greater respect for local biodiversity
column4: leading to far fewer conflicts between humans and chimpanzees.

column1: “Community development and education is a critical part of what we do
column2: ” Tully says. Sanctuaries are there for the long term
column3: he says
column4: and this allows them to build up trust with communities
column5: play a role in alleviating poverty
column6: and develop better relationships with the authorities.

column1: “A sanctuary isn’t just about taking care of the animals. They have strong connections with the government and have spent years pushing to make changes happen and get government officials to realize that these chimpanzees have value as an iconic species
column2: ” Tully says.

column1: The Tacugama sanctuary in Sierra Leonne was set up by Sri Lankan-born Bala Amarasekaran in 1995
column2: and since then its success has been based on a mixture of hard work and shrewd diplomacy.

column1: “Other sanctuaries and conservation organizations talk of road blocks and problems with government – I have never experienced that
column2: ” Amarasekaran says. “We work very closely with the government and they don’t look at us as an outside entity. Tacugama is considered to be one of theirs.”

column1: One of Amarasekaran’s key achievements has been persuading the government to declare the chimpanzee the national animal. It gave him the leverage to push for changes to Sierra Leone’s out-of-date wildlife laws too
column2: and give the new national symbol greater protection against traffickers and poachers. “You can’t make the chimpanzee the national animal and then not have laws to protect it
column3: ” he says.

column1: Yet in all this
column2: Amarasekaran says he is careful to make sure it is the authorities
column3: not the sanctuary
column4: that takes the plaudits. “You focus on the goal
column5: not about who did it.”

column1: Babar Turay
column2: a conservation manager at Sierra Leone’s National Protected Area Authority
column3: an agency within the Ministry of Agriculture
column4: Forestry and Food Security
column5: has worked closely with Amarasekaran. “If we didn’t have Tacugama
column6: where would we be taking all these captured chimpanzees?” he says. “Do you just capture them and return them to the forest? [Then] they will be vulnerable and people will capture them again.”

column1: Because of their autonomy
column2: Turay says sanctuaries have an important role to play in “making a noise
column3: ” raising international and community awareness
column4: and forcing governments into action. “That is the power that we do not have directly
column5: ” he says.

column1: At Tacugama
column2: Amarasekaran says
column3: we “don’t just focus on confiscations and running an orphanage; we are movement
column4: we do a lot more.”

column1: The sanctuary has been running an outreach program for 12 years and now works with 70 communities across Sierra Leone. These strong community links also help with law enforcement. Recently
column2: when animal traffickers were tipped off that the authorities were closing in
column3: they fled. However
column4: Amarasekaran was able to go on the radio and make a plea to local communities that their national animal was under threat. Within 30 minutes they were inundated with phone calls about the poachers’ whereabouts. “People felt a sense of duty
column5: ” he says.

column1: Tacugama also runs eco-lodges and yoga retreats
column2: providing employment and reinforcing the idea that primates are more valuable alive than dead.

column1: “If you don’t create some sort of a value for the people … in the areas that we are asking them to protect
column2: how are they going to protect these places?” he says. “If that connection is not made
column3: then we are wasting our time.”

column1: Ecotourism is also an important income stream for the project
column2: he says. Big conservation groups might get multimillion-dollar research grants
column3: but sanctuaries don’t attract that kind of money. “Sanctuaries are sometimes considered to be some roadside circus
column4: ” Amarasekaran says.

column1: “We are a very proud organization
column2: ” he says. “We don’t go around with our hat begging. Sixty percent of our operational costs come from within
column3: by our own initiatives.”

column1: While Amarasekaran describes reintroductions as “every sanctuary manager’s dream
column2: ” the reality can be different. Rehabilitating and releasing a chimpanzee back into the wild is expensive.

column1: Space is also at a premium
column2: Amarasekaran says. Sierra Leone only has around 6% of its natural forest left and it’s impossible to release chimps into an area where other wild chimps already exist
column3: and pointless re-releasing them where they can’t be given any protection. So
column4: he says
column5: “we have decided to focus on the 5
column7: 000 chimps that are still left in the wild and … on stopping them coming to the sanctuary.”

column1: Tully says he agrees. “Great ape reintroductions are extremely complicated
column2: expensive
column3: and time-consuming
column4: and aren’t possible in many countries because of the high risk of poaching and weak enforcement of protected areas
column5: ” he says. “It’s not just a case of opening a cage door and letting them go.”

column1: Most PASA sanctuaries are huge forest enclosures where young chimpanzees can learn to climb
column2: to socializes
column3: and to recognize dangers
column4: such as venomous snakes. But in all
column5: PASA has released just 61 chimpanzees back into the wild
column6: although 200 more live on large islands
column7: where they can mix with other chimp populations and remain safe while living with little human care.

column1: “For these reasons
column2: while PASA members would like to reintroduce more primates to the wild
column3: it isn’t a top priority
column4: ” Tully says. “To me

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Sign up to FREE email alerts from DerbyshireLive - Daily Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Invalid Email
Staff at Twycross Zoo have admitted they are ""fighting to protect its future"" as it falls further into debt while its gates are closed due to the coronavirus pandemic.
Today
column2: May 26
column3: marks the 100-acre zoo's 57th birthday after first opening its doors in 1963. Back then it enjoyed record-breaking visitor numbers in its opening year.

column1: However
column2: in stark contrast
column3: the zoo
column4: which is home to 500 animals from 125 species
column5: is now struggling to raise the £650
column6: 000 a month it needs to keep operating
column7: having been closed for almost three months.

column1: Dr Sharon Redrobe
column2: CEO of Twycross Zoo
column3: said: ""This milestone is bittersweet for us.

column1: It's an incredible achievement to be open for 57 years
column2: however without our visitors it's not as happy as it should be.

column1: We're experiencing a very uncertain time
column2: and we've never been closed this long in our history.""

column1: While the Government has set up a fund to help some small zoos
column2: Twycross Zoo is not eligible as its too large
column3: with bosses there saying different support is desperately needed from the Government to protect its future and and its animals.

column1: Dr Redrobe added: ""In order to keep operating the zoo has been relying on its reserves
column2: which run out in June
column3: as well as donations from its many supporters.

column1: It is vital that this work continues in support of the UK's commitment to global biodiversity.
It still costs us over half a million pounds a month to run the zoo even while we're closed
column2: and there are no grants from the Government for large zoos like us undertaking critical conservation work and caring for such large groups of endangered species.

column1: Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
Every day we are shut is getting us more into debt.
We are hopeful as a 100-acre outdoor site with plenty of space that we will be able to reopen to visitors in the not too distant future.
While we've been shut we have worked to ensure our staff have a safe environment and we have been working on measures to observe social distancing and hygiene guidelines on site for our visitors.
We are working on many changes to how we operate to ensure that when we do open we will be 'Covid-19 secure' in line with all Government guidelines
column2: and we will share details of this soon.

column1: Opening again will provide a Covid-19 secure environment for families to relax and enjoy nature
column2: as well as some much-needed income and a sigh of relief for the future of our zoo.""

column1: Sad loss of one of the zoo's apes
The zoo has also announced the death of its elderly chimpanzee
column2: Tojo
column3: on May 20.

column1: The ape
column2: who had previously been diagnosed with heart disease
column3: had been under the weather for a few days.

column1: The zoo's expert team needed to do a full medical check to find out what was wrong and start any treatment and
column2: of course chimpanzees need an anaesthetic for this
column3: but unfortunately
column4: despite best efforts
column5: she was too poorly to recover from general anaesthetic
column6: said a spokesman.

column1: Tojo
column2: was 43 years old and came to Twycross Zoo in 1980.

column1: Twycross started from humble beginnings when founders Molly Badham and Nathalie Evans had a love of primates and created the zoo after outgrowing their small site in Hints
column2: Staffordshire and moving to Twycross to open the zoo in 1963.

column1: Since then the zoo has evolved into a world-renowned conservation charity zoo
column2: winning countless awards for animal welfare
column3: education and business.

column1: Only six months ago the zoo had enjoyed its best year ever in 2019 with record-breaking visitor numbers and announced its 2030 Vision
column2: which included developing a national centre for science and conservation in the heart of the Midlands at Twycross Zoo.

column1: Anyone who can donate to help Twycross Zoo stay afloat
column2: can do so by visiting www.twycrosszoo.org/donate/";Twycross Zoo 'fighting to protect its future' as it gets further into debt;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiVGh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmRlcmJ5dGVsZWdyYXBoLmNvLnVrL2J1cnRvbi90d3ljcm9zcy16b28tZmlnaHRpbmctcHJvdGVjdC1mdXR1cmUtNDE2NDc3N9IBWGh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmRlcmJ5dGVsZWdyYXBoLmNvLnVrL2J1cnRvbi90d3ljcm9zcy16b28tZmlnaHRpbmctcHJvdGVjdC1mdXR1cmUtNDE2NDc3Ny5hbXA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://i2-prod.derbytelegraph.co.uk/incoming/article4165002.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/0_Untitled-design-2020-05-26T124505079.jpg;05/26/2020;"[{'sent': 'Sign up to FREE email alerts from DerbyshireLive - Daily Subscribe Thank you for subscribing'

column1: The Little Rock Zoo welcomed a new chimpanzee last month
column2: officials announced Thursday.

column1: Kianga is a 13-year-old female chimp who came to Little Rock from the Albuquerque Biological Park on a breeding recommendation from the Association of Zoos and Aquariums’ Chimpanzee Species Survival Plan. She arrived March 3.
According to her keepers
column2: Kianga is petite but savvy and has already made friends with the other chimps
column3: the zoo said in a news release.

column1: Since Kianga’s arrival
column2: the zoo has closed due to the covid-19 pandemic
column3: but anyone interested in learning about her and the zoo’s other chimpanzees can watch a video posted on the zoo’s Facebook page on Sunday.

column1: The zoo is also hosting daily virtual tours on Facebook. See the zoo's website for details.
Thirteen is considered adult age for female chimpanzees
column2: a Little Rock Zoo employee said in the video
column3: while males reach adult age around 15 or 16.

column1: @WLTradeNews;@WLTradeNews;NA;NA;2020-06-18;"Lip smacks made by chimpanzees follow a rhythm similar to human speech
column2: according to a new study.

column1: Monkeys are known to use this facial gesture
column2: characterised by fast-paced cycles of vertical jaw movement
column3: to communicate with each other.

column1: But scientists have
column2: for the first time
column3: observed these mouth signals in a great ape and found their lip smacks to have the same pace of human spoken language.

column1: They believe their findings
column2: published in the journal Biology Letters
column3: could be a “critical step” towards unlocking the mystery of how speech evolved in humans.

column1: Humans are thought to open their mouths between two and seven times per second while talking
column2: with each open-close cycle corresponding to a syllable.

column1: Two chimpanzees grooming each other (Dr Catherine Hobaiter/University of St Andrews)
This speech-like rhythm has also been observed in other monkey species such as gibbons
column2: orangutans and macaques.

column1: However
column2: the lip smacks of African great apes
column3: the closest species to humans
column4: had never been studied.

column1: So a team of researchers
column2: which included scientists from St Andrews University
column3: the University of York and the University of Warwick
column4: looked at data from four chimpanzee populations.

column1: They analysed the video recordings of these primates from Edinburgh Zoo and Leipzig Zoo in Germany
column2: alongside footage collected from wild communities in Uganda
column3: including the Kanyawara and the Waibira.

column1: Researchers found that chimpanzees made lip smacks while grooming another
column2: opening and closing their mouths at an average of four times per second.

column1: According to the experts
column2: these findings confirm that human speech has “ancient roots within primate communication”.

column1: They believe these mouth signals may have played a role in the evolution of a vocal system in humans that laid the foundation for speech.
Study author Dr Adriano Lameira
column2: from the department of psychology at the University of Warwick
column3: said: “Our results prove that spoken language was pulled together within our ancestral lineage using ‘ingredients’ that were already available and in use by other primates and hominids.

column1: “This dispels much of the scientific enigma that language evolution has represented so far.”
He added: “We found pronounced differences in rhythm between chimpanzee populations
column2: suggesting that these are not the automatic and stereotypical signals so often attributed to our ape cousins.

column1: “Instead
column2: just like in humans
column3: we should start seriously considering that individual differences
column4: social conventions and environmental factors may play a role in how chimpanzees engage ‘in conversation’ with one another.”";Chimpanzee lip smacks offer new insight into the evolution of human speech;https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiemh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmV2ZW5pbmdleHByZXNzLmNvLnVrL25ld3Mvc2NvdGxhbmQvY2hpbXBhbnplZS1saXAtc21hY2tzLW9mZmVyLW5ldy1pbnNpZ2h0LWludG8tdGhlLWV2b2x1dGlvbi1vZi1odW1hbi1zcGVlY2gv0gEA?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen;https://wpcluster.dctdigital.com/eveningexpress/wp-content/uploads/sites/54/2020/05/2.9295748-scaled.jpg;05/26/2020;[{'sent': 'Humans are thought to open their mouths between two and seven times per second while talking
